name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Axel Voss, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on copyright in the Digital Single Market (COM(2016)0593 – C8—0383/2016 – 2016/0280(COD)) (A8—0245/2018). Before I give the floor to the rapporteur, and as this debate is quite a significant one, I would urge colleagues to please adhere to their time so that we can give some catch—the—eye moments to colleagues who are not listed in the debate.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Today, we are actually faced with a very crucial question: to what extent can we still save our concept of ownership into a digital world? How can we adjust that? Do we really want to protect our property as we know it? And does the right of ownership still apply to us at all, or who owns it? Do we want to create a legal framework for the Internet here, so that owners are not basically robbed? That is the big question that we are dealing with here today, and to what extent this needs to be weighed up, balanced between freedom of expression and the theft of property. That is what it is all about. And do we want to allow everything on the Internet in the end, or do we still have the protection of values? I know that the whole discussion hangs on to the famous Article 13 and everything is focused on it. However, I would also like to take a very brief position on the other content that we have enshrined in this directive. That is, we have modern text and data mining, a commercial text and data mining that we implement there, which is very advanced, and also the world's first way in this direction. Through Article 12, we have created a possibility for Member States affected by this to rebalance the Reprobel judgment of the ECJ for authors and book publishers. With Articles 14ff., everything in the old order, we have created an opportunity for the artists – for the small artists, for actors, for all creatives – to get a better relationship with the rights holders, producer labels or even publishers, without always having to go to court, by offering opportunities to improve the relationship accordingly. With Article 11, we have a chance for our press publishers to get a better right. And that is what we are basically doing here, which is to give them only the right. How they deal with the law in the end is up to them, but they have the opportunity to get on a better footing with the appropriate platforms here, because here, too, the possibility prevails on the Internet and this has developed in recent years in such a way that what is available on the Internet is simply considered free and used in a way. , that publishers can no longer benefit from this. If we look at Article 13, there is often a failure to point out that we have created access, a definition, according to which we only drop the platforms under Article 13, which know full well that they are using the property of others and are making a lot of money with it. Ultimately, this becomes a question of how this can actually be implemented technically in the case of platforms that invite everyone to upload everything they want, where the platforms must also have a responsibility that we want to give them today – a responsibility to deal properly with the property of others and also to respect the property of others. That is the question at stake today. We have created a working, good basis for making progress here, which also gives the Member States guidance on how to implement the whole thing accordingly. That is why I believe that this is the right way forward here, in order to balance property rights, freedom of expression and the digital world. (Applause)

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is quite clear that there was a need for a European copyright reform in the light of the digital revolution. This directive affirms principles that Parliament has enshrined several times in recent years, in particular the responsibility of platforms and a better balance with the economic environment in which they operate. The media bombardment of the last few days has once again attempted to divert attention from the true scope of today's vote. This directive will not lead to censorship, nor to the restriction of the freedom of the network, which we defend and guarantee. It will not affect small and medium-sized enterprises, nor will it affect the dissemination of non-profit-making knowledge, such as free encyclopedias of the web. Behind the fake news of these days hide instead precise interests of those who want the network to continue to be a far west dominated by a few large platforms. On the contrary, the new rules aim to ensure fair compensation for authors and creators, who have always been the backbone of European culture and also represent an important part of our economy.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, dear rapporteurs, dear shadow rapporteurs, ladies and gentlemen of the European Parliament, let me first of all thank you for the constructive debate we have had over the last two and a half years. The Copyright Directive is an essential part of our Digital Single Market strategy. Therefore, on behalf of the European Commission, we are pleased to see that an interim political agreement has been reached on this important issue. Ladies and gentlemen, this is a crucial moment for European culture, for our digital economy and for the defence of our European values. The new Copyright Directive will achieve our common goal of adapting copyright to the twenty-first century. The directive will benefit those who make our European values what they are: authors, interpreters, journalists, press and book publishers, film and music producers, digital services, researchers, libraries and many others. It will help our press and the creative sector, it will strengthen artificial intelligence and make European cultural heritage more easily accessible to our citizens. Finally, for the first time in EU legislation, individual creators will benefit from specific provisions that will strengthen their negotiating position and help them obtain fair remuneration. Ladies and gentlemen, all these actors, all these authors look at us and expect the European Union to keep its promises. Better equipping our creators is to keep our culture alive. Better equipping our journalists is to keep our democracy alive. We believe that the text of the political agreement before you is balanced but also ambitious, it reconciles the different interests at stake. Creators and other rights holders will be fairly compensated, the impact on service providers will remain proportionate and users and their freedom of expression will be protected. Finally, let me mention that the Commission will issue a statement on the situation of the organisers of sporting events accompanying the adoption of the directive. The text of the declaration is attached to the legislative resolution. Therefore, I am pleased to hear your point of view and I remain in this expectation, while sincerely hoping that, through support for the Copyright Directive, we will all send, once again, a strong signal, a signal to our creators, our authors, our values.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: draft opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab A directive on copyright in the digital market is needed – we are all aware of this. The solutions developed years ago, at a time when InfoSoc and e-commerce directives were being adopted, have become obscetual. They inhibit innovation, create legal uncertainties to the business and, in some cases, dangerously distort market relationships.  It would seem clear, however, that this is not the case. This directive has become the subject of manipulation and fighting by corporate giants. Great players on both sides of the barricade, I stress – on both sides: both internet giants and press corporations – have spared neither black PR funding nor ideas for increasing manipulation over the past two years. Unfortunately, some of these manipulations are being manipulated. What is most appalling is that they have thus taken hostage the entities which are also the addressees of this directive. I am talking about scientists, educators, museum-goers, screenwriters who are waiting for solutions to this directive, but whose interests are not admonished today.  However, It seems to me that we have reached a critical point and this parliament is not in a position to make a rational decision on this issue, and we should address this in the next term of office.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. Madam President, everything has been said about the benefits of this text and I will not go back to it at length. In truth, I believe that there is only one question: what does this vote mean for Europe? Europe first honoured itself by being at the forefront of digital regulation and by becoming a global model in this area. Today, the choice is clear: either we confirm our leadership position or we give up it completely.  As we know, a trilogue agreement is not an a la carte text. It's all or nothing. There is no longer any possible leakage forward and to sabotage this agreement would first serve the interests of the GAFA (web giants) because it alone would benefit. It would not benefit the citizens, the authors, or the SMEs, but simply the GAFA.  What citizens want today is an internet that is fair, where platforms are accountable, where authors are paid, where everyday uses are protected. This is exactly what this text contains, and this afternoon's vote actually raises only one question: yes or no, do platforms have a responsibility to our society?  It is this one question that colleagues will have to answer in accountability and conscience. My answer and that of the Europeans is a firm and definitive 'yes'.

name: Michał BONI
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Article 13 raised doubts from the outset and therefore needed a legally clear compromise between the rights of authors, platforms and users.  The Internet is not only access to the works of famous authors and journalists. It's the work of digital wizards, commentators, going into millions every day. It is false to write that there is no general obligation to filter, because at the same time there is a legal requirement that everything be checked for licenses. Someone promotes their product with references to content that, for example, as pastiche should be exceptions. But will machine filtering recognize the nuances? You will end up with precautionary platforms. They have to take on the full burden of recognizing legality. I don't want corporations to decide whether to put content into circulation. This caution will turn into prevention for fear of penalties. In the past, prevention is censorship, in the digital world – it's a mistake, but it's also a loss of opportunity for earnings and reputation.  I am in favour of removing Article 13 from the Directive. Then I can only vote for it – and for what is very, very good – in it. And I thank Axel Voss for the hard work he has put into us being so close.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union certainly needs copyright reform. We are looking for a new balance, a balance between the interests of authors, users and platforms between them. We are looking for a balance for the 21st digital century, which is why I am glad that the proposal contains new exclusions from copyright protection for the benefit of science, for the benefit of teaching, for the preservation of cultural heritage.  I am glad that the proposal confirms the rights of publishers, but at the same time that it is willing to deal with parasites, with platforms that actually steal copyright content. Some have criticized the proposal for introducing internet censorship. But he would have introduced real internet censorship if he had prevented talented creators, talented authors, from being able to make a professional living in the digital environment with their talents. To create an environment where they would have to make a living as salesmen or taxi drivers, and only in the evening after work could they write down what they wanted. That would be real internet censorship. The result of the trilogue personally satisfyes me even more than the original mandate of the European Parliament, for which I am very happy.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, for the past two years we have debated different versions of Article 13 and now it is certain this text will change the internet as we know it and it will have vast negative effects on the way people share and acquire knowledge. We all had one great objective in mind: to help authors and performers, but in the end we failed to strike a balance between the rights of all the parties involved. This is a big mistake. Therefore, the only choice we have now is to delete Article 13. This is the minimum necessary to make this Directive less devastating for the European digital companies and our citizens who already demonstrate against this in the majority of capitals across the EU. The mandate we had from the European Parliament clearly protected and excluded the European small and medium-sized enterprises from the scope of Article 13. Unfortunately, this is no longer the case. Therefore, these SMEs will be obliged to buy expensive filtering technology, at the moment produced only by American giants. In the current text, all commercial websites and apps that allow users to post content will have to make best efforts to buy licenses for anything that the person may possibly upload in the future. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you Madam. I’m really sorry, but I did warn, so apologies for interrupting you. There is a blue-card request from Mr Rohde, but Mr Rohde you have speaking time so perhaps you could address it in your speaking time. I’ll reserve blue cards for those who are not involved in the debate.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, may I first of all congratulate Axel on a job very well done in getting this file to this particular stage. Now colleagues, my priority throughout has been to make sure that rightholders and creators continue to make a living in the creative industries and that their exclusive economic rights, including communication to the public, were protected. This was essential, given the emergence of new business models and platforms, which has led to an un-even playing field. It was not an easy negotiation, but I’m satisfied that my particular goal was achieved and that the necessary safeguards are in place. I will therefore be supporting the outcome in today’s votes, given the many improvements which have been made and these include: text and data mining will be possible for commercial purposes across the EU for the first time; Article 11 was improved during negotiations so that the future of publishing industry is secure; the right will only apply to individual words and small extracts of texts that are shared online; Article 13 clarifies that the platforms within the scope ‘communicatation to the public’ are no longer eligible for the e-commerce safe harbour and will be required to seek authorisation and fairly share revenues which they derive from copyright protected creative works. And the list goes on, and in particular the flexibility that we have been able to maintain for Member States is essential and there is not going to be any general monitoring of users. So, despite what some platforms have tried to persuade the general European public of, that has been nothing but an exercise of misleading and misinformation and this Parliament will push back against that type of exercise.  (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Sorry, Mr Rohde, you want to make a point.

name: Jens ROHDE
text: – Madam President, yes I do, because I find it absurd that you’re preventing a debate. Listen, the whole world is watching us today and everyone comes down in the plenary and holds their own homemade speeches and we don’t have a debate on such a crucial topic, because you’re preventing it. I don’t think that’s wise and I don’t think it’s fair. Sorry. (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I agree. I’d love everyone to have speaking time. I’m conscious that people have been in the Chamber who are not on the list and want to speak. You are on the list. I have to make a judgement call and I try and prioritise catch—the-eye. If you want this debate to go on longer and have an exchange, I am open to that but I will have a problem with the services. So I hope you can understand the reason for that decision. I hope you can make your point when I give you the floor, and I do take note.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, this morning is a very historic moment because, for the first time on a continent, a parliamentary assembly is trying to rebalance the relationship between the GAFA and those who feed them, that is, the creators and the press.  The creative economy, which brews 530 billion euros each year and employs 7.2 million employees in Europe, is seriously threatened by the unfairness of these financial reports. But there is at least as serious, if not immediately dangerous, the press economy is collapsing in pieces and, so far, no one knows how to fix it. The press, ladies and gentlemen, the press, Madam President, is the basis of democracy. When there is no free press, when there are no journalists in Google, Wikipedia, YouTube, or anywhere else, you will have no more information. You will have passions and rumors like the ones we have just had for a number of months.  This text is the only chance for European creators, media companies and journalists to rebalance the situation in their favour and protect their future. That is why we must vote on this text and vote for it in a block, refusing all the amendments. We have to take this text as a whole, because it is only a first step. More will be needed to rebalance this matter.  We are told about censorship, we are told about filtering, we are told about Wikipedia. Wikipedia is protected in the text, there is no censorship, there is no filtering, and why did these ideas reach this Chamber? Because for the first time in my fifteen years in office, we have been bombarded like vulgar cultural intellectual political prisoners by financial behemoths who will take all of our activities. We must vote this text as a whole, otherwise it will be an intellectual Munich, which will have very serious consequences for the future of the European continent.

name: Julia REDA
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for Three things are unprecedented in this debate on copyright. Firstly, 200 000 people demonstrated against this reform this weekend. Five million have signed a petition against upload filters. There has never been such a broad protest against an EU directive.  Secondly, protests have never been so consistently ignored by this House. Already in the summer, voters faced a massive disinformation campaign. Instead of dealing with criticism, every critical voice was covered in insults. Rumours were spread – as Mr Cavada has just done – emails came from bots, the EU Commission has called critics a mob, and the head of the CDU delegation, Mr Caspary, even says that demonstrators are paid. All these defamations are fictitious and easily refuted.  They were launched by a few lobby groups, and they were disseminated in the feuilleton of certain newspapers that hoped to profit from copyright reform. Unfortunately, this disinformation worked. Today, with images of mass demonstrations going around the world, some still believe that the emails do not come from real people. This belief that all criticism is driven by America has vaccinated her against addressing the substance of the concern. No matter that the warning about upload filters comes from the Federal Data Protection Commissioner, the UN Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Expression and from leading research centres.  (Interjections) Thirdly, no one, neither the Union nor the SPD nor the opposition, thinks this reform makes sense. Nobody wants to take political responsibility for upload filters that come with Article 13. The federal government will still vote for it.  Ladies and gentlemen, I would ask you to have all your time. I would also like to be able to make my speech. Thank you. Madam President, I am waiting for colleagues to calm down.  (The President asked Members to rest) Nobody in the Federal Government wants to take responsibility for the upload filters, not even Chancellor Merkel. The federal government will still vote for it. And since yesterday, we also know why this might be the case, because the FAZ has uncovered a horse-trading between Germany and France, according to which Germany seems to accept upload filters – in exchange for France's approval of the Nord Stream gas pipeline. The most tragic...  (Interjections) (The President urged Members to rest) Ladies and gentlemen, the most tragic thing about this process is that a new generation, which is going to the European elections for the first time this year, is learning its lesson. Your protests are worth nothing, politics will tip out lies about you and will not be impressed by factual arguments when it comes to hard-hitting geopolitical interests. This experience, this feeling of powerlessness, will have a lasting impact on them. Ladies and gentlemen, that is not the way we can make policy.  This directive must not be allowed to pass without amendment. Not only would this be devastating for freedom on the internet, it would also deprive an entire generation of confidence that politics works and that this Parliament represents the interests of the people. That is why we need to delete Articles 11 and 13.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Reda, did I understand you correctly that you assumed that I had described demonstrators as bought? If that were the case , because I understood you that way, I would like to make it very clear and repeat what I have said, and I would ask you to take only my words and not to deliberately misinterpret and misinterpret what you and other interested parties are. I said that there is now an apparent attempt to prevent the adoption of copyright even with bought demonstrators. I did not mean the thousands of young people and the thousands of people who take to the streets to exercise the right to demonstrate. I will always defend this because I am a staunch democrat. But if the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung in an article with the headline ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Julia REDA
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Caspary, I would like to thank Mr Caspary for his work on You have just read it yourself. You said that some of the protesters had been bought. And you were talking about EUR 450. We have heard all this. The EUR 450 you have talked about has been offered by the civil rights organisation EDRi to its members and volunteers to come to Brussels to attend lobby meetings. That is exactly what GEMA is doing. Do you not really believe that when, for example, members of the GEMA are invited to Brussels, who have to bear their own travel expenses? These are not bought demonstrators. (The President cut off the speaker) (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Rohde, did you indicate a point of order? Can I try and solve this by the following? You have one minute’s speaking time coming up in a moment. Do you want to use that now for a question?  (Interjection from Mr Rohde off micro) I can hear you, but I’m not sure everyone else can because your microphone is not on. I’m trying to make sure that the people who’ve come into this Chamber early to be in catch—the—eye get that moment. Because you are insisting, Mr Rohde, and it’s disrupting the debate, I would ask Ms Reda whether she will take a short question from you now.  I hope you will respect my decision from here on in.

name: Jens ROHDE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Reda, where is this upload filter in the text? Please answer!

name: Julia REDA
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Dear Mr. Rohde, I would like to thank mr. Rohde for his excellent work and for his excellent work. The text says: Platforms must prevent upload for reported content. You can try to obtain licenses, but the rights holders do not have to grant them a license and can insist on upload filters if in doubt. That is clearly stated in the text. (Applause and heckling)

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, today's session is more reminiscent of a football championship final than a rational parliamentary debate. I think I will speak for all of you if I say that we will all be relieved when this text is voted on, perhaps regardless of the outcome.  Although I fundamentally disagree with Articles 11 and 13, we have had two years of hard work and difficult negotiations. It is no secret that I am not satisfied with the result and I will recommend to my faction to vote against the proposal. We have missed the unique opportunity to modernise copyright to stimulate Europe's creative industries, encourage innovation and SMEs. Instead, we have a proposal on the table that envisages, excuse me, internet censorship, bullying of start-ups, a proposal that will lead to a decline in discussion forums and ultimately fall on every single user of social networks. It will end the Internet as we know it today. I could give a lot of concrete evidence for that, but time is running out. Moreover, I believe that if colleagues vote down this proposal, I underline it, they will vote, slap in the face to all those thousands of citizens who have written us daily warning emails, signed petitions and demonstrated in the streets. This will only prove why more and more states are sceptical about membership of this institution. The arrogance of power and the departure from citizens and their interests for the benefit of the interests of multinational corporations is exactly what we need to change.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, we’re being lobbied extensively by both sides of this debate. On one side I’m hearing from huge numbers of ordinary people who are concerned about the future of their Internet, and on the other side, we’ve got cocktail receptions, slick advertising, even saw a taxi on the way here advocating this legislation. Now don’t think for a second that the creative industries are uniformly behind this legislation, because they’re not. But the big players are the ones with the money to lobby and I care far more about the voices and views of my constituents, about ordinary people, than the views of lobbyists who are paid to tell us what they want us to think. Now, of course, what we need is a balance between protecting creators of copyrighted material and protecting the lawful rights of citizens going about their daily business. But this legislation, in particular Articles 11 and 13, does not deliver that balance. It is fundamentally illiberal, because in practice tech companies will end up treating citizens as guilty until proven innocent on copyright, content will end up being removed automatically. It will push one size fits all enforcement upon platforms across Europe, despite national copyright law being different from one country to the next. You can’t deal with that minefield, so legal content will end up being treated as though it is illegal. Many of you here are true believers in the European project, all I can say is what I see from the United Kingdom, British people’s opinions on this place haven’t changed very much, people who supported remain still support remain, people who voted leave still support leave generally speaking, but I have had people come to me to tell me that they voted to remain in 2016 but now would vote leave because of the Copyright Directive. In other European countries, if you vote for this today, you will drive a wedge between the European Union and young people across Europe. This is bad legislation. It is classic end-of-term legislation. This Parliament has three and half weeks to complete its business ready for the European elections and things are being rushed through because of that. They have not been properly and fully considered. Please listen to your constituents on this. Please don’t make the chasm between this Parliament and the people of the United Kingdom, the people of Europe, any wider than it already is. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I am one of the last people to say that he is a lobbyist, but I am very keen to distinguish between lobbyists. I would like to make it clear that this group, which is fighting for the right to its remuneration, cannot be called lobbyists.  I have a question for you: Do you distinguish between lobbyists working for economic operators and those who fight only to prevent them from being robbed of their wages?

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card answer. – I have no problem with people who want to make a living putting their points across – that is absolutely what they should do. And I also have no problem with average members of the public putting their points across. But what I’m seeing, time and time again, is that we are being pushed by the industry rather than being pushed by those creators, and actually when I hear from creators in my constituency I don’t hear of it as this one-sided idea that they desperately want this; I actually hear from both sides. But I’m also seeing from members of the public that they really are very, very concerned about the impact of 11 and 13.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, today we will vote on the copyright directive: it will be a historic day for creation in Europe or, on the contrary, a dark day for culture. The text presented is the result of nearly three years of meticulous work, its content does not correspond in any way to all these fake news and manipulations orchestrated by the giants of Silicon Valley. On the contrary, the text ensures a balance between the interests of creators and those of users. These users will be strengthened in their rights, especially in the face of online platforms that too often remove their yet legal content. This text is fundamental for our artists, they are entitled to a fair and equitable remuneration on the part of these platforms that are enriched by their works. Malraux said that culture does not inherit, it conquers, it has never been more true. So, as shadow rapporteur, I say yes to culture, yes to the rights of our authors, creators, publishers and artists.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, as we speak, many companies operating on the Internet and especially in the social media sector are applying censorship based solely on the wishes and interests of their owners. How are private bodies entitled to restrict fundamental freedoms? Content markings and categorization may be used as a tool to stigmatize or exterminate unwanted or competing ideas and persons. For example, only simply mentioning my name or sharing a speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on a specific social media is sufficient to punish the account holder with a penalty of exclusion for a relatively long time or to close his profile.  So if in this already gloomy environment for freedom of speech we add Orwellian-inspired software that will detect forbidden words, we understand that we are setting the foundations for a suppression of freedoms taken from the blackest pages of history, befitting only soviet regimes. So I ask you: Is this the future you want for the Union? We certainly do not, and that is why we will be voting against this report and, above all, this provision.

name: Sabine VERHEYEN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which For more than two and a half years, we have been wrangled here in Parliament and with the Member States to find a balanced compromise, and now we finally have a text that allows for more fairness on the Internet and, in particular, takes responsibility for the ruthlessly capitalising large corporations. The protection of intellectual property is a fundamental right, and those who vote against copyright today are voting for art and culture to become a breadless art again. In 2016, the annual median income of a European director and screenwriter was €19,000. That cannot be the aim of our society and not the aim of our policy. The same politicians who are fighting here full-bodied for the minimum wage, for adequate incomes, ignore a situation in which large capitalist corporations exploit cultural workers to the point of no longer. The aim of this policy is not to block, but to license content. And so that it does not become a mammoth task, the licensing procedures have been simplified. Freedom of expression is ensured, inter alia, in recital 70, Article 17 paragraphs 7, 8 and 9 and in many other areas. In addition, there are many exceptions to avoid disproportionate requirements. Non-commercial platforms and platforms such as Wikipedia, Dropbox, eBay are generally exempt from the policy, and special rules also apply to start-ups, micro- and small businesses. If they fall outside the exceptions, the proportionality of the measures and the proportionality behind them still apply. We bring fairness to the Internet, and platforms are the ones that make the most profit. Here we must finally create rules that allow fairness on the Internet and which finally put an end to the purest capitalism that we are witnessing here time and again.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: Madam President, this directive is the result of two and a half years of hard work and is expected by all European culture: artists, authors, journalists, producers, publishers, researchers. But it is also expected by users and consumers because it will bring legal certainty and take new uses out of the arbitrariness of platforms.  It is also proof that Europe is capable of asserting its sovereignty in the face of companies that have become monstrous by their size, but also by their practices of plundering our personal data, our private lives, our time, but also, in this case, the work of European authors and artists. How can we accept that the work is no longer remunerative because it is digital? On the contrary, all work deserves pay!  As for their aggressive and deceitful lobbying practices, we can no longer turn a blind eye to the multiple breaches of our transparency rules, the threats we have received, the obscure funding of a number of platforms and organizations. So I hope that this afternoon's vote will mark Act I of Europe's victorious fight against predatory ultraliberalism and for European culture.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We have just witnessed a dispute about what is in this directive. That is the essence of what is at stake, because the biggest problem with this directive is that its interpretation will be more important than the content itself, which Mr Voss so unconvincingly praises. This is where the greatest threat lies: in vague terms and definitions. The introduction of related rights for press publishers will mean a serious reduction in public debate. Only the largest publishers will be on the market, who already have a huge influence on shaping public opinion. They will share the profits from the link tax and create an information monopoly that smaller portals or bloggers will no longer be able to break. I therefore call for this directive to be rejected.

name: Jens ROHDE
text: Madam President! I have to say that it is quite incredible that today we have to listen to, especially a left wing, which is stretched to the bandwagon of the big tech giants - tech giants that do not even pay taxes! Should we just address a few of the misconceptions that have been in the debate: there is no link-tax, there is no upload filter. No matter how much Julia Reda claims, there's no upload filter! Nor are there any restrictions on the rights of individuals, quite the opposite, because responsibility now lies with the platforms. Today - and this is such fun - we happily accept that Facebook and other giants have poorly trained Indians in New Delhi to decide what should be on our platforms and what we can upload. However, we do not accept any technology which is not about monitoring the individual, but which is about monitoring the work of art to which the rights are entitled. This is a showdown with the biggest art theft in the history of the world by the big tech giants that don't pay taxes. Without a strong creative industry, we become economically poorer and we become spiritually poorer. I therefore hope that there will be a large majority voting in favour of the agreement we have made here today.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We want a free, but also at last fair, network. We want freedom and responsibility. We do not want censorship. None of us! Censorship is in China – but there is no copyright protection. What we want is for active, commercial platforms to finally have to license. Anything that is licensed is not filtered. It is a win-win situation, which we propose. The uploaders are getting legal certainty, there are no more waves of warnings, the platforms must finally take responsibility, and the authors and journalists are finally being paid appropriately. I call this a fair rule! And we bring justice into the free net that we all want.  We generally need rules for platform capitalism. They have to pay taxes, they have to take responsibility when there are disinformation campaigns. We need data protection – we have already decided on this. And copyright protection is, for me, part of such a regulatory package. It is not about over-regulation. It's just about fair rules. And authors are a minority in our society. They need our protection, they need our support.  Please vote in favour of this directive! It's about justice on the Internet.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I once welcomed the European harmonisation of copyright. But what is now on the table is far from courageous. Proponents of the reform, especially publishers and exploiters, say that the creatives have been strengthened. But five million people – and I would ask you to be creative – have now told us by signature that machines are not left to decisions on fundamental rights; there is the rule of law for that. And no matter how upload filters are described in Article 13 or 17, smaller providers cannot negotiate licenses with the whole world. This is absurd. The costly filtering obligation remains. Platform regulation is different: digital tax, ethical algorithms, strict antitrust law. That is why we reject the outcome of the trialogue. Let's find better solutions! It is not a question of market adjustment, but of free communication in the 21st century, analogue and digital.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Madam President, no one is against fair copyright and protecting the legitimate rights of authors, but this directive is about promoting the interests of multinational corporations and maximising their profits. It is also about controlling and shutting down free speech and dissent not approved of by the media and political establishments. Dissenting voices are already being de—platformed and de—monetised and this will institutionalise censorship. UKIP MEPs and others forced a vote on this directive using the Rules of Procedure, otherwise it would have gone through on the nod last year. Members should take note that the European elections will follow shortly. Voters should take note of which MEPs and which parties voted for this directive, and they should vote against them on 23 May. The European Union and the political and media establishments want to suppress free speech and dissent. If MEPs vote for this directive, then they deserve to lose their seats.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Internet has become what it is, it has become such a world in miniature thanks to the voluntary involvement of ordinary people and the lack of regulation. And that hurts you, because the development of the internet is an example of how our world could grow if it weren't for all your regulations, were it not for the heavy backpack of regulations and taxes that each of us has to bear every day. The Internet is just the last bastion of freedom, and it does not give you sleep, because it is proof that all your regulations and regulations, directives are really unnecessary and harmful, and the world would develop better without it, it would develop exactly like the internet. If it weren't for your ambitious plans, added values, leverage, sending strong signals, we would just be better and simple. That's why you try to destroy it, so you try to put your foot in the door every time there's an opportunity, but we don't want your foot in that door. Now you go back a few centimeters, because people are protesting, but we don't want you there at all, we don't want your regulations, we don't want your paws on the internet. It works well, creativity develops on the internet without any of your regulations.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: – Madam President, the famous Article 13 seeks to give the responsibility of the platforms in the event of copyright infringement. No more, no less, ladies and gentlemen. There are many copyright infringements on the internet caused by freedom that allows any user to freely raise what they want to digital platforms, including content that is protected by copyright, that is, that is, that they are owned by someone.  There is one thing we must be clear about: copyright is a property right like any other property right, material or not. And exist for artists to live off their works, so it is our duty to protect it, and I defend it unequivocally. Instead of holding each individual user accountable for the content they post, the platform will be responsible, because after all, the platform is the one who makes a profit from this content through advertising revenue or analysis of behavioral data. It is therefore the platform that must purchase the license or ensure that no one comes up with content without the owner's consent. I believe that the outcome of the agreement reached between trilogs by rapporteur Voss is very positive. It responds satisfactorily to the objective of correcting imbalances in the emergence of new agents that the digital environment has caused. And I think he deserves our full support.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Only Google is opposed to this reform, say proponents of the directive. But that is not true! On the other hand, the Federal Data Protection Commissioner, the UN Special Rapporteur on Human Rights, are many scientists and also many authors. This reform will lead to a stronger consumer, but not creative.  The truth is that this debate is now about much more than copyright. It is about dealing with our democracy. Five million people who sign a resolution are called mobbys by the Commission. Critical young people are referred to by political opponents, proponents of reform, as remote-controlled bots and computer programs. Demonstrators are accused of accepting a demo money of 450 euros and going to demonstrate for this reason only.  This debate is about the state of our democracy and we must take seriously, in particular, the young Europeans who have serious concerns about this reform, which will actually destroy their Internet as they know it.  Ladies and gentlemen, we must delete Article 13!  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Dennis RADTKE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Dear colleague, you have just listed who is now against the reform, everything but Google. The Minister for Justice and the leading candidate of the German Social Democrats, Mrs Barley, you have now forgotten in the list. What is their position now? She voted in favour in the Council, and now she is calling everywhere at the SPD events: stop the thief, we must vote against it! That is why I am not so clear now, and I hope that you will be able to clarify it a little now.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Dear Dennis, it is an honor to help you. The Federal Minister of Justice rejects upload filters and has had to give herself up to the Chancellor, who has concluded a deal with the French government, as reported by the FAZ yesterday. There is supposedly the exchange – and the FAZ does not just make such a thing so public – gas against upload filters. That is the reason.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for It's amazing what the FAZ has uncovered, isn't it? Apparently, unrelated connections are established, and somehow a swap is made between Nord Stream 2 on the one hand and the upload filters on the other. I do not believe that this is the style in which we should be making policy here. We should ask properly: do we really need these upload filters in order to enforce the completely undisputed copyright protection? Nobody wants to take their income from the artists, but is it really necessary to do this with these filters? And when it is said in this House that the law does not provide any filters at all, that is simply untrue. Because, of course, the law states that each platform must first check whether it actually infringes copyrights before making the content public. This check is a filter, and therefore an upload filter is included in this law. However, this upload filter leads to overblocking, it leads precisely to the fact that the small artists, who do not yet have a distribution, do not yet have a publisher, will not be able to distribute their content. And that is why what is happening here is anti-competitive. We should remove Article 13 from the Copyright Directive and adopt it otherwise, because copyright protection as such is important.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Madam President, the fact that this Directive took two and half years doesn’t make it better, unfortunately. The impact of this Directive on human rights is drastic, as has been pointed out by academics, digital rights NGOs and David Kaye, the UN Special Rapporteur on the promotion and protection of the right to freedom of opinion and expression, in particular when it comes to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which clearly states that everyone has the right to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers. This is exactly what Articles 11 and 13 will breach by creating obstacles in the way we seek, receive and impart information. It is clear that the rights of creators need to be protected, but creators and rightholders are not the same and we need to consider that this proposal is not balanced. We are putting the rights of a small group ahead of the rights of everyone else. The last time we voted in September, there were several alternatives on the table. Now that is not the case. It is either accept Articles 11 and 13 as is or reject them. I would like to urge my colleagues to vote to delete these articles. The damage to our fundamental rights will simply be too high.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: – Madam President, I would like to talk about the ridiculous conspiracy theory advanced by the corporate lobby, which is that those of us who want a free and open internet are in the pay of – or have been fooled or hoodwinked by – Google and Facebook.  That is just tosh! We have been fighting against the internet giants for years. We have been fighting for data protection. We have been fighting for people’s privacy. We have been fighting against their monopolistic tendencies. I would like to hit Google and Facebook where it hurts. I would like them to pay their taxes. I’m fighting for a digital tax. We’re fighting for strong e-privacy regulation, and we’re fighting for them to take editorial responsibility for what they’re doing.  This is not the right thing to do. I don’t trust Google and Facebook, but I do trust all the experts who say that Articles 11 and 13 are bad for the internet and should not be allowed to cause collateral damage.  (Applause)

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: Madam President, it is time to legislate to force the major North American digital groups to return to creators, publishers and journalists the value they are plundering to feed their networks in order to take away the advertising windfall that they are taking away from the media and the press.  We understand the pressures and appetites of the digital giants when we know that creation in the European Union, as Mr Cavada has just pointed out, amounts to 536 billion euros a year. Today, there are more people working in the creative and cultural sectors than in the automotive and telecom sectors combined.  What we are discussing here with the vote on the Copyright and Neighbouring Rights Directive is cultural diversity and pluralism. The directive creates a balanced legal framework requiring major platforms to respect creators and journalists, while providing users with legal certainty that does not exist until now. It guarantees a right to sharing and promotes everyone's access to knowledge while promoting the renewal of creation by protecting it. It is the creation and production of content that must be defended and not looted, and that is the purpose of this directive.

name: Stanisław ŻÓŁTEK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This version of the directive also introduces surveillance and censorship that are not in communist countries. Only the content was muddled to hide the real intention. But it is no longer worth persuading this parliament. The majority will vote anyway, as the head of the government says. So I turn to the voters in Europe. European citizens, if you do not want to lose the remnants of freedom, will have your governments to leave the European Union. Follow the footsteps of Brexit party italexit and polexit. Let us leave this creature, this bureaucratic monster, which is the European Union. Let us create a true European Union, a union of nations, from scratch. And let the divine hand defend you to vote for the Members who will support this directive. See how soon they will vote. (The speaker agreed to answer two questions raised by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – You said that you are against this directive, against the wages of the people of the world of culture. Have you said that you are in favour of polexit, or that you are the head of the Polexit party, whose main aim is to Polish out of the European Union?

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: 'blue card' question. Madam President, my speech is going to be very short, I will ask my colleague who is absolutely convincing about the idea that we should leave the European Union, why does he persist in coming here and sitting when it hurts him so much to be there?

name: Stanisław ŻÓŁTEK
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Yes, about a month ago, maybe a little more than a month ago, I publicly announced in this Parliament that I was in favour of Polish leave the European Union. I am also in favour of the exit of other countries and the creation of a new European Union, not the bureaucratic, self-looking and delicious monster that the Union is at the moment. I announced it publicly, so I don't understand the question too much. In Poland, too, I am doing everything I can to make this happen. And in Parliament, I have said this so far: if Parliament does not change, if the European Union does not change, it will have to go out. But what has happened recently, what is happening with this directive and other laws that have recently been introduced, just means that the Union has accelerated and changed, but it has not gone the way I wanted. She went the other way, so now you just have to go out and create it all over again. Because the current Union is a monster...  (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you, sir. You answered one question and there were two, but I don’t have the time to give you to continue.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking My colleague Axel Voss for the exceptional work he has done so far. This seems to me to be one of the most important battles of the entire mandate that we are about to conclude, because Europe is creativity, it is work and it is art, and the reason why this battle is the battle that defends Europe that Europeans love, is because it defends exactly that. Therefore, I would ask colleagues who are lashing out against this directive to make a careful assessment: if web platforms want to collect billions of dollars from advertising revenue, they must recognise the value of the work of those who allow them to make those receipts. So let them fight, perhaps, to prevent there from being advertising on Google: this would balance and make this whole debate more democratic. And dear Colleague Reda, you were talking about young people. Among those young people there are young people who today are paid three euros a piece for the excellent journalism they do, precisely because, at the origin of the supply chain, the platform does not pay the copyrights. If you want to defend them, defend the copyright.

name: Giorgos GRAMMATIKAKIS
text: Madam President, the battle for copyright began as a technical debate, but along the way it has evolved into a battle for the soul of Europe, namely its culture and values. The agreement not only ensures that artists and creators survive in the digital age. It also proves something more serious: that the European Union has the courage to confront the tech giants and their potential to mislead citizens and politicians. I am impressed that some colleagues do not seem to understand this. So after two and a half years of negotiations, five different committees and three plenary votes have the best possible result. It is even characteristic that the directive is supported by all the official bodies of authors and artists, who have very much discussed it. As rapporteur for the Socialists in the Committee on Culture, Public Health and Consumer Protection, I would therefore like to urge all colleagues who are in favour of an open and free and fair Internet to support the outcome of the tripartite dialogue. It will not only be a battle for the present of Europe but also for its future.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: – Madam President. The current Copyright Directive, that is to say, the proposal, fundamentally restricts internet freedom, namely Articles 11 and 13. That's why we recently turned off Wikipedia. According to Article 11, everything but very short snipts is to be copyrighted. Unfortunately, it is not specified what this means: whether it is three words or three sentences. Article 13 introduces the responsibility of social network operators for the fact that content is not stolen. It's as if the owner of the car park or the parking lot operator should be responsible for the fact that the car I park with him is not stolen. More than five million people have signed a petition against these two articles. That's more people than have said in favour of changing the time. I am therefore surprised at how the Commission and the Council are ignoring the will of the electorate and how they are subject to the influence of print publishers. I have tabled a proposal with a group of Members to delete Articles 11 and 13, but if this proposal passes, I will vote in favour of this directive.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Madam President, just as we have the right to free speech on the Internet, we also have the right to protection of copyright.  Cultural content and independent journalism are important building blocks of modern society. In the debate on this directive, some have tried to prove that these two rights are mutually exclusive. But that's not the case. A compromise needs to be found between them, which, following years of work, has been successfully concluded by the rapporteur, Axel Voss, following a number of warnings. In it, we focused only on those largest platforms that actually make big profits by advertising copyrighted content online and do not want to share it with authors.  If we want the survival of independent journalism, independent music, film works, if we want to maintain quality, then we need to move forward.  This directive will not solve all the problems, the dominance of American tech giants on the world wide web, but it is at least the beginning.  I will put myself on the side of creativity, creativity and support this document, because it goes to fairness on the Internet.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President; no one intends to end internet freedom. But the internet can't be lawless territory. There will be no content to exploit if there is no creation and there will be no creation if there is no fair remuneration.  This directive seeks to correct these imbalances in order to give more strength to creators, to rebalance the value chain, and I do not understand how, from the so-called left, some left-wing people defend the exploitation of creators and do not advocate the redistribution of wealth from large platforms. I don't understand.  No one co-arranges freedom of speech. No monitoring obligation is imposed. No links or memes are put at risk. This directive is at the height of the 21st century and in any case reinforces one thing: freedom of expression, freedom of creation and fair remuneration for the work carried out.  (He agreed to answer two questions posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure) ).

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I just wanted to ask Mr Blanco Lopez whether it is true that all non-commercial users will be exempt from liability in future if they download and download?

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – Mr President, I would like to ask the colleague who said that there is no creation if there is no fair remuneration for the creators, I ask him to quote the part of the Directive where it is explicit that there will be fair remuneration for breeders with it. It's just that I can't find her. There is censorship, but fair pay for creators is nowhere. Please quote me the part of the Directive where you are. I thank you!

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: "blue card" response. – It's about rebalancing the value chain. It is a question of large platforms contributing fair remuneration to creators. It's about paying the value of creation and it's not about exploding. That is why I reiterate that I do not understand certain voices from the left in favour of the benefits of a few to the detriment of the creation and work of the number of creators of our Europe, of our country.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". – I wanted to ask Mr Blanco Lopez whether it is true that all non-commercial users are exempted from liability as a result, and that, therefore, the legal industry can no longer sue ordinary citizens for infringement of copyright, but that in future this will be entirely the liability of the corresponding platforms.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: "blue card" response. –No, I don't think that's the case.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: – Madam President, I believe that a balanced text has been agreed which serves the interests of all parties. However, it has been a great disappointment for the world of sport that a specific mention of the rights of the organisers of sporting events has not been included, in accordance with the amendment to the original Article 12a, which was adopted by almost four hundred votes in favour in last September's plenary session. Despite requesting that a recital be included in relation to the Premier League/Murphy judgment, which provided that Member States could protect sporting events and that the Commission underfided to analyse protection schemes in order to harmonise them, the Commission has chosen to make only one general statement. I think it is as important to recognize the rights of creators as those of sporting event organizers over their own events. Of course, however, I am going to vote in favour of this text, because I think it is absolutely essential to preserve the rights of creators in Europe.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The debate here shows that we live lively, passionate parliamentarianism. We do not agree on many things. In any case, I do not think that anyone in this Chamber has been bored today. Copyright is no longer up-to-date, we agree. Internet giants deserve it, and many artists don't see it. Especially those who don't earn big, who don't produce hits on the running band, who don't write any top bestsellers, who need us to find appropriate solutions, because they live more and more precariously. We must not, therefore, destroy the Internet, but we must adapt copyright to the Internet. I am opposed to private Internet companies enforcing the rights of creatives, artists and artists at the expense of the freedom of information and expression of all. And that's why: The concept of comprehensive liability of the platforms leads to upload filters and these inevitably lead to censorship on the Internet. My concern in this whole process has always been to protect the creatives in particular. They should have the right to receive adequate and fair remuneration. In this respect, I am absolutely disappointed with the result in relation to what we voted on in the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would first of all like to thank the author of this report, Axel Voss, for his truly purposeful work and also for being brave, because we are resisting a major campaign against this new directive, and I will vote for it, because I think that the recast version balances very well the interests of both online platforms and authors, publishers and also us consumers.  Non-commercial platforms such as Wikipedia and educational platforms are exempt from charging. Article 13, which arouses the greatest emotions and has become a symbol against so-called censorship. But his critics have put forward no constructive proposal on how else to pay the rewards for the authors. In other words, how to prevent creators from being robbed of their author's works. And it's not just the authors, it's us, the consumers. It is in our interest that there are valuable works on the Internet. I will therefore vote in favour of this directive. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I would like to ask my colleague, when she talks about the anti-campaign, how she feels that even some representatives of Czech publishers are simply threatening us, that they hope that journalists will do their best to put a stop sign to those who vote against the opinion of Czech publishers. We're just going to be blocked in the print media. You think that's what kind of campaign is when you're talking about an anti-campaign? It's just blackmail, that's all, nothing less. And that's what we who have a different opinion are taking.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I would like to say that what I appreciate about this whole debate is openness, transparency, and ultimately we will make a democratic decision here. If you're being blackmailed, that's your business. I'm not going to be blackmailed. A campaign is a campaign. Arguments are put forward here and it is up to us to take these arguments into account and insist on a solution that is fair, that is good for the authors, that is good for consumers. Let us not be manipulated, let us defend, argue and vote.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, after almost three years of work, it is reasonable to reach a conclusion that is proportionate, fair and balanced. But what would not be excusable is that this European Parliament did not do its job of protecting fundamental rights.  Freedom of expression certainly is, but so is freedom of expression, as well as freedom of artistic creation and literary creation, as well as scientific and technical. It is in the Spanish Constitution and it is in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. And Parliament must also protect the most vulnerable. And certainly none, in the value chain, are the most vulnerable are the creators and artists, unprotected from the giants on the net, who violate our fundamental rights, who attack our privacy, who traffic with our data, who choose to pay their taxes and finance and organise massive troll campaigns that try to threaten and extort this European Parliament and its individual parliamentarians to make a decision.  The good news is that, after this directive, the internet will continue to exist and freedom of expression will also exist, but the subject, the creator, the artist, the most vulnerable in the value chain will be more protected.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I understand the position of GAFA, Google, Apple, Facebook, Amazon and all american platforms that are against this Directive because it threatens their huge profits in Europe every year by offering free content produced by European publishers, newspapers and authors. I understand that Mrs. Julia Reda is against it, because she is in favor of the generalization of piracy and therefore the party to which she belongs is called the Pirate Party, i.e. a party against copyright. I understand that some far right is against this Directive for obvious reasons because they are against the European Union, I do not understand that people, Members, who in their countries are full their mouths defending national culture and European culture, are against this Directive.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Madam President, we are witnessing a giant's roar that has nothing to do with safeguarding the interests of the creators or the users. Let us be clear, what is at stake is the distribution of the profits resulting from the dissemination of content without guaranteeing fair remuneration to creators. For these, inequalities, dependency and precariousness remain.  Filters are institutionalized, conditioning creative freedom, freedom of the press and free access to culture, while promoting greater concentration and monopoly in the digital sector. Culture is commercialized and normalized. We have put forward proposals to guarantee authors, artists, creators, interpreters and journalists a fair remuneration for their work and the use of their works, a fair remuneration compatible with the democratization and diversification of culture with the wide and free dissemination and enjoyment of content, without filters or censorship, which requires, in particular, the large platforms and producers, to give up the magnificent profits and redistribute them fairly by the creators.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, this copyright directive is certainly not perfect, it is rarely the case in our legislation, but it is nevertheless the result and compromise of five years of long negotiations, and I would like to warmly thank Axel Voss and the entire negotiating team for the tenacious work you have done in the face of many cross-pressures. The rights of authors must also be safeguarded in the digital age. It is clear that the work of others must not be commercially exploited without permission. It is also a fair and necessary principle in the digital world. It is essential to note that the Copyright Directive does not infringe and threaten freedom of expression, or does not mean filters or blocking, but specifically applies to online platforms whose main business is commercially exploiting, distributing and promoting copyrighted content. This requires a permit or a licence to do so in the future. It is a true and fair principle in the digital world.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Two reasons why we should not vote in favour of this directive. First of all, start-ups are not really exempt and are forced to take over filters from large companies after three years. This is a wonderful business model for the big American companies, and that is probably not what we could wish for.  It does not guarantee even what the directive is intended for – the very purpose of the directive, to achieve adequate remuneration for authors and artists. Because these rights are totally watered down in the recitals, and I think that is not what we want, but we want strong rights for the creative. And these are not guaranteed here, because only those who work for publishers are in the protection, and all the others who work freely do not have this protection. And that, I think, is exactly the wrong thing to do.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we Europeans must have a great ambition with this directive, make the world understand that even the actors in the digital ecosystem cannot trample on rights, violate people's dignity, exploit and underpaid the work of others, ignore the effort to invest in skills and professionalism and arm smear and intimidation campaigns against the representatives of European citizens. We know that today they are trying to protect their billionaire business interests: just think of the fact that the three largest US platforms are collecting 80% of advertising revenue and not returning adequate compensation to rightholders, authors and journalists. We have explained this to the great platforms of Silicon Valley: it is a battle of freedom, civility and responsibility, because freedom and cultural diversity are at stake. It is a battle to protect cultural diversity, the value of intellectual and creative work, pluralism of newspapers and quality journalism. We are defending millions of jobs for those in art, music, cinema, audiovisual, publishing and the survival of free and in-depth journalism. We have responded to gigantic fake news that we are restricting access to culture... That's not true! We have extended access and mandatory exceptions for the whole of Europe for those who have no commercial purpose. Wikipedia is also deceiving the people of the network.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, we have to remember why this directive was created, it was not created because people have difficulty accessing culture or the Internet, it was created because we have citizens who want to be able to enjoy the income from their work and cannot yet allow everyone to access and make use of this production without any kind of control. I want to remind you that piracy and contracourse are considered crimes, precisely because they subvert the laws of production and consumption, generating the use of the work of others and social inequality. In art, culture and journalism it is exactly the same as it happens, this is what we have to think about when we think that we have the right to use a text, a song or an image for our own benefit, without remunerating those who create it. If a creator wants to donate his work for free use he can do so, but if a creator wants to protect his right to use his work he cannot, he does not have the means to protect him from the digital space today. That is what this Directive is for. It is a shame the manipulation of citizens in this matter that prevented it from being given... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker.)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Commissioner, it is clear from today's debate that this is an extremely important thing that we need to regulate. You see that there are different positions even in the same political group.  It all started with the idea that we must, of course, have freedom of expression. At the same time, we must also have protection for the author and the reward for creation. We need a digital market, we also need a creative industry. We cannot without culture and people of culture must be rewarded.  Of course, it's not the best option in Article 11, 13, 14. A lot of work has been done, we've all talked to both sides. I believe that these articles should be voted on in order to be able to take a step forward and, of course, to consider improving this directive. But if we do nothing, I don't think the digital market or copyright protection have any gain. And, therefore, I urge that these articles, which have been amended by... (The President withdrew the speaker's word)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the third time I have intervened in plenary on the copyright directive. The first time I voted in favour of a return of the text to committee, seeking a better balance between the freedom of the network and the rights of those who produce a work of ingenuity, which has been done. The copyright directive is necessary to ensure fair remuneration for copyright in the digital world. At this time, my e-mail box is ceding to e-mails sent by European citizens at the invitation of online platforms, which are strongly opposed by their lobbies to retain the privileges of laws written in 2000, when the Internet was something else. The Internet is constantly evolving and, although it wants to, because it operates in a virtual world and therefore by definition boundless, it can never be restricted. The agreement reached in the trialogue does not provide for any censorship: on the contrary, it defends the freedom of the network, affirming the principle of responsibility for online platforms and for what they publish.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Madam President, almost at the end of this debate, I have to say that it is a very controversial debate and not because there is a difference of opinion, that this is good and in all debates there are usually. It is curious, we are facing a necessary regulation of a market – the digital market – and yet there is great passion and great controversy. It shocks me, because there is currently distortion in the digital single market, and what this regulation seeks is to regulate copyright. I believe that a great balance has been achieved; so why do we oppose regulation? Regulation is not equal to prohibition. It consists simply of putting some rules so that everyone, also in the digital market as well as in the commercial or the financial market, knows what the rules of the game are. That's all it is. Let us therefore vote on this directive in largeity.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I speak as Labour’s spokesperson on culture in the EU, and as someone who worked in the creative sector as the founder of a small to medium enterprise working in the digital sphere. This is the biggest reform of the EU copyright law for 15 years and it will curb the tech giant’s power over online content, including news and current affairs. Crucially, it will ensure that creative artists are fairly rewarded for their work. This reform package will address the unfair situation that means a song needs to be streamed 50 million times on YouTube before the artist can expect to earn the average UK salary. Copyright ensures authors, composers, artists, filmmakers and other creators, receive recognition, payment and protection for their works. It rewards creativity and stimulates investment in the creative sector, and I want to thank organisations such as UK music, directors UK and the Writers Guild of Great Britain who...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members of the European Parliament for this debate. Many speakers spoke about upload filters today. To be clear, upload filters are not mentioned in the text of the directive, but as we all know they are already used by big platforms. Voting down the directive will not take away upload filters. The directive will, on the contrary, give our citizens of the right to ask for reuploads and contest removals of content that they should be able to upload. This is a major improvement on the current situation.  The vote on the copyright directive is about Europe’s message to its creators. It is simple, we care about you and we protect you so that you continue your invaluable work and contribution to our culture. Culture is what European societies are built on. It is at the source of our values and our inspiration. The ultimate beneficiaries of this directive will be Europe’s citizens.  A modernised legal environment for copyright will improve their access to European arts, entertainment and quality journalism. This vote is also about the EU’s ability to tackle the complex and important legal challenges of the online environment. We understand that there are different voices and different opinions. This is normal in such an important debate.  We have listened to the different views and respect all of them. However, we believe that the text resulting from the trilogue is balanced and delivers on our objective to modernise European copyright law.  It is time to step up and make European copyright law fit for the digital age. Thank you President, thank you Mr Voss and shadow rapporteurs, thank you honourable Members.  (Applause)

name: Axel VOSS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Some of the speeches in today's debate show that the measure and the middle of this debate have actually been lost.
