There will be no censorship with this reform. This reform does not restrict legitimate freedom of expression. With this reform, we are creating legal certainty for the lawful handling of copyrighted works and offering much more opportunities for individual users and citizens. Google, Facebook, YouTube are doing a governance by shitstorm here, they spread disinformation, they use a lot of money to sneak public opinion. They show how easy it is to have younger groups of people in particular instrumentalised or instrumentalised.  That is why it is now also a question of whether a parliament and our democracy can still prevail against powerful platforms today. It is about the rule of law, it is about protecting a fundamental right that we are talking about here. It is about property, it is about the right to intellectual property, and it is also about fair remuneration for authors. It is now in our hands to save European cultural heritage and not leave it to the exploitation of tech monopolists. It is also in our hands today to offer our European creatives much-needed protection. I therefore ask you all to support today's proposal for a balanced reform.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Tuesday 26 March 2019.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Parliament has voted on a digital directive, known by its opponents as ACTA2. For months, it divided the inhabitants of European cities: it was supported by artists and publishers, opposed by some internet users, considering it an attempt to censor the network. On the one hand, the directive is really intended to strike at widespread piracy. These are, for example, all portals that copy the texts of individual newspapers or other media in their entirety. On the other hand, these regulations are one big scandal. Internet users have been deceived because the directive may directly restrict freedom of expression on the internet. It's an attempt to impose muzzle and censorship.  The most controversial in the so-called ACTA2 case is Article 11 and Article 13. The first implies granting publishers related rights, while the second imposes an obligation to filter content on the portal from the point of view of copyright. In the context of ACTA2, Article 3 of the Directive is also discussed, which provides that only research institutions for scientific purposes will be able to use data from publicly available resources, which constitutes a block for private institutions.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – The provisional agreement that was reached in the trilogues is not the balanced approach that we all should be voting on today. We see thousands of people protesting in various countries against Article 13; more than 4 million people signed a petition to delete Article 13. Does it matter nothing to us? The European Parliament is also very divided on this. It clearly shows that the copyright proposal has not reached the outcome that the majority will be happy about. We should protect the fundamental freedom of speech and not impose an obligation to use upload filters for service providers. While I am in favour of protecting our authors, I believe that the provisional agreement will bring more chaos and damage to the sector.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. "At the end of a long period of work, we are adopting new digital copyright rules. These improve the enforcement of copyright on the Internet, especially on platforms such as YouTube. It is important to remember that legislation only applies to large players whose main activity is the distribution of different materials. All others, including small startups or companies that have been operating for less than three years, are excluded. Large platforms must pay compensation to the authors in the same way as they already do with regard to the library or radio. At the same time, a private individual is not liable for any more of the content they share. Naturally, wedding videos, memes, collas and the like should be shared as before. Copyright guarantees the arrival of a creative employee and the opportunity to produce more music, literature and films for us. Without proper compensation, we don't have art in all its great forms – that's why the importance of copyright should not be underestimated.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. – This Directive intends to further modernise and harmonise the EU copyright framework to take account of technological developments and new channels for the distribution of protected content. The Directive focuses, in particular, on digital and cross-border uses, exceptions and limitations, on licensing facilitation, on rules ensuring a functioning market for the exploitation of works. Member States will have to give press publishers the right of protection for the online use of their publications by information society providers and service platforms. We welcome the balanced approach of future copyright rules in the digital age and, in particular, to ensure that artists and authors are fairly remunerated for their work. Thus, authors will be remunerated for both direct and indirect revenues obtained through the use of their activity, will benefit from new transparency obligations, and trade unions and other representative organisations will be able to initiate dispute resolution mechanisms on their part. The Member State shall ensure that authors and performers receive regularly and at least once a year up-to-date and comprehensive information on the exploitation of their works on all revenue generated and remuneration due.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Written. – I am voting for an update of copyright. The existing directive is outdated. This legislation ensures that the more content users upload, the more large platforms earn. Unfortunately, that money does not go to the authors, who put a lot of time, energy and money into their creations. The new copyright aims to put an end to this by holding platforms such as YouTube itself liable for copyright infringements. As a result, they are forced to ask permission from the author, for which they can ask for a fair fee. In my opinion, the fear of excessive blocking is unjustified. The new directive provides for the necessary guarantees for a free Internet. Many existing platforms were excluded and smaller platforms and startups have a separate arrangement. Moreover, a general filter is not mandatory and further specific exceptions are clearly defined (memes, snippets, hyperlinks, quotes, ...). I will never allow internet freedom to be curtailed, but it is clear that the authors in this story allow themselves to be eaten the cheese of bread by the big platforms. It is up to us to be with the pinkies and to adjust the legislation quickly if necessary, but it would be a shame to throw the child away with the bathwater.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Andrea Cozzolino on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development (COM(2018)0372 - C8-0227/2018 - 2018/0197 (COD)) (A8-0094/2019).

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, so here we are, with tomorrow's vote, we are delivering a good text to the next Parliament and to the work of the trialogue with the Commission and the Council. The European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund remain europe's largest public investment instruments for the period 2021-2027, despite the budget cuts presented by the Commission and which remain unacceptable to us in Parliament. It is therefore not a luxury, nor a waste of public resources. Regional policy supports job creation, business competitiveness, economic growth, sustainable development and improving the quality of life of citizens in all regions and cities of the Union. They are the essential tool to combat territorial and social inequalities, they work to leave no one behind, be they a person or a territory, a city, a peripheral community. This has been the case with Greece, Portugal and Ireland; this was the case with Italy after the seismic events of recent years, to promote the safety of our territories, starting with that extraordinary heritage that is cultural heritage. Despite the last ten years of austerity, which have reduced the policies of development and massive strategic investments for our countries – a dramatic reduction – in this context, regional policy has become increasingly important, without which public investment in the lagging Member States would have halved. So we are in the new regulation. There are five priorities: firstly, innovative, intelligent and inclusive development; a greener, low-carbon, resilient Europe that can meet the challenge of energy transition; a more interconnected Europe, improving people's mobility; a more social and inclusive Europe, implementing the European pillar of social rights, for new welfare, for a new pact between European citizens and Europe; a Europe that is closer to its citizens, promoting sustainable development and integrating cities and non-urban areas through local initiatives. This is all the choices that are at the heart of the new regulation for the ERDF and cohesion policy: we have established a thematic concentration which provides, for all categories of regions, to allocate at least 30% of the resources of the objective concerning the environmental challenge; we have introduced elements of flexibility to enable those regions that need them to have policies that are more attentive to local development; we have increased the minimum funding limit for urban areas and large cities to 10% and, at the same time, we have introduced an absolute novelty, namely a 5% that will have to be allocated to small municipalities and disadvantaged areas, such as mountain areas; we have introduced the possibility of financing programmes to strengthen public administrations; We have obtained, with the CPR, important instruments to allow ad hoc flexibility to co-finance strategic investments with the Structural Funds. In short, I believe that we have done a great deal of good work: thank you very much to all my fellow Members who have contributed to this important effort. It is now up to us, it is up to the debate, it is up to the vote, to the debate that we are going to have in this House and tomorrow for the vote. I know that there are still open questions, especially on environmental issues, which concern real interests for the lives of citizens: we will debate and vote. But I appeal to all of you: let us keep the vote on this instrument together and give the next Parliament a really innovative instrument that can generate development and growth.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, tomorrow’s vote is another milestone in the post-2020 negotiations of the shared management of EU funds, as the regulation on the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund sets up the main investment tools in research and innovation, climate change, connectivity and social infrastructure. On behalf of the European Commission, I would like to commend the rapporteur Mr Cozzolino, as well as the other Members of the European Parliament in the Committee on Regional Development (REGI), and in the other committees, for the efficiency and the quality of the work done in such a short time. We can only regret that the May elections are already so close, that despite this great effort, the timing of the first reading will not permit trilogues to start during the term of this Parliament. When looking into the REGI report, the Commission recognises and welcomes the effort to root the policy deeper in the territorial reality of every region and to ensure that no region is left behind.  However, as much as we share the objectives, we do not always agree on the best tools to achieve them. Allow me to raise two issues which are ‘thematic concentration’ and the ‘scope of support’. Concentration of resources on a limited number of priorities — thematic concentration, if you like — is a key principle that spurs efficiency of investment, avoiding funds from being distributed too thinly. This is why the ambitious levels of thematic concentration should be maintained. Cohesion policy should steer investments towards our common objectives of a smarter and greener Europe.  Concentration requirements at national level does not mean more centralisation. On the contrary, it allowed for greater flexibility in setting up regional concentration thresholds, as richer regions could compensate for poorer ones.  Member States where relations between national, regional and local partners are based on trust and open dialogue could easily achieve that. In terms of objectives, the Commission has proposed a clear vision by defining broad policy objectives of a smarter, greener, a better connected and more social Europe. Specific objectives — second level objectives, if you like — are not intended to describe an exhaustive menu of eligible actions, but rather to indicate their purpose. This was a further step from an action-based to a result-oriented approach. Unfortunately, we did not manage to get a mutual understanding on this issue.  Redefining the content of specific objectives, as proposed by the Parliament, notably in relation to broadband, urban mobility, tourism, natural resources and sports, would have significant policy implications. It would dilute thematic concentration and encourage sectoral project-based investments rather than an integrated approach, based on territorial strategies. The Commission has proposed to exclude from funding a few areas which were evaluated as having low impact and EU added-value, for example investment in landfills, or could have a long-term lock-in effect, preventing the achievement of agreed EU or international goals, for example investment in fossil fuels.  We are afraid that Parliament’s amendments could result in inefficiencies of investments.  Finally, the Commission would like to stress that provisions related to the implementation of the Stability and Growth Pact should not be introduced through sectoral legislation. The Commission has proposed that the Common Provisions Regulation should continue to regulate the link with economic governance, through the principle of macro-economic conditionality. I look forward to a fruitful debate and thank you.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for We have listened attentively to the Commissioner and her criticisms of the European Parliament's amendments – which, at the beginning of the discussion, promises to be interesting. I would like to say that Parliament has clearly supported the European Commission in terms of simplifying the procedure, reducing the number of targets, defining urban issues more clearly, but in some cases Parliament has a slightly different view from the European Commission, including as regards the setting of individual objectives – and this does not show less efficiency, but more programme coherence. Furthermore, the European Parliament has a slightly different view on exemptions from investment, just as it has a different opinion when it comes to thematic concentration. In any case, we believe that the European Regional Development Fund is a good proposal financially, but requires, in the Opinion of the European Parliament, the necessary amendments.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Mr President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur. The ERDF will remain one of the main investment tools for the European Union. Indeed, in the next MFF it will still account for about 25% of the budget. Therefore, the Committee on Budgetary Control will obviously be keen to ensure that the money is spent properly, effectively and efficiently. But we also recognise that it is an important fund, and therefore we would welcome most of the proposals put forward by the rapporteur, unlike maybe the Commission. I particularly wanted to welcome the initiative or the proposal to allocate a percentage of funds to rural areas for the first time, because we know in the past rural areas have sometimes felt left out from Cohesion Policy funding. I also wanted to say that I am very disappointed that, possibly, in the future, Wales will not be able to benefit from Structural Funds. We’ve been a huge net beneficiary of Structural Funds, and it’s sad that we might not be able to benefit from them in the future. But I want to say that the ERDF is an important source of funding. Even if the UK does leave the European Union – and I hope it doesn’t – I want ERDF to continue to be successful and I would like this Parliament to continue to fight for the ERDF in the future.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Rapporteur for the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – Mr President, Commissioner, allow me, on the committee I represent, to say our next position. We agreed on the need to provide more resources for modernising the infrastructure of poorer Member States so that new climate, transport and waste management targets can be met. Cohesion funds support is simply essential to meet these objectives, and in many countries they account for up to 50% of all public investment, and without these funds, they do not have the possibility to modernise.  I am disappointed because the REGI Committee did not respect our ENVI committee's recommendation to move support for sustainable urban mobility from Objective 3 to Objective 2 or to increase resources to combat climate change.   Transport emissions need to be reduced as soon as possible and it is therefore necessary to offer Member States the opportunity to finance the development of infrastructure for low-emission vehicles from these funds as well. I welcome the way in which the REGI Committee has taken a stand to finance measures against drought, floods and measures to reduce noise and light pollution. We have a lot of work to do and we are looking forward to the trialogue.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the revision of these funds is a major issue for our territories. For the projects financed to benefit the millions of European citizens, the funds must be managed efficiently and as closely as possible to the populations, and therefore to the regions. At the other end of the day, local authorities must have room for manoeuvre, particularly in transport. As rapporteur for the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I wished to go back to the Commission's original idea of excluding investments in the purchase of trains or in airport infrastructure from the scope. Transport is at the crossroads of three pillars: economic development, social cohesion and the just ecological transition. Investing in sustainable mobility means contributing fully to our sustainable development goals. Regions must be allowed to finance transport infrastructure, while respecting the environment. As for the airports that have been the subject of intense discussion in this House, I simply appeal to common sense: my political family has tabled amendments to allow investment in old airports, on the strict condition that they participate in improving the environmental record. This is a concrete step in the fight against climate change.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Let me start with a memoir of the beginning of this Parliament's term of office. Cohesion policy may not have been criticised at the time, but its existence, objectives and effectiveness have been questioned. I remember that when I was Minister of Culture, we managed to achieve a huge number of projects in Poland using European funds and with extremely positive results, and even arouse some jealousy about the quantity and quality of the goals achieved. Today, cohesion policy is not only defended, not only is it properly justified, but, in my opinion, extremely important, it is further valued. I agree with those who fought for cohesion policy to be: with Jan Olbrycht or with Danuta Hübner. It was then that their voices appeared in order to not only defend cohesion policy, but also strengthen it. I believe that at the moment it is necessary to rationalise the objectives, to ensure the coherence of the messages addressed primarily to local authorities, to correct certain things. But in general, I think we are dealing with a good document and a positive finale to the whole debate.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: PPE Group. –Mr President, the position of this House on the ERDF and also the Cohesion Fund will be voted on at first reading tomorrow. I believe that, thanks to the work of recent months, this Parliament has managed to enrich and improve the Commission's initial proposal.  We want the ERDF and the Cohesion Fund to be able to finance aid for natural disasters such as earthquakes, fires or floods, because European solidarity must be where a catastrophe is happening and should neither be late nor do so without resources.  We have managed to reflect the claims of our peripheral and outermost regions. We have been able to introduce the problem of depopulation, as crucial to the future of countries like Spain. Stopping the rural exodus begins by boosting the development of small population centres, and to this end we are committed to endothing ERDF resources to stimulate areas with democratic handicaps. Thanks to the joint work, we have made the fight against depopulation very present, and regional funds could be used to revitalize our peoples, especially with regard to social innovation and the green economy.  Leaving the winter we are in and delying into a demographic spring is about activating the sharing of resources. We must therefore ensure that those wishing to build their vital project in the field can do so. Priorities are clear: investment facilities, digital empowerment, improved public services and maternity aid.  I am fully convinced that, if we are betting on rural Europe today, tomorrow we will have much to celebrate and we will be able to do so from the pride of consolidating a welfare system based on the freedom, opportunities and equality of all families, regardless of where they live.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to praise Mr Cozzolino for the excellent cooperation and work on his report. As a former rapporteur for the Cohesion Fund, I’m certainly not happy about the budget the Commission has proposed for the Cohesion Fund, but I think that the text negotiated by the rapporteur for the two funds is the best possible one under the conditions, and I call on everyone to vote down any amendments that go against the negotiated text.  When I was the rapporteur I gave a very environmentally-friendly imprint. Today, I have not changed my belief, and let me say that all attempts aimed at impeding investments that could make some activities like co-generation and district heating more efficient are simply irrational.  At the same time, when it comes to investment in gas to replace more—polluting fossil fuels, it is surprising that such calls are coming from colleagues from countries that benefited from the funds for such activities and now want to prevent other Member States to do the same while, at the same time, they are promoting gas infrastructure like Nord Stream 2.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to express my thanks to the rapporteur and to all my fellow Members who have worked very well in committee on a fundamental text. I would just like to make a few quick points. The first is to share the negative opinion that has been expressed in the foreword by a little of all my fellow Members on the subject of cuts which, of course, do not give that perspective to which we have imagined that we can work, even in the past. But also to make very brief comments on three basic issues. The first, the one linked to the issue of speed of action: the aim of the approval is to be able to commit resources from 2021. The second consideration is that this regulation must overcome the delays that have characterised the past from the point of view of commitment and expenditure and, above all, prevent these delays from affecting and having consequences for the situation of the administrative capacity of the various regions. The third and final point is that of flexibility in order to make the best use of these resources at national level, in relation to the issues of the dis spin-off of resources.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur and all my colleagues in the Committee on Regional Development for the professionally prepared and approved legislative report on the proposal for a regulation on the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund.  The European Commission's proposal, which we have been working on, clearly presents a position that is for greater efficiency, greater flexibility and simplification of the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund. It was essential that this message and this trend be maintained in the report, which was adopted in the Committee on Regional Development.  I would like to highlight a few positive elements of the report. First, this is to increase the contribution of the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund to climate change objectives by 35% and 40% of the Cohesion Fund respectively. With regard to urban development, the proposal of the Committee on Regional Development is 10% with a view to strengthening the urban dimension of cohesion policy and supporting the successful implementation of the urban agenda.  For the Group of Liberals and Democrats, there are several key elements of the Regulation that are in the context of the reformed cohesion policy and its interaction with other sectoral Community policies. We support the Commission's proposal as regards thematic concentration based on gross national income, flexibility and adaptability at the level of individual regions. ALDE's position is to maintain the concentration of resources towards a smarter and lower carbon Europe. As regards the exclusion of investments from financing, I would like to stress that we need to have a balanced approach between specific objectives, eligible activities and the list of exclusions.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Club. – Dear Chairman, Respected Commissioner Jourová, we probably all agree in this chamber and we have a consensus that the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund are very important for Member States to make progress in regions lagging behind the Eu average, to bring them closer to more developed regions, to use the money for the right purpose, to promote European policies and shared value.  However, as a shadow rapporteur, I can say that I am disappointed with the result of this file, because it goes below the ambitions actually proposed by the European Commission because we know that in this period very much money has actually been spent for the wrong purposes. By investing in fossil fuels, in gas infrastructure, in everything that does not really contribute to the implementation of the policies we have agreed in the European Parliament, therefore, the circular economy. Today we will vote on the final completion of the Power Market Energy Union.  In fact, with a proposal like this, we will make it impossible for Member States to be able to use public money effectively from European funds for their own development.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The regional development funds are and will remain a useful means of developing rural areas in particular and are therefore irreplaceable in the social balance of European regions. What is new is a focus on a greener Europe; We also welcome that. But this is not about decorative cosmetics, but about a fundamental socio-ecological conversion. Let us make the following clear: social-ecological rethinking and structural change do not exist at zero cost. Specifically, we call for a minimum of 40% of ERDF funding to be used in all regions for projects in the field of social-ecological change – just transition. Secondly, we reject the fact that an ambitious catalogue of socio-ecological conversions can encourage investment in the construction of airports or even in fossil energy technology. Thirdly, it is important that integration projects on the ground are eligible regardless of the status of recognition and residence of the migrant women. The socio-ecological structural change must be actively shaped – we remain left-wing.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ... (inaudible) ... in our parliamentary term, that is to say, the approval and closure of the first reading on the regulation of the European Regional Development Fund. I will talk about the two major problems encountered. Firstly, the break-up of the share cofinanced by the Member State from the deficit included in the Stability Pact. Secondly, the stop to fossil funding. How can we present ourselves to our citizens by saying that this institution has, for the umpteenth time, rejected fundamental demands for the finances of local and regional authorities? How can we support Greta Thunberg's fantastic initiative and also the strike for the climate of our children, if this House then, by introducing dangerous exceptions, actually makes it possible to use the European Union's only truly redistributive policy for the investment of fossil fuels? For today, for the future, I call on all my fellow Members to support the amendments on the Stability Pact and the environment.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, regional development is the incest variant of development aid. It is shifting taxpayers' money within the European family without any kind of result. As with development aid, it is not that taxpayers' money goes from the rich to the poor – after all, the real rich no longer pay taxes at all. No, the money goes from the middle class to the super-rich in Eastern Europe, and those super-rich know with an army of advisers and lawyers who are skilfully and quickly emptying grant pots. So the taxpayer is again heavy the Sjaak, and when is this going to stop? (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: blue-card question. – I listened carefully to the contribution of colleague Stuger, and he talked about the ‘incest variant’. I’m totally stuck now, because we never saw him attending the Committee on Regional Development (REGI) when we debated the many results of the seventh cohesion report, under which the biggest investments in this period reached the poorer parts. How can you say such a thing? You are lost. Read your documents please. Can you comment?

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" answer. – Thank you for the sharp question. I'll also give a sharp answer. At the time when you were in the Committee on Regional Development, you were in Eastern Europe, I was in Eastern Europe, I was in Romania, I was in Bulgaria, to show the people of the Netherlands where that money is going. For example to plastic castles: 90 million to plastic castles as an attraction for tourists. There's not going to be a dog, really no dog. It's ridiculous. And if you sit there and spend that money from Dutch taxpayers, then you should be ashamed of yourself.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the well-known fairy tales of the European Union and its governments are repeated in the proposal for a regulation on the ERDF and cohesion funds to combat poverty, inequality and unemployment. These were judged in Greece, where in the years of the capitalist crisis Greece took the lead in the absorption of Euro-funds and poverty took off, part-time or flexible employment soared, plunging the people even deeper into deadlocks. Because EU funds, all sweats of the people from their savage tax evasion, are directed at strengthening EU monopolies. At the same time flood defences, fire-fighting, earthquake-related projects, vital needs for health and education remain unsatisfied on the basis of profits for monopolies and, in addition, fines, conditionality, the bill is passed on through engravings and taxation again to the people. With a strong JRC, the demands of the labour movement in the fight for total reversals will be given a stronger voice, so that all these funds will finance projects crucial to alleviating and meeting popular needs.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: Mr President, we prioritise cities from 5% to 10%. Fine, but we are also coming up with a novelty now, and the rapporteur and other colleagues also spoke of this: EUR 2.4 billion to strengthen the role of the villages, of those communities. The Espon indicates that 8 million people will be moving from villages, rural areas to the cities in the near future, and many young people with good training will not return. A pact for smart villages, which is what we called for in the resolution in October, and that must be done under the Finnish or Croatian Presidency. Commissioner, can I ask you to actively work on this and get an answer to it? The ERDF jumps in.  My second point: merging the two funds, the Cohesion Fund for Structure and the ERDF, the regional fund for more substantive development, simplification. That sounds nice, but in practice you see a dilution of both funds. It's about turning knowledge, Horizon Europe, into skill. With knowledge innovate, produce, export, spread sandwiches. That is the line that must apply to the whole of Europe, including Eastern Europe, and that is the starting point for this new economy in 2021-2027 that we are now calling for.  This is my last speech as a Dutchman here and I would like to have this recorded because those opportunities are in both sides of Europe – that is cohesion! – should stay.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, I know that we are already in pre-campaign mode, but it is completely unacceptable to accuse the cohesion policy of not helping both Greece and my country, Portugal. It's not just an intellectual and political dishonesty, it's a moral dishonesty. And so what we have done in this report is to ensure that cohesion policy continues, and continues, to reduce inequalities and to contribute to a Europe more social and closer to its regions and its citizens. This is why they pay particular attention to demographic, natural or structural and permanent disadvantages, such as the case of the outermost regions. It was more than fair to include the guarantee for these regions of ERDF and Cohesion Fund support in investments in waste facilities and management and environmental protection. Another important measure was the maintenance of infrastructure financing at its airports. However, Commissioner, I would like to tell you that I am very concerned about the effects of a thematic concentration at national level.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, regional development is an area where the EU contributes in particular by good targeting of common resources to quality projects and bypassing most administrative barriers at lower levels. Cohesion policy for countries like my Croatia is an important tool for reaching developed members. We want the standard that developed members have and that the working-age population stays in our country because without it we cannot build a better future. Both as a member of the Committee for Regional Development and as a representative from Croatia, I support a new approach, better set goals and orientation of the future with stronger support for sustainable and environmentally friendly solutions. I must stress once again that it is of utmost importance to continue to remove unnecessary administrative and financial burdens at all levels, to educate local and regional stakeholders and public administration and to make funds more accessible to those to whom they are primarily intended.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Mr President, for many parts of Europe, THE ERDF funds are an island of budgetary resources in an ocean of austerity. In less developed regions, these funds remain essential to support investment. For the outermost regions, the position of our Parliament is to reject the reduction proposed by the European Commission. For Mayotte, we will restore it to its rights compared to the previous programming. With regard to co-financing, while the Commission proposes to cut them to 70%, we propose to reduce them to 85%.  I believe that, after the adoption of the European Commission's renewed strategy for the UPRs, it is not possible for the Commission not to join us in our uncompromising defence of the outermost regions.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Mr President, the Regional Fund and the Cohesion Fund are key funds by which we are addressing development disparities in Europe. We can safely say that they are also the binders of the European Union. I therefore support the committee's view that we should not in any way reduce funding for these two funds. Otherwise, we will not perform this basic function in Europe. I very much support all efforts for green, innovative new jobs, to the transition to energy efficiency. However, I am pleased that my amendment has also been adopted to allo now de way to rural areas and, within that, 2.4 billion for the smart villages project. In Europe, there is a trend of internal migration, which is the basis for emptying the countryside and moving people to richer, more developed areas. And in this way, by this measure, we also address these problems. Creating new jobs in rural areas, strengthening new mobility models where there is no public transport in rural areas. On the other hand, modern, modern agricultural production, rural tourism, decentralised social jobs, where caring for the elderly is possible, and even more of a quality, to do in rural areas than in large cities. EHealth, decentralised energy, these are all opportunities that we put into the pool of these smart villages. All other renewable sourcing policies, digitalisation, are also being followed, and I am convinced that this is heading in the right direction. I will therefore also support this proposal.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund are the main investment instruments for employment, infrastructure and economic growth to support the regions. In recent years, we have been working precisely in the interests of these territories – I am taking the example of my own Sicily – which, without the Structural Funds, would have no future and to combat those obstacles that still block their use, aiming at simplifying procedures and reducing bureaucracy, but also at levels of cofinancing that favour the take-off of projects and so that the threat of macroeconomic conditionality does not mortify the territorial dimension. We have a duty to put states and regions in a position to use European resources, and to do so we must enter into the territorial reality which, experience shows, is now far from parameters that do not take account of real inequalities and territorial specificities such as island ones. A reform of the technical assistance mechanism for strengthening the capacities of public administrations and citizens' services is now essential. Only in this way will we reconnect the citizens of Europe with the Union.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund have as their main objective the increase of economic and social solidarity, while aiming to reduce the gaps between the levels of development of the different regions.  But at the same time, fellow members, we must be fair to each other and recognise the beneficial effects of these policies, both in Eastern Europe and in western Europe. In the current context, it is extremely important that ERDF investments contribute to the development of large networks of high-speed digital infrastructure, to the promotion of green and sustainable multimodal urban mobility.  Research and innovation in any field, attracting private investors to this end, creating strong partnerships, and transferring results on the ground must remain absolute priorities of European Union policies. It is essential to have a strengthening of cooperation between partners, including between those at local and regional level, within the same Member State or at cross-border level.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: Mr President, I also join the colleagues who have praised the work of our rapporteur. The text from our REGI committee seems relevant to me in more ways than one. It helps, among other things, to re-regionalize and flexibilize FEDER and cohesion funds in order to be more efficient, and above all to eliminate inequalities between territories. I also welcome the proposals that maintain thematic concentration at the regional level. This will, I hope, enable us to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion as closely as possible to the needs of our regions and the expectations of our fellow citizens. As an elected official or representative of the French outermost regions, I welcome measures that maintain or improve the consideration of the specificities of the UPRs, which are essential when we know that the ERDF is, in the UPRs, one of the main means of financing infrastructure, mobility and SMEs. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, I invite you to act in line with our thematic and environmental objectives, by supporting the amendments tabled by our group.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the Cohesion Fund and the ERDF are essential, crucial instruments for the convergence policy of The European regions, but they are in particular for the outermost regions.  I cannot fail to regret two absences here: first the absence of Commissioner Corina Creţu, and secondly, the absence, in her speech, of the Commission representative for the outermost regions. The report we are going to vote on here mentions this and, contrary to what has been done by the Socialist government Portuguese, this Parliament does not accept a cut in cohesion policy. Unlike the disinvestment that has been made by the Portuguese government in the outermost regions here, the approval of this new proposal for regions such as Madeira, which once again has instruments to promote investment in employment, innovation, housing, the integration of migrants, mobility and transport, is reinforced. We have a compromise agreement here in the European Parliament. I hope that there will be a clear commitment from the Member States, also from Portugal, on the final amounts so that we can have a next framework with more support for the outermost regions as well.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Dear Chairman, cohesion policy is the main instrument for promoting social, economic and territorial cohesion and solidarity between different regions. As the main investment policy, it represents one of the Union's most important achievements.  The new proposal contains some positive provisions to adapt funding to future needs. It is worth welcoming 80 measures to make it easier to use the funds. However, macroeconomic conditionality and increasing the burden of co-financing on countries and regions are not the solution to the current problems. Moreover, it will only further prevent regions with smaller budgets from submitting projects, and they need funds the most.  A greater degree of decentralisation, flexibility and stronger public administration capacities in the preparation and implementation of projects are needed. The future of cohesion and the Regional Development Fund depends on the budget. Brexit uncertainty and the refusal of some members to allocate additional funds must not jeopardise cohesion policy objectives.  I support the work of the rapporteur and thank him, in particular for taking into account Article 174 TB. treaty on the functioning of the European Union, which also directly includes the islands in the proposal.

name: Kerstin WESTPHAL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I think it is a great pity that the non-attached Member has now left instead of listening to what the ERDF is actually doing. Then he wouldn't have to tell as many stupid things as he just told. The ERDF is a programme of growth for all regions and, above all, for all citizens.  What we want is to invest heavily in a modern, digital Europe, in a green Europe, in a social Europe, in a Europe of people, in urban and rural life. This fund is indeed synonymous with research, innovation, new jobs, the fight against climate change. And especially before the European elections, it is so important to show people where European money is going. And the ERDF and the Cohesion Fund together represent a quarter of the budget. That is why it is important to tell people: money is coming back to your region, to your city. And there is meaningful spending on it.  Our group does not want to promote regional airports from which no one departs. Our group also does not want to promote gas pipelines or fossil fuels. We want a fund that puts important screws in place, that makes Europe fit and that is up to the challenge.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: drafts member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Mr President, a year and a half ago we were adopting a report in this Parliament, of which I had the honour of being an author, on how cohesion policy can combat demographic challenges and depopulation, which is what we need right now in Europe. Today, with the adoption of this ERDF Regulation, we make it a reality that these instruments can help combat depopulation. The work that has been incorporated through amendments is reflected in Article 8, which states that at least 5% of the ERDF has to be earmarked for these areas with demographic disadvantages. Article 10 also incorporates the possibility of specific funds in partnership agreements to combat the demographic challenge we currently have in Europe. It is essential for our rural environment that European policy and cohesion policy are a fundamental element in giving hope to all the peoples who are dying today. Let us therefore welcome a new Regulation which in Europe is sensitive to demographic challenges.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, the European Regional Development Fund is a very important instrument — as has already been said — to promote cohesion in European regions. I want to focus on a problem affecting many of these regions, and especially mine, Galicia. I am referring precisely to demographic decline and an ageing population.  The Galician Government is taking action — for example, on birth control, conciliation, daycare – and is now preparing a law of demographic momentum. But I am convinced that the Union and the Member States need to do more. Demographic decline should be a relevant criterion when it comes to the distribution of funds.  Recently, with my colleague Ramón Luis Valcárcel, I tabled a number of amendments to this Regulation, the result of which is a specific article, the 10a, relating to areas with demographic challenges, which pays greater attention to provinces and municipalities suffering from depopulation.  These territories are expected to be subject to specific plans that promote their attractiveness to the population, through, for example, increased investment. I also welcome the agreement of the Member State's partnership with the European Commission to include a fund aimed at addressing the demographic challenge for these territories.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, if there is a fundamental value in the European Union it is the value of solidarity, the value of social justice. That is why Europe cannot afford a step back in those policies that contain the necessary convergence between its regions. I welcome the improvements made to this proposal by the European Parliament, especially with regard to demographics. Efforts and resources are urgently needed to combat depopulation, against ageing that undermines the continent's economic vitality and sustainability, the survival of our social model and the social and territorial cohesion of the European Union itself. Proposals like these give meaning and content to the social and cohesive Europe that many of us advocate. Defending equality and territorial and social cohesion was always a flag. And it's very important for regions like mine, for Galicia. That's why this agreement is important.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by There is no doubt that the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund are some of the most effective instruments to strengthen real economic and social cohesion in the European Union and to compensate for regional disparities. It is these funds that allow us to support, among other things, local development in both rural and urban areas, small and medium-sized enterprises or digital technologies. I am pleased that we have managed to develop a balanced document that allows us to support such important investments as, among other things, railways. I also consider it particularly important to have more flexibility in the selection criteria, so that Member States and regions can decide on investments that are better suited to their individual needs.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, on Saturday over a million people marched in London calling for a public vote on Brexit. Amongst them were many busloads of people from my home region, the North-East of England. As the reality of Brexit has emerged, the less attractive it has become, as today’s survey of British social attitudes shows. My region has long benefited from substantial investment from the European Regional Development Fund: a billion pounds of EU funding between 2014-2020, bringing vital resources, creating jobs, upgrading our infrastructure and supporting local business. Some claim this is UK taxpayer money in the first place. Yes, it is, but the EU allocates on the basis of economic need, not political preference. It is solidarity in action. If we stay, the North—East is guaranteed millions of pounds. Outside, we are dependent on Westminster governments and at the mercy of them. This report includes Brexit-readiness clauses. Please, let’s not use them. Let’s stay.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, colleagues have said a lot about the importance of the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund in citizens' daily lives. I would like to point out that this new proposal is particularly important because we open the door to sports infrastructure, which is also important in the Member States, but also to greater investment in integrated territorial investments and development, and in particular to the minimum investment we prescribe for rural development.  We're all in the same boat. And the European Commission, and the Council, and us in the European Parliament. If we are talking about smart villages, if we are talking about responses to demographic challenges, if we are talking about the importance of uniform development – a Europe of equal opportunities and living standards for all citizens, then we must also show it with the budget and instruments we finance from the European budget. That is why it is important that this new regulation responds to the needs of our citizens and the uniform development of all Member States.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Jourová, this Parliament does its job of showing its weight and muscle by legislating, by the ordinary legislative procedure, nothing less than the ERDF and cohesion fund Regulation, which amount, respectively, to EUR 272 billion and EUR 46 billion — a quarter of the multiannual financial framework 2021-2027.  It is of importance, above all, to those most disadvantaged regions. It is vital for the outermost regions: in connectivity, in employment, in transport, in incorporation into trans-European networks. And it is a guarantee in terms of meeting the objectives of combating climate change, subjecting to environmental legislation and the circular economy, even when it comes to waste management. And that is why I would like to point out that there should be no exception to the commitment that no waste management incinerator should be financed from these Funds if it is not strictly subject to the environmental and circular economy legislation of the European Union.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we are speaking here today about something extremely important. We are speaking about the next budget, the next Cohesion Policy, and the next European Development Fund and Cohesion Fund. At the same time, we are speaking not only about money, we are also speaking about the policy, which is based on solidarity. The policy is meant to help the regions where convergence is not yet ‘finished business’, to increase GDP and employment and many other important things.  This is not ‘just’ about the money, but rather ‘also’ about the money. We know that in the next programming period there will be less money in Cohesion Policy, and whenever we face such a situation, we have to think about how to invest the money. The debate here was mainly about this topic. We are all aware that we want to do more with less money, and we need to do more. The value for money principle has to be maintained. It must not be spending; it must be smart and sustainable investment. There will always be the people who see plastic castles. I have always seen thousands, or tens of thousands, of new jobs, investments, growth of European industry, cleaner air, cleaner rivers and many other very visible results of the previous investments from European Cohesion Policy. It has to be kept, and that’s why when we try to have better value for money so that the investments are to the benefit of the citizens, we need to have that thematic concentration and a clear added value of the investments. I would like to thank Parliament for all the good work that hopefully, by the end of tomorrow, will result in a first reading position on the entire Cohesion Policy legislative package. It paves the way to restart the legislative process on all fronts as soon as possible in October.  If we want to avoid delays in launching the post-2020 programmes, not only do the regulations have to be adopted this year, but the programming documents in Member States and regions also have to be prepared and adopted in a timely manner. The Commission cannot agree to any proposals that jeopardise the efficiency and added value of Cohesion Policy projects.  I have a final comment, coming back to the question of smarter cities or smarter villages. For decades, European Cohesion Policy has tried to balance fairly the development of urban areas and rural areas, and this should remain in the future Cohesion Policy. The Common Provisions Regulation introduces a new dedicated policy objective – a Europe closer to citizens – by fostering the sustainable and integrated development of urban, rural and coastal areas through local initiatives, which should allow for a well-integrated, multi-sectoral approach to urban development. The strategies are expected to further improve coherence in interventions and strategic planning. The involvement of urban authorities will improve ownership.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that tomorrow's vote will be satisfied, on the one hand, with the broad consensus that the debate has led to and then, of course, also the critical comments that have come from the debate and the amendments tabled. As far as I am concerned, I would like to say this at the end of the debate. On the subject of thematic concentration, we have been in line with the indications given to us by the Commission, but we have strengthened, as was right, the regional dimension, otherwise it would have been a vain concentration from this point of view, such as, I would say to those who have raised the issue of the environment, that never has a programme concentrated so many resources over the next few years on tackling environmental challenges at local level. , territorial and regional: we are over 30% of the resources. Furthermore, the principle we have adopted, both in the CPR and in the regulation on flexibility, is very important in order to strengthen cofinancing, release annual resources and strengthen strategic investments through cohesion policy. Finally – it seems to me that a significant result, as all the rapporteurs and speakers have grasped – we put at the centre the issue, above all, of the realities that have suffered the most in recent years, where there have been obvious demographic declines but also a progressive disappearance of the function of the State and of Europe, fewer services, fewer opportunities. There we have intervened and we want to intervene with cohesion policy to bring millions of citizens back to the centre of European policy. This is the effort we are making and I hope that tomorrow's vote will consolidate this trend and enable us, especially with the next Parliament, to have a solid report that can open an important season of development and growth for our Europe.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 27 March 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The proposal for a European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund highlights the decisive role of these two funds in supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, developing the digital infrastructure network, promoting sustainable multimodal mobility, improving the living conditions of disadvantaged populations (such as Roma communities), to name but a few areas where significant progress can be achieved through the ERDF and the Cohesion Fund. I also agree with the point in the report that the ERDF should pay particular attention to demographic change as a priority area when designing and implementing programmes. However, I do not share the proposal's finding that cohesion policy should play a role in the reception and integration of refugees and migrants, much less agree that there would be a mutually reinforcing link between integration and local economic growth. The European Union's pressing demographic problem, the rapid ageing, must be remedied by family support policies and not by bringing third-country nationals to Europe.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the joint debate on: – the report by Evelyne Gebhardt and Axel Voss, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and the Committee on Legal Remedies, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on certain aspects of digital content contracts (COM(2015)0634 - C8-0394/201 5 – 2015/0287(COD)) (A8-0375/2017) and – a report by Pascal Arimont, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the amended proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on certain aspects of contracts for the sale of goods online or otherwise at a distance, amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 of the European Parliament and of the Council and Directive 2009/22/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Directive 1999/44/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council (COM(2017)0637 – C8-0379/2017 – 2015/0288(COD)) (A8-0043/2018).

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. In this Parliament we are always witnessing astonishing moments, in this case the always astonishing twists and turns in the cooperation with my co-rapporteur Axel Voss. This legislation is a lesson in the fact that the better argument can exist even and especially when the other side claims the opposite, without making better arguments themselves. With these two sister directives, we have achieved a great deal for European consumer protection. Consumer law is also applicable when customers do not pay in hard currency, but companies receive personal data that commercialises them, for example through targeted advertising. Consumer protection rights are, of course, the same – as was not originally intended – whether consumers download an app or rent or buy an online game, and regardless of whether the consumer does his/her purchases with and through a smart refrigerator. All software must be interoperable with any common hardware – this is also an important principle. Consumers are entitled to software updates that lead to a longer service life and greater security of internet-enabled and so-called smart products that would be useless and worthless without appropriate working software. The portability of content produced by consumers over a short or even long period of use of social networks, cloud services or smart speakers is another point: the maintenance of minimum harmonisation in the area of warranty periods, with a simultaneous extension of the time limit or for the reversal of the burden of proof from six months to one year or even two years in certain cases. I think that in doing so, we have really brought in components in this legislation, in these two directives, which have become real twin directives, thanks to our strong cooperation, including with the rapporteur, Mr Arimont, so that we have really got the best out of consumers that we have been able to get out. This was not taken for granted from the outset, because we had to fight hard, very, very hard for three years in order for this right to really be enforced in this way. The Commission did not always agree either. The right-wing side of this European Parliament has also had to swallow one or the other. But we have succeeded in enforcing this. With the help of a great, tireless and constantly struggling team, I have achieved the goal I had – a goal for which I was occasionally ridiculed at the beginning of this legislative process. I remember saying at the beginning: 'Yes, I want this right, it is to be developed, but it must not reduce the law in any Member State and any Member State'. It has been said that this is not possible, we want full harmonisation, and if we accept all the law in all the Member States, that is unacceptable. We did it. We have managed to achieve this, thanks in part to cooperation with the Commissioner, and also because we have achieved minimum harmonisation in certain areas, so that where there is wider law, this broader right can be maintained. Because the populists would have been happy if we had done it differently, because they would have had the best. So I'm incredibly proud of what we've achieved. At the same time, we have achieved an internationally unprecedented high and innovative consumer protection law – that is digital consumer protection at European level.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner and co-rapporteur, Mrs Gebhardt, I would like to thank mrs Gebhardt for her work on this report. First of all, I would like to thank the Commission very much for this very progressive proposal that has been made here in a new area. And I would like to thank the co-rapporteur, Mrs Gebhardt, very warmly for the very intensive cooperation that has resulted in something good as a result of the dispute. Mrs Gebhardt has driven consumer protection more forward, and I was actually more interested in digital contract rights with my legal background. In this way, we have been able to put the two together well and have achieved a reasonable and good result.  It took us a long time to do this, but there were also some problems to be avoided: on the one hand, the question of how we actually deal with the relationship with data protection, but also with copyright, and on the other hand, the great debate about how we actually deal with smart goods, where we first managed to include this in this directive. , and then afterwards, during the negotiations with the Council, we decided to include this smart goods in the report, which will come afterthat, from Pascal Arimont to the tangible goods – because that then played a reasonable role there. What we wanted to achieve in principle was, as far as possible, full harmonisation in individual legal consequences, and we basically did not want to leave any gaps in the treatment of these smart goods, which ultimately led us to say that the legal consequences of both legal acts must basically describe the same legal consequence. It doesn't matter if I buy the same property directly, order it online or download it. And that's what often mattered and where it became difficult to set a line. That is why I believe that, with the Digital Content Directive, we have also created a good basis for a common digital single market, that we have been able to achieve what I would like to see in the Council, from minimum harmonisation to full harmonisation at certain deadlines: the desire to create a digital single market in the digital sector as well. , and does not retract to including only his own BGB regulations or civil legislation, and says that we must not disturb this. No, it is precisely in this digital area that we must create a level where we are all convinced that full harmonisation at European level makes sense.  This directive, which we are discussing today, is intended to ensure that contractual remedies also apply to the provision of digital content throughout the Union. At present, this is only the case at EU level with the minimum requirements set out in the 1999 directive, and therefore there is still this difference in legislation, and therefore also legal uncertainty, which also affects consumer confidence in cross-border trade. That is why this step has now been taken. And we also want to ensure that it no longer makes any difference whether a consumer purchases the digital content or services in one Member State or another. With the reversal of the burden of proof and full harmonisation in this area, the legal situation in each Member State is clear.  That is why I think that we are taking an important step here and that we are making good progress on the digital level as well.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am happy to take up the picture of Mrs Gebhardt, who said that after a long, hard and tough struggle, we gave birth to twins. I myself don't have the ambition to have children, but having twins feels something like that. I know this from parents who did this or who were lucky enough to have twins. Getting twins is really a difficult thing, especially the first few months. That is exactly what we have achieved, because we have brought these twin directives into the world. With these two directives, we are, for the first time, putting in place uniform guarantee rules that apply throughout the EU, whether you buy online or offline, whether it is a piece of furniture, an app or a smartphone. By the way, the smartphone exemplifies how fluid the boundaries between classic goods and digital content have become. First of all, it's a device I can touch. However, this device runs on a digital operating system and is almost constantly connected to the Internet. And finally, I can also download all apps with the device – from photo editing to single exchange. The challenge was therefore to create coherent and coordinated guarantee rules that apply both to a classic non-digital product and to an operating system or a music streaming app, as uniformly as possible across the EU. This new legal framework applies where the purchased goods or the subscribed video streaming service breaks down. That is what it is all about. What is the consumer's right or what does the trader have to do, and what does he have to look at or consider? Basically, the following basic framework applies, which already exists when buying a classic product and which we are now introducing for both digital content and smart devices. Firstly, every consumer in the EU has at least two years' warranty on all goods and all digital content. Secondly, if something breaks within this two-year period, any consumer can request repair or repair or replacement from the dealer, discount or even termination of the contract with the return of money. As far as trade in goods in particular is concerned, we have been able to introduce some news. The first is to double the so-called time limit for reversal of the burden of proof. In other words, the consumer no longer has to prove after six months that his purchased goods were defective from the outset, but only after one year, and the Member States are free to increase this period to even two years. Secondly, it will be easier for the consumer to terminate the contract of sale. If a defect reappears after an initial repair or replacement, the customer can immediately terminate the purchase contract and receive his money back. Thirdly, manufacturers should also be made more accountable, because if they state that their equipment lasts a certain amount of time, the consumer should also be able to contact them directly to request repair or replacement. We are therefore clearly strengthening consumers by not only giving them clear rights, but also by asserting these rights throughout the EU. However, this standardisation should benefit not only consumers, but also businesses, especially small ones. In the future, they no longer need to worry about what law is to be applied if they want to sell to other European countries. And this is of particular benefit to small retailers who do not have a legal department, such as the large online retailers. With these new rules, we are strengthening the rights of consumers. We give businesses legal certainty and thus create confidence in our Digital Single Market and in cross-border trade in goods. I would therefore like to thank all the Colleagues who have worked on this text. We have shown in all – and I say to all – groups the will it takes to find compromises. And in times of polarization and black-and-white thinking, the good old compromise is the highest and best form of parliamentary democracy.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this is a great moment for me because, after quite a long time, we are coming to the end of the legislative process on these two proposals which are of great added value for EU consumers and business.  I am not so sure about twins. I would rather speak about two sisters. In my language ‘directive’ is ‘she’. One sister proved to be rather sporty and quite modern and the other one became fatter and fatter because she also swallowed the offline shopping – not only online – and she proved not to be easy to move in the process. But after all, we managed and it was thanks to the very good cooperation of the co—legislators and of course my special thanks go to Ms Gebhardt, Mr Arimont and Mr Voss, who know very well that we went through some dramatic moments and some moments of anxiety that there was no easy result which would fulfil the purpose.  But here we are. I think that the result is very good. We have all worked towards one common goal: ensuring effective protection for consumers, while at the same time removing barriers to the digital single market. For the first time, European consumers and businesses will be able to rely on largely harmonised rules, specifically designed for the supply of digital content and digital services. Moreover, the current sales rules are modernised with the specific regulation of smart goods. This will cover a rapidly growing market of a wide variety of products, ranging from smartphones and laptops to connected toys and smart home systems. The new rules will also ensure that consumers are adequately protected and more confident when buying smart goods across the EU. This includes receiving updates for digital elements that are necessary for a satisfactory use of the product. For businesses, the two proposals are an important step forward in terms of legal certainty. The digital content proposal achieves a very high degree of harmonisation and prevents legal fragmentation, while the sale of goods proposal also provides for fully harmonised conformity criteria and consumer remedies throughout the EU. This will decrease the costs of having to adjust to different national laws.  We have promised European consumers and businesses a modern and coherent set of contract rules for their everyday transactions and you are about to deliver this to them. I see many beautiful young people in the audience. I am sure that most of them go online for their shopping so I think I have a good message for the consumers who are also sitting here with us that there should be no bad surprises when you go shopping online from a different Member State because there are going to be highly harmonised contract tools on the digital single market.  So my message is: enjoy your shopping, don’t worry, be happy and be aware that the rules will work for your greater protection.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. – Mr President, I want to thank colleagues Voss, Gebhardt and Arimont for the work they have done with these two directives. As you may remember, the Committee on Legal Affairs failed to choose between maximum and minimum harmonisation, and that’s why we voted ourselves out of the game quite early. But anyway, this is a harmonisation exercise, because the EU needs to harmonise its consumer protection legislation. At the same time, the EU has introduced now a completely new layer of consumer protection for digital content. It has been a success in many ways. These two directives create a standard set of consumer and contract law rules that boost consumer confidence throughout the EU, when the digital business-to-consumer market is growing. These directives also restrict further fragmentation of the consumer legislation in the Member States. Finally, these two directives also clarify intermediary liability and enable sellers to pursue remedies against previous persons in the chain of transaction. So this is, again, one step towards more responsible supply chains.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, we have been talking recently about where Europe should not intervene, where we do not need the European Union. However, if there is an unconditional sector where action at European Union level is respected by the whole world, then this is the digital economy.  To compete with markets like China and the US, we need to be united and capitalise on our strengths, namely Europe is where the consumer has guaranteed rights. If in the analogue world we know where to find and make a claim for a defect of a coffee machine, for example, then in case of defect in a mobile application this was not the case until now. At least $70 million. users had a problem with their subscriptions, but only 10% of them received any compensation. The many of them don't even know who to turn to. As rapporteur for the ERA group in the Consumer Committee, we have worked to address this problem and it will now be clear where and how to obtain compensation for a faulty digital service.   I would particularly like to thank my colleagues Axel Voss and Pascal Arimont for the cooperation we have had and for being able to boast of a Consumer Directive, which is an example of a truly ambitious Europe.  A Europe that facilitates the lives of its citizens, a Europe that dictates consumer protection trends in the digital age.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D - Mr President, I would like to commend the important work done by the rapporteurs on this issue, on these two directives, and in particular by my colleague Evelyne Gebhardt, who has shown great strength of conviction on this issue. These two texts are a real step forward for European citizens and traders. They will allow us to update our consumer rules in the face of the rise of e-commerce, but also in the face of new uses and new services. I am pleased that we have reached an agreement that will ensure a simple understanding of these rules by citizens, by ensuring an alignment between the rules applicable to the sale of goods and the rules applicable to the provision of digital content. It is also quite positive that we cover the contents embedded in physical goods. Indeed, it would have been incomprehensible to protect the consumer only for material goods, without worrying about embedded software that ensures their proper functioning. With regard to the text on digital content, this is a particularly important directive because it will harmonize European rules in an area where sometimes there is still no national rule. We must also welcome the fact that we have reached an agreement that will provide a homogeneous European framework for this growing sector. We also wanted to take into account the reality of consumer use, including in the text contracts that are concluded against payment, but also contracts that are concluded by the collection of personal data. Today, much of the interactions that take place online are based on this type of exchange and it was essential to bring them into the scope of the text. These two texts therefore represent a step towards a genuine digital single market that protects consumers. This is the Europe we are fighting for.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank our three co-rapporteurs for their work as well. Having one set of rules for people who buy digital content and services across Europe will make life easier for consumers and businesses alike. The UK was the first country to introduce such legislation, but many Member States had no provisions at all, and if you want Europe to be a digital superpower, we can’t rely on old analogue regulations. In today’s modern economy, millions of people daily buy apps, subscribe to news outlets, or take part in online gaming, and these new rules will mean consumers have the same base-level of protection wherever they buy products. That also means less red tape for businesses that sell digital content or services across borders.
