It will also make it easier for people to cancel contracts or seek refunds if those products are not up to scratch, so the recent example of a French newspaper making it very easy to instantly subscribe online but then requiring all cancellations to be done by a paper form should be a thing of the past. So this is a win for consumers, it is a win for European businesses, and we in my Group will be supporting it.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I believe we can be happy with the result of these two important consumer files, especially as we are extending the European guarantee to online goods. While I supported extending the reversal of the burden of proof for the whole two years of the European guarantee, I believe that extending the ‘no questions asked’ guarantee from six months to a year is already a very positive step for consumers. Manufacturers need to build better and safer products. If your product cannot work for a year, it should not be on the market. This said, I believe the most important part of these two files is that it moves us closer to a single consumer rule-book for Europe. A single set of rules in Europe. If both traders and consumers know what the rules are and that it is the same everywhere, they will sell to anywhere and they will buy from everywhere. This is vital for the single market.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, e-commerce needs the confidence of consumers to grow, who must feel protected in online shopping as well as in purchases in traditional stores, whether they buy material goods or digital goods. With these two directives, the protections that exist today are being improved and made more usable for consumers. Furthermore, we do not add onerous tasks for sellers, especially if they are SMEs and micro-enterprises. Thus, in the presence of a lack of conformity, the buyer can ask the seller to repair or replace the goods and then have the right to a price reduction or termination of the contract. In this respect, however, we must also strengthen the protections of small retailers and SMEs against producers. In fact, for retailers, the costs incurred for repair or replacement can be very onerous and disproportionate to earnings. Furthermore, in terms of protection, it is now written in black and white that those who buy a digital asset will have the same protections as those who buy a material asset; so those who buy music or movies online will have the same protections as those who buy a CD or DVD. For example, if the download fails or the service is of poor quality, you will be entitled to replacement and refund, and this with a future-proof approach, because it will also apply to social media, video and audio sharing platforms and instant messaging services. This is important because consumers must have the highest possible protection regardless of the technology they use.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Commissioner, e-commerce has taken on considerable proportions due to the rise of new technologies and the internet and is becoming an essential vehicle for development for businesses, especially SMEs, and a guarantee of new opportunities for consumers. But it has also created serious distortions of competition with the advent of internet behemoths such as GAFA and anti-competitive practices, which have been fuelled by the lack of adequate regulatory defences. This text has therefore taken stock of the current economic challenge for consumer advocacy by providing a clear definition of digital content, guaranteeing consumers contractual compliance with their purchases, framing online business practices, establishing commercial sustainability guarantees that should mechanically encourage consumers and producers to consume and produce less , but better. Moreover, the balance of the French law on contractual aspects between sellers and consumers has finally been respected and this is good news.  Unfortunately, the perennial ideological refrain about the abolition of borders and obstacles to the single market is, on the other hand, very superfluous in the economic and social context we know.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, every day in the European Union millions of citizens access digital content and services and enter into contracts for this. In several Member States, however, there are no clear rules on purchases of digital content and there are multiple and different rules on online and offline contracts. With this new package we strengthen consumer rights, give a common framework of rights to citizens and businesses and ensure predictability for all, especially small and medium-sized enterprises.  We have thus eliminated the main obstacles related to contract law, which hinder cross-border trade. Including face-to-face sales was key. Only with a single set of rules for physical or virtual stores we give legal certainty to businesses and consumers. I also welcome the fact that the acquired rights of consumers in some Member States, such as Portugal, have been safeguarded.  Full harmonisation that did not respect the rights of these countries, which are more advanced in consumer protection, would be unfair and unacceptable.   We want to improve and not weaken consumer protection.  The Citizens' Europe we seek to build has an obligation to defend and guarantee these rights at all time.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, I’m speaking particularly about the new sale of goods directive, which is a significant achievement for consumers, businesses and indeed for the legal experts amongst us, for the future of EU contract law as a whole. As has been said, the new rights for sales of goods that function with software are very important and include rules protecting consumers who rely on updates for their smart phones or other devices that are connected to the internet.  More generally, Article 14 provides that repairs or replacements for defective goods must be free of charge. Other good points include that Article 20 requires Member States to take appropriate measures to inform consumers of their rights. Also to be welcomed is the strengthened emphasis on producer’s liability in Article 17. I hope this right can be improved further in future.  Finally, Member States will still be permitted to improve on this directive in key areas such as extending the reversal of burden of proof and protecting the short-term right to reject defective goods. I urge Member States to do so. In short, this is a directive well worth voting for and I will be pleased to do so.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues who have worked tirelessly to get this over the line. I think it’s very important for us, both in the European Union and from a digital single market perspective, that everyone in the European Union can have access to all the goods they want to buy – that we have a really harmonised approach. And I really like the fact that we are going the harmonisation way – the path that has led us to a very successful Europe. As a shadow rapporteur for the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI), I’ve worked tirelessly to get this over the line with our colleagues, and I’m very happy that the full harmonisation approach for the contract sales of goods was reached. I encourage everyone to keep working and to vote and support this proposal in the vote.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! We are here today with a victory for Europe's consumers. Today, European consumers are buying more and more goods over the Internet. They also do it across borders. This results in lower prices and offers a much greater choice for the consumer. Unfortunately, however, it can also be difficult to see what rights you have as a consumer. With these legislations, we are on the way to ensuring much better safeguards for European consumers. It's going to be a lot easier to avoid getting caught. This is really important and I think it is a big step for consumers, not least the fact that you certainly have the right to have your product repaired or a new one if things go wrong. There are also considerably greater demands on information from businesses to consumers. There's a lot of good things going on in this! In other words, it is one of the areas where, after a long time and hard work, not least from Mrs Gebhardt, we have shown that we have created an advantage for consumers when they shop online. So congratulations to European consumers today!

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are today considering drafts of two pieces of legislation that are essential for the building and good functioning of the European Digital Single Market. I would like to thank our rapporteurs, especially Mr Axel Voss, Mr Pascal Arimont, for their work in these two reports. They pursue two main objectives: firstly, to ensure the same rights for purchasers who purchase goods and services in both the traditional channel and the digital channel at a distance via the internet. Secondly, it is about harmonisation of rules across the Union and, above all, harmonisation between countries, because at the moment online sales are a very segmented market. This certainly creates too much uncertainty for consumers, and it is good that both reports have properly address this problem.  I would like to stress that the main objective of these two legislations is to protect consumer rights, and I am very pleased that these reports have been adopted. I ask my colleagues to support them in the vote.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I am happy to support this legislation, which improves consumer rights but, as a result, also promotes trade and therefore those who provide trade in an online environment. The digital market is a great opportunity and is growing in popularity with consumers, so their security also needs to be strengthened. The creation of a common European standard therefore means both greater comfort, greater simplification for us, for consumers and also for the providers of this trade.  I am glad that a solution has also been found on these technical issues, as well as political agreement, and that we can therefore vote on an agreement that is already on the table and which is already approved. In this situation, I would like to call on the Commissioner to take up and, with greater activity, to support negotiations with the Council on a directive against unfair commercial practices on the so-called dual quality of food, which is of great interest to our citizens.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, yes, it is a directive that we have been waiting for a very long time, because the main objective was to contribute to the growth of the digital market and sure that statistics show that most SMEs and consumers face in e-commerce with differences in quality, differences in rules at national level and sure that this directive will allow Member States to harmonise and ensure , on the one hand consumer protection, on the other hand, the development of cross-border trade and the development of e-commerce.  There are a lot of good proposals - what happens to the product that is non-compliant, what are the rules and the possibility of compensation for the buyer - so I think it is good to vote on this proposal for a directive and, obviously, after that, it is important that the Member States assimilate the directive for the development of the digital market.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is clear for me now, having also heard the debate and the statements of the rapporteurs, that this is a great opportunity for this Parliament to seal an important agreement that brings concrete benefits for European consumers and businesses. This is exactly what Europe needs at a time when the relevance and proximity of Union policies to its citizens are being so often questioned.  I therefore strongly encourage this House to endorse with its vote the political agreement on the digital contracts package and send a strong signal that we can live up to the challenge of ensuring EU consumers and businesses can fully benefit from the digital world. The Commission will take very seriously the cooperation with the Member States to ensure timely transposition and application of the package and ensure that they continue to meet the challenges of the digital single market.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you very much, Commissioner. I believe that, with this right, which we will vote on later, we will indeed do a great service to innovation and also to the digital sector, because we will create legal certainty, legal certainty for consumers, legal certainty for traders and legal certainty for manufacturers. And this is a very important question in an area that is increasingly on the move and in which we must ensure that there is a European response. I believe that we have preserved the achievements of national law and, at the same time, we have achieved an internationally unprecedented lyant and innovative level of consumer protection.  This is digital consumer protection at European level. This is digital consumer protection, just as it understands innovation and must ensure that we can create the best possible for citizens. And I am proud that we have succeeded in achieving this.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you to all the speakers. Once again, I would like to appeal to everyone in this House to agree to this result, which we found in the two related reports Digital Content and Online Sales Goods Directive, because we have taken a good step in both reports. We have set the guarantee harmonisation at two years, we have set the reversal of the burden of proof in our case in full harmonisation and in the other report between one and two years, so that this is also a further step for all consumers. It is important for the Digital Single Market, it is also important for legal certainty, it is important for consumers and it is also important for cross-border trade. I would therefore like to thank all those who have contributed to this, in particular the Commission, Pascal Arimont and Evelyn Gebhardt, for their intensive cooperation. Thank you very much.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work she has done on this. Firstly, three years of hard work, secondly, very many assemblies, thirdly, very good compromises, fourthly, the rights of consumers strengthened, fifthly, the lives of small entrepreneurs made it easier and better. With this in mind, I would like to thank all my colleagues, and I would ask you to vote in favour of this text. Thank you!

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Tuesday 26 March 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. – The high level of protection of consumers and harmonised contractual rights online are the key aspects of the Digital Single Market strategy, which aims to secure access to online goods and services for European companies and citizens. Due to the nature of shopping online, without any physical contact between customer and trader, people who are buying applications, videos, music, software, games, cloud storages and other products and services need to be better protected against unfair practices. Therefore, I welcome the proposal on contracts for the supply of digital content and digital services. We need harmonised rules applicable across the EU, since the European online retail market is still vastly segmented. Fragmentation creates additional barriers and obstacles not only to shopping online but also to the expansion of business practice to other states of the Union. The proposal sets specific conditions regarding software-updates, rights for remedies for faulty digital content and terminations of contracts. I am glad the issue of remedies was addressed on the EU level, since based on statistics only 10% of the 70 million Europeans who have had a problem with digital services received any kind of compensation. This directive unifies the rights of customers online with those shopping offline.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The sitting is resumed.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I would like to inform you that, pursuant to Rule 187, a group of Members at least at the lower threshold will present tomorrow, at the beginning of the debate on the Mobility package, a preliminary question concerning the admissibility of the following two reports: the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2006/22/EC as regards the implementing requirements and laying down specific rules for Directive 96/71/EC and Directive 2014/67/EU on the posting of drivers in the road transport sector (Kyllönen report); the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 561/2006 as regards the minimum requirements for maximum daily and weekly driving times, minimum breaks and daily and weekly rest periods and Regulation (EU) No 165/2014 as regards tachograph positioning (van de Camp report). I repeat that the problem will be raised tomorrow at the beginning of the debate on the mobility package. This is a preliminary question concerning the admissibility of the two reports under Rule 187.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Michel REIMON
text: Mr President, on a point of order, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work on I refer to Article 115, which requires us to work as transparently as possible. Since 11 February, we have had new rules on the transparency of rapporteurs. I have heard that since last night, when we opened the sitting here, there have been lobbying meetings between industry and this law, which we have now voted on. I would ask you, as President, to clarify and publish this, if it has taken place, that in the evening there are lobbying meetings with Members during a sitting and journalists were not allowed.  In particular, I would also like to ask you to take action: demonstrators have been insulted as paid demonstrators because they come from civil society and visit us here in the European Parliament to talk to us. As the European Parliament, we cannot allow people who come to us to be insulted as paid demonstrators. I would ask you, as President, to condemn this – publicly.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: They made a public appeal to me last night and again this morning not to interfere with the work of Members.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: on behalf of a number of Members sufficient to reach the low threshold. – Mr President, I speak on behalf of the 38+ Members. First of all, a big thank you to everybody who has worked so hard on protecting artists and creatives. Unfortunately, the Directive requires further adjustments. Last week, the rapporteur’s own national party publicly announced that the Directive, as it stands, is unclear on upload filters. They said that they would avoid upload filters in Germany’s implementation. Two hundred thousand people went on the streets and five million signed the petition. Let me recall that the title of the Directive is: ‘Copyright in the Digital Single Market’. It’s our duty to fix issues of great concern at European level and not in the national legislation. For this reason, I ask for your support to open the Directive to the amendments and request a vote on these amendments that so many of us have signed. (Applause)

name: Neena GILL
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I requested two minutes to speak and just brief honourable Members on the sustainable benchmark legislation. According to the OECD, EUR 6.2 billion are needed globally to make our economy more sustainable and to limit global warming to 2°. With this in mind, the report introduces two new types of benchmarks and encourages investments to be channelled towards those who are on a decarbonisation trajectory. It reduces the risk of greenwashes and obliges all benchmark administrators to disclose how they are aligned with the ESG (environmental, social and governance) criteria. Sustainability is a multifaceted concept. However, some aspects like diversity are often neglected. I recall the first time I spoke in the Chamber; it was with President Nicole Fontaine. Twenty years later, surprisingly, she remains the one and only female President of this House. Shocking. We claim to be global leaders when it comes to equality. Many female Members of this House leave to become Ministers, Prime Ministers, Commissioners, yet in these 20 years we’ve had no female Commission President, we’ve had no female President of the European Parliament, and we’ve had no female leader of the big political groups. It is highly unlikely I will be here in the ninth legislature, but I would urge this House to ensure that we address this injustice. The credibility of this Parliament depends on it. Like climate change, it is a race we can win. We can overcome gender inequality and make our political system more sustainable and diverse. If I may beg the indulgence of this Chamber for a few more seconds, given this could be my last plenary, it has been an honour and a privilege to serve in this House with so many passionate colleagues from across the Chamber. Brexit, I believe, is a colossal mistake, and I fear for the future of my constituents and future generations. As a committed European, I regret the path … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mrs Gill, please, we have understood what you want to say. Thank you, but there are women's group chairmen. Ska Keller, there is Mr Ska Keller. Gabriele Zimmer who are presidents.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the We have discussed this text in many assemblies, and a large majority of this Parliament and unanimity in committee have resulted in the vast majority of this Parliament supporting a programme such as Interreg. Interreg is exactly the opposite of what is happening with Brexit. Interreg means working together across borders, investing money from European coffers, bringing people together and working out solutions. I would like to thank all the colleagues who have worked on this and I would like to see Interreg get the money it deserves in the next Parliament.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, I voted against this report. I have no problem with the clocks going backwards and forwards, but I believe that Britain should go onto double summertime – BST throughout the winter, and an extra hour forward in the summer. Shifting an hour of daylight from mornings to the end of the working day would be better for tired drivers. Indeed, BRAKE says that 450 lives a year could be saved by such a move. It would create savings in carbon emissions, and lighter nights would boost outdoor tourism and leisure activities. Finally, on the subject of ticking clocks, five million people have signed a petition. We’ve broken the Government’s petitions website because Brexit is breaking Britain, but there is still time to fix it. Stop the clock. Revoke Article 50.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by For several years Now, I have been a strong supporter of not changing the time to either summer or winter, and I believe that the meaning of these changes has long been behind us. It is worth emphasizing what perturbations accompany us, when we change the time twice a year, to winter or summer. I also recognise the need for harmonisation, it is obvious, as well as a certain period of preparation for this decision. On the other hand, I believe that what is being proposed at the moment, namely this 18-month period, is far too long. In some ways, it is evidence of the failure of the European institutions, of a lack of readiness to act smoothly where this efficiency is expected of us. I therefore call for the time change to be stopped and for this preparatory period to be reduced to a maximum of one year.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, I just voted in favour of the report, for the abolition of this annual exchange between summer and winter time, and I voted resolutely in favour of the maintenance of daylight saving time. Why? Our citizens have also made it known en masse that they are for one time and that this is preferably daylight saving time. As far as I am concerned, it should have gone into the future more quickly. I had actually hoped that this weekend we would make the switch to daylight saving time for the very last time, but the report has ruled and Parliament has judged that we need some time, time for a coordination mechanism because we actually want to avoid a patchwork of time zones in the European Union at all costs, because that would of course be detrimental to our internal market. , for our economy. However, I am very pleased with this report and I hope, of course, that in 2021 we can switch to daylight saving time for good.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Dear Chairman, studies have shown that the change in clockwise times, which is conditioned by seasons and annual periods, has negatively affected health, transport, the energy system, agriculture, and therefore today I have agreed to abolish the change in time. However, I would be glad if we did not wait until 2021, if we could stay on summer time now, at the end of March. So, I have made a claim to this report, but my personal view is that we should stay on daylight saving time and I believe research will show that daylight saving time will win.  Normally, it has been left to Member States to decide for themselves, however, there will be coordination problems. I think it will have to be agreed since then, if we have different times, it will have a negative impact on borders and traffic, and therefore I advocate that daylight saving time is still in favour.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur The issue we are discussing is important. It affects virtually every citizen, who twice a year we disturb the rhythm of life, but also the calendar. It is also important for entrepreneurs, for the economy, for transport, for tourism. For these reasons, in short, I support change.  However, Let me be honest, I have big doubts. That is why I am calling here for us to consider how to achieve the objectives. Firstly, the timing of these changes is moving very radically, and this is already worrying, but secondly, we are in danger – as is the result of the discussions and attitudes of the Member States – that, after the changes, we will continue to have different times in different countries in the same single European Union. This should not be the case.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, I was very amused to hear my Labour colleague trying to turn this debate about the time change into a call to stop the clocks on Brexit. I tell you, if that were to happen, and there were to be another European election, I can’t imagine that there would be many Labour MEPs returned – precious few Tories either, for that matter.  Isn’t it extraordinary, though, that everyone takes it for granted that this is now an EU decision: that the issue of what time zone you’re in is no longer utterly for the Member State involved? For what it’s worth, I think there is a strong case for being permanently in summertime in the UK, where we’re attached to rules that reflect working patterns of a much earlier generation. It does seem to me a strange comment on how stealthily the idea of a European policy has increased over the last 20 years; it just goes without notice, without anyone passing comment that this is now decided here.  Whichever way we decide, it won’t end the argument. Whether this blow might be the be-all and the end-all – here, but here, upon this bank and shoal of time, we’d jump the life to come.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, mar bhall den ghrúpa oibre ar an ábhar seo le cúig nó sé bliana anuas, ar dtús faoi Helmut Weil, agus le déanaí, Pavel Svoboda ina chathaoirleach, bhí áthas an domhain orm gur ghlac an Pharlaimint leis an moladh anseo inniu: 410 i bhfabhar, 192 ina choinne. Dá bhrí sin, tá seans againn anois brú ar aghaidh leis an moladh seo agus deireadh a chur le hathrú an chloig dhá uair gach bliain san Aontas Eorpach.  Tugann 2021 seans do na Ballstáit anois féachaint air agus oibriú amach cé acu is fearr leo - am an tsamhraidh nó am an gheimhridh? Mé féin, is fearr liom am an tsamhraidh. Is dóigh liom, cosúil leis an Uasal Hannan, gur fearr le muintir na Breataine agus muintir na hÉireann am an tsamhraidh chomh maith. Dá bhrí sin, beimid le chéile ar an ábhar seo ar a laghad. Is maith sin.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Finally, there is something I could support and that I could vote for with a clear conscience. It turns out that you can write a document in which there are no references to women's rights, gender equality, LGBT, there are no ambitious plans, leverage effects, sending strong signals to the whole world. Although it has taken a few pages to abolish the time change, I still think it is some progress, so I was happy to vote in favour this time. The government is finally detaching from our watches. If someone wants to get up early, they can get up early without spinning their watches, and especially without forcing everyone else to do so. That is why I think this is one of the few good changes to this Parliament at the end of this term of office.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I supported this report, and I must say that I very much appreciated the ups and downs of citizens, european citizens, associated with this initiative. It was one of the biggest initiatives that was also heard very quickly by the Commission. For this reason, I think it is right that we were able to comment on this so quickly.  The deadline of 2021 may be too long for citizens. They expected a transition to a uniform time, either summer or winter maybe in a closer time. I confess that I am quite reserved on this matter. In principle, I accept the decision that both my Member State and, of course, the EU institutions will take. I'm able to live with that winter or even summer time. I think that Europe is already such a large continent, if I take it from Portugal to Finland, actually from part of the sub-equatorial climate zone to the Arctic Circle, so these are, I think, such marked differences that we have to accept certain differences.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Mr President, today we are voting on the reform of the internal electricity market and today we finally recognise energy communities and cooperatives as key players in the ecological transition. The transition will not be successful without the active participation of citizens and, above all, without democratization and decentralization of the energy system. We cannot let the energy transition remain in the hands of large companies, but we must put citizens at the centre.  Today we also put limits on capacity mechanisms – putting 2025 as a deadline for the most polluting thermal power plants. These complex mechanisms are, after all, covert subsidies to fossil fuels, such as coal, or nuclear power. However, climate urgency requires going much faster than electricity market reform envisages; social urgency also means leaving no one behind, putting alternatives to workers affected by changes in the productive model.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am against excessive regulation, excessive interference by governments, states in solutions that from time to time, and usually always result in certain financial costs. On the other hand, I would like to point out that, in this case, we are voting de facto on four proposals. These conclusions make up a whole, not entirely coherent, but it is good that, however, in some minims it is coherent. We have a strengthening of the audience itself here, which is extremely important, and we also have at least the desire, the intention, to strengthen climate protection, that is, to reduce emissions, and we are also trying to regulate those rules that have so far been so unbuttoned that they have de facto harmed everyone. On the other hand, I would like to draw attention to the need for transitional periods, for pre-emptive action, so that those who are the target or certain subject of these regulations have time to adapt to the conditions that the European Union or the European institutions are introducing.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, I am very pleased that an important package of directives and regulations aimed at reforming the European electricity market has been adopted today by a large majority. This is the last piece of the so-called clean energy package. Significant steps have been taken during this period to develop the European Union of Electricity. Why is this important? Because improving the functioning of the electricity market is a prerequisite for improving energy security and for us to be able to increase the share of renewable energies in our energy systems. The Nordic and Baltic countries already have a functioning electricity market, and spreading this model to the rest of Europe is an important step. Europe's climate and energy measures are proof that we are capable of cooperation. In the forthcoming parliamentary term, however, even more needs to be done and the level of ambition raised. A well-functioning electricity market enables stricter emission reduction targets.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I support the proposals put forward relating to the internal market for electricity, particularly the efforts to phase out subsidies for coal—fired power plants. While this is indeed something that would be a challenge for my own country, Ireland, we must drive forward the energy transition, and restricting state aid available to power plants provides a twofold benefit by divesting investment from fossil fuels and making this investment available to renewable energy. After the passing of the Fossil Fuel Divestment Act in Ireland in December 2018 it is encouraging to see the European Union taking a similar approach to the question of fossil fuels. Having helped to deliver the 32% renewable energy target last year as a rapporteur for this file, I am certain that investment in renewable energy is investment in a cleaner future and a step in the right direction. I warmly welcome this legislation as it will make the market more suitable for renewables and allow us to meet our important, if challenging, targets.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, electricity and the electricity market are an essential part of our internal market. For this, I generally want the market to be unhindered, so that there are indeed no insurmountable barriers between Member States. Unnecessary regulation certainly prevents such a market. However, this is not the case with this particular initiative and legislation. I think that this fits within the broader framework of the Energy Union, and here the European Union has undoubtedly had quite significant debt for a long time. We are gradually deleting it, which is why I welcome this legislation.  I think that this is of course also of interest to citizens, and we are responding to the specific demands that climate change brings, secondly, we are responding to the position of consumers in this internal market, we are righting competition between different types of energy and within electricity, and at the same time we are trying to maintain this system as long-term, albeit ambitious.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The work on the Gas Directive has been difficult and lengthy. It is very good that an agreement has been reached. The greatest achievement of the new directive is the inclusion of the third energy package of all import pipelines within the European Union, including in territorial waters. Gas supply infrastructure from third countries will also be covered, so that new pipelines will not be able to be built in a legal vacuum, as was the case with Nord Stream 1. The legal change will have a positive impact on Europe's energy and price security. I hope that the new rules will apply to the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline as soon as possible. From here, I would like to thank Jerzy Buzek and the entire Negotiating Team of the European Parliament for their efforts and great commitment to the negotiations. I supported the directive with conviction in today's vote.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by There is no doubt that the internal electricity market in the European Union needs to be changed. Energy consumers should be empowered under this plan, cross-border trade should be improved, security of supply should be ensured, electricity production from friendly sources should be facilitated and, consequently, a healthier environment for citizens, a better climate. To achieve this, we need to move to a low-carbon electricity production system, to integrate a large number of distributed renewable energy sources, to introduce decentralised energy production, of course also with the parallel involvement of electricity consumers themselves, but what is very important is that we must create an effective capacity market, with public support, without that, without that, we will not achieve this objective. The legislation we are debating is going in this direction, which is why I support it.

name: Babette WINTER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I abstained in the final vote on copyright after the request for a split vote on Article 13, which I co-signed, was rejected. Intellectual property rights must also be preserved and enforced in the digital world. Remunerate instead of banning is my guideline. And in the version that has now been adopted, licensing is the aim, but I would have found flat-rate allowances more appropriate in order to avoid technical filtering in case of doubt. Because this has brought a lot of people onto the streets. That is why I could not agree.  However, I did not refuse either, as I think it is right to hold the platforms that make profits with their business model from uploads, from data. There are also good results for science and education, as well as for the rights of creatives and publishers. As a result, I was unable to reject the directive in its entirety.  I am now counting on the transposition of the directive into national law to achieve a further balance between diversity on the net and the enforcement of copyright protection.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, today we took a very important step. A step to give the answer that freedom stops where the violation of each other's rights begins. Europe's creators, writers and journalists must be compensated when their work is used by the major platforms. Copyright can also work in the digital single market. Start-ups, the platforms that have now been launched, which have no shelf life of more than three years, which have a turnover of less than ten million, which have fewer than five million visitors per month, should not be subject to controls and specifications that exist on the major platforms. However, they should all pay compensation to the authors. It is the creators who give meaning to all this effort. The digital world must be governed by rules. Even as digital life evolves more rapidly than legislation, we are here as co-laws and we must give citizens the tools to protect their jobs.

name: Michael DETJEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I voted against the directive today. I am afraid that Parliament has today cleared the way for an undemocratic censorship machine which will restrict the Internet solely for private interests, economic interests and without any democratic control. We have thus authorized the gaffers to censor the Internet. On the pretext of protecting intellectual property, freedom of expression will be abolished. Private censorship is becoming stronger than state censorship has ever been, algorithms will control opinions. This has not been a good day for IT creators, it has not been a good day for cultural workers, and it was a black day for the Internet.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Mr President, an author's directive is certainly necessary, we all need it, and most of all, of course, the authors.  However, it is clear that this directive does not constitute a victory for anyone and is actually turning the Internet into a space of robotised censorship by the nal of online giants. And just a week after the second astronomical penalty imposed by the European Commission on Google for abusing market position, this copyright directive once again leaves room for abuse and interference with rights and market relationships.  In particular, we have always pointed to the completely vague role of so-called robotised censors or censor filters and the fact that these filters will be able to thoroughly encroa this day in the rights of Internet users. And I fear that, in its implementation, this directive will turn into its opposite in terms of purpose, effectively limiting the role of the Internet as we know it, and also stifling the creativity that Europe also needs.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am against the compromise of the Copyright Directive because of Article 13, now 17. I welcome a right that protects content, rewards artists, writers, musicians, journalists. Intellectual property must not be free. Anyone who puts it on the Internet has to pay for it. However, the control of protected works by upload filters is error-prone. Algorithms do not adequately recognize the differences between corporate law and copied content. It is by no means a dispute between young and old, analogue and digital. I hope that the many concerns will be taken into account in the implementation of the copyright directive that has just been adopted in the Member States. With all the necessary control, there must be no restriction of freedom of expression. The Internet must be fair, open and still accessible to all.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Mr President, I voted against the agreement reached in the trialoga under the new Copyright Directive. I believe that a coherent text thus does not guarantee a balance between respect for consumer rights and fair pay for rightholders.  The speed with which new technologies are developing undoubtedly necessitas a renewal of copyright legislation. However, this reform should not and should not happen at all costs. The unprecedented wave of public reactions is in itself indicative of the controversial texts crossing the red lines. For me, such a red line is Article 13 in its current form. Yes, creators must be supported and begin to receive a decent reward for their work. However, freedom of expression on the internet cannot be used as a bargaining chip to achieve these objectives. I cannot give my support for a reform that will create prerequisites for filtering consumer content on the web and put the right-holders at an even disadvantage than before.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we started off with the right aim of reforming the copyright directive and updating it, since it is now almost twenty years old and we have instead ended up approving a text that jeopardises the freedom of the Internet and fundamental rights. Not a great achievement, therefore, for those who, especially like me, care about the freedom of the network and freedom of expression, cornerstones of any system that wants to call itself democratic.  The agreement reached in the trialogue is not satisfactory because, while there are articles that we can support that introduce just changes in the light of technological advances and the advent of digital technology, on the other hand the presence of the two articles ex eleven and thirteen that affect the whole of the directive weighs, because they risk endangering the network and encumbent freedom of expression on the Internet. This is unacceptable and we have therefore been able to vote against it. The network must remain free and the 5 Star Movement will always fight for it.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I voted against the directive because it does not represent a fair compromise between the interests of authors and the interests of network users. Other solutions would have made this possible. However, the fact that the rightholders and the majority of this House, in particular, have underestimated the risk that lies in the upload filters and have ignored the relevant criticism is, in my view, a serious mistake. The authors will find that this directive brings them less than they hope. The monopolisation of economic power is encouraged rather than hindered, and we have alienated many young people who want to commit themselves to our common European work.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, today was a good day when the European Parliament upheld the rights of creators, performers, artists, journalists and others in the creative sector to fair renumeration for their work. We did this by making their works copyrighted when their work is being used for profit by digital platforms.  This is a victory for the individual where the tech platforms will no longer be able to amass vast fortunes on the backs of artists and others whose works, whose performance and whose creativity has been consistently exploited. Today, this Parliament refused to be swayed by the well—resourced campaigns of those who want to maintain their dominant position.  Finally, one of the principals on which we must continue to build the European Union is the principle of decent pay for workers and their labour. I believe we have upheld that principle today in this Parliament for the creative sector.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Mr President, protecting authors and opposing GAFAM is not opposing small platforms, against the very advice of the United Nations, it is not being deaf to the lives of academics and millions of citizens across Europe who are worried about internet freedom. For, despite advances to protect creators, freedom of expression and the free sharing of knowledge are threatened by the massive filtering of content that this directive prepares, a text which I consider to be liberticidal and which induces major cultural censorship. This directive is outdated, its workings are worn down by a conception of the internet of the last century. Let's make no mistake about fighting, let's make a mistake, let's invent a new internet that really protects creation and really taxes the GAFAM to the heart.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, the easiest thing to do today would have been either to abstain or pretend you weren’t here at all and not to vote, as some have done. That’s not my style; I always vote and I voted in favour of this important, if controversial, proposal. While I understand the concerns that have been raised, we must ensure that legislation evolves with technological developments if we want to ensure a well-functioning digital single market. I support the protection of rights holders from copyright infringement. Content creators, journalists and cultural actors must be fairly remunerated for the work they produce and a better balance needs to be struck between their rights and those of digital economic actors.  The proposed directive narrows the value gap, so that those who generate value also receive a fair share of it, instead of it going into the pockets of big tech companies only. The digital single market is not only an economic forum but a cultural one also, and I support measures aimed at protecting and supporting cultural output. No actor’s or journalist’s work should be exploited without fair remuneration. This is a directive that can be improved on when it comes to implementation at Member State level.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President. After three years of working and seeking optimal settings for copyright protection in the digital era, we must conclude that the authors of this directive have failed. I therefore voted against. And I am disappointed that MEPs, colleagues, have not sloppy the voice of the citizens and we have adopted this directive. AI technology and development are a huge challenge to democracy. They are a powerful tool of control in authoritarian regimes. Many of these advances will provide autocrats with new ways of spreading propaganda. I am terrified by the progress of AI, which will reach the stage where the original intelligence post and what will be generated technologically will not be recognizable from each other. Authors and publishers ignore this fact in the name of profit, because they are only interested in rewarding their authorship and work. I myself am the author of dozens of translations of books from English to Slovak. But, this is what authors are entitled to, but not at the cost of losing freedom on the Internet. And we, who are from the states behind the Iron Curtain, have our own experience of living in freedom, and therefore we are more aware of the risks that freedom is not a matter of course. So I appreciate the commitment of the people who called us, wrote to us, but demanded that we be against it. Even if it didn't work out.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, many NGOs and IT experts have made strong criticisms against the new Copyright Directive. I am concerned about the reliability of the automatic content filters required by the directive in practice, as algorithms mis-recognise parody, for example. This would lead to automatic censorship and restrict citizens' freedom of expression on the Internet. The opportunities for growth and competition with large international companies for small and medium-sized enterprises will also become more difficult. The directive also changes the logic of linking to news, which can lead to an increase in the number of fake news and reduce the visibility of small publications. I fully understand the efforts of the advocates of the directive to ensure that copyright is realised on the Internet, so that creative operators and news publications are fairly compensated for their work. However, the risks associated with the reform are too great, which is why I voted against the motion and its problematic articles.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by That's what we've been doing! I have said not to enter the Union. But if someone can bat, put himself above himself and say that he can wrap us up, then count on him not to use it and that he will hold back, it is really reckless. And we didn't have enough of the bat in Warsaw, we turned the second whip over each other in Brussels, and now we're going to whip two whips, once from one, once from the other. Once Warsaw, once Brussels, your freedom is seduing.  Why do they do it? We have a crisis? We have a shortage of creators? Are creators starving? Do we have bad access to culture? No, it's as good as ever, we have an explosion of creativity, media companies are rich and come for even more. In fact, it is just an excuse to start controlling the last bastion of freedom in the world. For them, for these bureaucrats, for all these weirdoes here in Parliament, the internet, which organizes itself and regulates itself, is simply remorse, proof that the world can exist without their stupid regulations.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, perhaps the easiest way to respond to today's vote would be not to be here today. But that would be too cowardly. I strongly agree that rightholders, whether they are authors, whether they are producers, software companies, have rights to their ownership, to what they create. They have rights to a reward.  And the other party, users, have rights to reasonable conditions under which they can, of course, obtain licenses. We should look for a balance between this relationship and that of third parties who provide services in the information society. And I am quite dissatisfied with how it turned out today, because by a few votes we were not allowed to vote on the amendments, and above all this concerns Article 13.  I, in Article 11, think that's where the balance was found. But Article 13 was amended after the trialogue to make it a real big potato pancake. It's called mishmaš in Czech. So we should look for ways to fix it. We did not succeed because of the procedural vote that was made here today, which is why I had to abstain from the final vote.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Well, colleagues, I warmly congratulate you! Today, we have voted in favour of censorship on the Internet and let us put in the right words what happened here. I do not understand why Mr Voss was applauded by the majority of Members who were pleased that the directive was adopted in that sense and in that way.  I was the one who supported Evelyn Regner's proposal to reopen the amendments to the directives, and I certainly voted against the supposedly first reading, but well... I congratulate you: we are taking a step forward today towards the USSR and north Korea. And don't lie— authors won't get anything because copyright will belong to large corporations.  I used to have a broadcast on Latvian television called "No Censorship.". I am kidding because I am thinking: 'There will never again be censorship in the European Union'. Is! And we in Eastern Europe, former citizens of the USSR, we feel it with the skin compared to Western Europe. And I do not know how we can rectify the current situation. Congratulations! Censorship will exist in Europe.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, for the first time, Europe recognises this odious form of racism against Afro-descendants, which is unfortunately becoming more and more widespread in Europe. This resolution is only the first step towards a more inclusive, multicultural, fair and respectful society, a society where there is no longer any room for racial hatred.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, money laundering costs us EUR 110 billion every year. That is 1% of the European Union's GDP. In addition, 70% of money laundering cases are cross-border cases, and globally, costs amount to more than EUR 1.5 million in cross-border cases.  Parliament and the Council adopted the Fifth Directive for the prevention of money laundering last year. The Union therefore has a legislative framework to combat this phenomenon and the deadline for transposition is January 2020.  Romania has not yet transposed even the Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive, and the Commission has started the infringement procedure against Romania and because it has been delayed, and because it is now transposing it without complying with the provisions of the Fourth Directive. The Romanian Government and Parliament must urgently adopt legislation that transposes European directives correctly, in a timely and complete way. Otherwise we cannot function in the European Union, except if we all transpose the European directives correctly.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, it may be legal, but it’s not right, it’s not moral and it has gone too far. The super-rich global elite, who avoid paying their fair share by setting up shell companies in exotic tax havens around the globe, must be stopped. Each pound they siphon off is a pound that belongs in our classrooms, hospitals and police stations, and it is a slap in the face for the people who pay their taxes day in, day out, after they’ve gone to work.  This is an international problem and so needs international institutions, like the EU, with the courage and capacity to push for real reform. This is why we need Britain to match these rules, whatever the Brexit outcome may be. There are enough problems in my country without us also competing in a race to the bottom on taxation.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the For five years, I have worked in the taxE, TAX2 and TAX3 special committees in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, but also in the Committee of Inquiry into the Panama Papers. I have participated in a number of hearings, from bankers to accountants, tax investigators to finance ministers. The work of whistleblowers and journalists, but also of us MEPs, has paid off. I would like to highlight the hearing with the son of journalist Daphne Galizia, who was murdered in Malta in 2017.  More than 1200 amendments have been incorporated into the TAX3 report. Money laundering must be made more difficult, tax havens must be dried up, and the fight against financial crime must be stepped up. We insist on country-by-country reporting. The coming European Parliament must continue this work, and the Member States must finally cooperate better. Unanimity on tax issues must be brought to an end. In the EU, it must also be fair on tax issues.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by If I had known my colleague Mann's speech before, I would no longer be speaking, because today I could have signed it. That's what I wanted to pay attention to. I would just add that, although the work lasted for a short time, because a year, the work on the solutions itself has taken place since the beginning of this term of office, and the number of amendments shows not only the interest, but also the desire to spoil this report, that is, to bring about a situation in which this resolution and our work will not bear fruit. I am very pleased that they have been rejected and that so many compromises have been reached that make the report acceptable and represents some progress. Once again, however, I would like to draw attention to a certain slowness in the preparation of such regulations and to the fact that the pace of work determines our effectiveness.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am very pleased that Parliament has adopted the report of the Committee on combating tax fraud and money laundering. I am also pleased that we have received broad cross-party support for this resolution. As coordinator in the TAX3 committee of the European People's Party, I have worked very closely with the rapporteurs to reach a compromise that can accept the widest possible political spectrum and which will point to very clear recommendations to the European Commission and the Member States. I would like to say that this is the culmination of a process that has been going on in the European Parliament since the very beginning of this term of office, and which has resulted from the fact that the fight against tax fraud and money laundering was one of our main objectives. As a result, a report has been produced that european citizens are certainly waiting for.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Financial and tax crimes reduce the budget of both the European Union and the Member States by huge amounts. Vat fraud alone causes losses of eur 50 billion, which amounts to EUR 100 per Citizen of the Union. It is high time to take action to curb this practice, especially as Member States' services are reluctant to cooperate with each other and exchange little information. This is a fundamental problem in the fight against financial and tax crimes. Moreover, some governments, because of the tax model in their countries, are in principle opposed to prosecuting fraud in this area. Tax fraud not only affects Member States' budgets, but also weakens competition in the single market. Small and medium-sized enterprises cannot afford to hire advisers to answer how to optimise taxes. In principle, it is difficult to identify the reasons why we should continue to maintain the existing situation and existing legal solutions. They do not serve the budgetary policies of the Union and the Member States, nor do they strengthen the European economy. For all these reasons, I think it is a good idea to create a Pan-European legal framework for cross-border investigations into tax and financial crimes, which is why I voted with full responsibility today to support the report prepared by the TAX3 committee.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, tax evasion and avoidance is a matter that undermines our economies, attracts resources that can be devoted to the well-being of the majority and impairs public confidence in institutions. The view that tax obligations are not equal for all has contributed to increased exasperation and outrage in our societies. It cannot be hidden that fiscal pressure and demands are always for the popular sectors and the middle classes. The defiscicalization of income has also meant a visible deterioration of public services for majority in our countries. Under the false excuse that fewer taxes favour investment and employment, fiscal avoidance mechanisms have been encouraged that have impoverished States and made social policies difficult. I voted in favour of this report because the TAX3 Commission has worked well and revealed the extent to which large companies are using increasingly aggressive tax engineering mechanisms to circumvent their responsibilities. At this point, the existence of tax havens is the great hole that allows to evade taxes and evade the obligations of those who have the most and large companies. We have also seen that the diversity of tax models in Europe creates competition between countries that is exploited by large companies for the sole purpose of contributing less and less. In this competitive logic nothing is gained and we all lose. Sooner or later someone can put lower rates and offer better tax advantages. Competition for fewer rights is detrimental to the vast majority. That is why it is now clear that countries are committed to implementing the proposals that this report makes. If we really want to regain the trust of societies and reduce unrest and social anger, we must guarantee the minimums that make our societies trust their institutions. And the tax issue is especially sensitive and important in this matter.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the joint debate on – the report by Inés Ayala Sender, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I greet the President of the Court of Auditors, Mr Lehne, I am also grateful that the representative of the Presidency of the Council is here, and I certainly greet Mr Oettinger. Firstly, we are faced with the last procedure for approving the management of this legislature, for the 2017 financial year, which is an important year for the budget of the European Union. But it is also important this moment, 2019, because we are facing a balance sheet where precisely the new elections of 26 May — of the week of the end of May — are going to be key to the future of the European Union. It is therefore essential to take a brief account of all these years — fifteen in my case, since it has been three legislatures — where we have learned all the institutions together. This European Parliament has exercised firmly, but at the same time opening itself up to all the other institutions to learn together and to find the best systems, paths and possibilities to make the Union budget implemented where it had been decided on values, priorities, and with all its guarantees of regularity and legality. I believe that, in that regard, Mr Lehne, I have to thank you - because you represent the Court of Auditors here - for the invaluable aid and the joint progression of both of them, which has been of enormous importance. I believe that the fact that we are facing the second year in which the declaration of reliability is not negative opens up precisely possibilities for a journey where European citizens are clearly told that all this work has been worthwhile, since in this whole period the levels of error have been greatly reduced. But it is true, and so does the Court of Auditors, and we have discussed it in depth with the Commission, that there are new challenges that appear. For example, the issue of financial instruments, which are very diverse right now; new trust funds, which also appear on the horizon as a possibility; or even the problems of public competitions or the various problems of the future, of new challenges such as defence, climate change or other fundamental aspects for the European Union, which certainly require all our wisdom and firmness for the future. I have to say that we have tried to make this 2017 report as readable as possible so that both those who come to the election and, above all, citizens, could read what the progress has been and where the fundamental challenges and problems are. We have worked on direct management, which presents some questions that the Commission will have to face. We have spoken and worked in shared management, where much has been improved — we must tell the Council that it has gradually been able to overcome some of the major problems — and also in indirect management, where, through these funds, these agencies and these new formulas, we need to go further in terms of inventing ourselves and in terms of controlling the European Union's budget. I would like to say that, since the vote in committee — which I thank very much for all my colleagues, the Secretariat and the Secretariats of the Groups, which have been of great help – two new things have happened. Once, OLAF's action — or misconduct this time — in relation to the IMG organisation and, on the other hand, a very important aspect of the conflict of interest relating to the Secretary-General of the Commission, which we will have the opportunity to see in the debate. I will answer you at the end of this debate.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking my fellow shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation and the Commission, the Court of Auditors and the EIB for their data, which have been very useful in drawing up this report. The European Union's action to promote development in third countries is crucial and important. Consequently, even given the figures at stake, it becomes extremely important to monitor their operation and results. I would like to start by addressing one of the most important issues, namely the fact that the Court of Auditors, in its annual report, pointed out that the estimated error rate for payments made in 2017 is 4.5%. This is a very worrying fact, which we have stressed in the report. The operations with the most errors were found were those relating to preventive programmes, grants, contribution agreements with international organisations and delegation agreements with member states' comparison agencies. The Commission should therefore improve contract management, selection procedures and the procurement management system. In this context, DG DEVCO should improve the monitoring and evaluation of key performance and performance indicators by gathering clear and comprehensive information. I would also like to point out that in 2017, under the European Development Funds, some EUR 860 million was disbursed through budget support operations. There must be quantifiable progress in the development of the countries benefiting from this instrument, and this method of aid must be clearly linked to concrete actions to combat corruption and fraud. The risk in these transactions is high: particular attention must also be paid to the presence of cases of tax evasion and avoidance and illegal financial flows, as we also pointed out in the TAXE report that was voted on today. I would now like to mention the Union's trust funds, to which the European Development Fund has so far contributed around EUR 3 billion out of the 4 in total. Although trust funds are flexible and useful instruments for dealing with critical situations, they need strict control, given their flexibility, both in the definition of the objectives to be achieved and in their implementation. I also believe that it is of the utmost importance to increase the traceability of relations with NGOs and international organisations. Cooperation is important, but I would remind you that the disbursement of funds must be subject to strict and timely control mechanisms. I would remind you, in this context, that the Court of Auditors recently published a special report aimed at analysing the traceability of Union funding, the implementation of which is left to NGOs. The special report points out that the Commission has not been sufficiently effective and that weaknesses have been identified both in the exercise of management procedures and in the collection of information on subcontracts. Once again, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs, the Court of Auditors, the Commission and the EIB.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The European Parliament spent EUR 1.9 billion in 2017, and the error rate was fortunately 0.5, the lowest possible level for other items of expenditure. But at least we are talking about an administrative budget, so the error rate of 0.5 is still too high, because 0 would of course be great. I have taken the trouble over the last few months and have looked at all areas of the European Parliament in person as far as possible. Colleagues were very accommodating, openly and honestly put their concerns and their things on the table, I could ask everything I wanted to know, and I felt that I had also received honest answers. Of course, not everything that shines is gold. It is, of course, the case that in the areas where most of my colleagues' complaints come from – that is, as always in such matters, the food and here also the driving service and the buildings, which I have looked at in more detail – there is certainly still a great deal of work to be done. However, when I speak now of the Chaffeur Service, the mere fact that we have integrated the drivers into Parliament is certainly a great step forward. As I said, I have looked at the areas. One of my hobby horses is the liaison offices. I think I'm standing relatively alone in the hallway, because somehow everyone likes it – except me. However, I believe that the fixed costs for buildings, salaries and travel costs are not in good proportion to what the liaison offices bring. I would like to see a much greater increase in the way people are approached in the liaison offices, the liaison offices and their staff. And I also expect much more communication via social media, because we are simply in the age of social media, and it is not enough to simply respond to campaigns, but to provide information in such a way that fake news does not find any breeding ground at all. Before I go into the major problem areas briefly, I would like to express my thanks to all my fellow Members. We can see from new compromise proposals that cooperation has been very good and very constructive, even if, of course, there was not always agreement. The big three problem areas, as almost every year, are the pension fund. We really need to come up with something here. It was created when MPs did not yet have national pension rights. Times have changed. We must now find solutions. The solution must certainly respect the rights of members who have paid in and must also protect the European taxpayer.  Headquarters in Strasbourg - single seat - the next of the big problems. There is no realise, especially among our French colleagues, that we are talking about the single seat. As always, this has been a huge problem. However, I would just like to point out the costs here: I do not like to talk about EUR 21 million a year, which costs the whole thing, and about THE CO2 savings, if you no longer have to go back and forth. The third is the general flat-rate cost. Flat rate is flat rate is flat rate. I believe that, even if we take the opposite view here, that is acceptable. And it cannot be the case that, just in order to make political money out of it, there should be an eternal debate here. All in all a good job, a very interesting work. I hope that we will relieve Parliament later.

name: Arndt KOHN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Lehne, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has said. The financial management of the other institutions and bodies was largely satisfactory in 2017. Only a few irregularities were found. In addition, however, we have also looked at certain aspects of administration and human resources management. As rapporteur, it was important to me to highlight working conditions in view of an increase in the number of jobs, to highlight the necessary steps towards equality for women and a determined approach to harassment in the workplace.  I welcome the fact that many of Parliament's recommendations from the last discharge have been included and that there have been positive developments in the management and human resources sectors. The European External Action Service, for example, has made progress in the administrative procedures in delegations, in particular in tendering procedures through targeted training, pooled expertise and the development of IT systems. In particular, I welcome cooperation with other national delegations abroad.  The Committee of the Regions and the Economic and Social Committee have exemplary administrative cooperation. Sharing buildings and translation services, for example, has led to significant savings. However, we have noticed a significant investment backlog, especially in IT systems. I encourage greater cooperation between the two institutions, but I reject the call for further cuts in their budgets in this context.  The European Ombudsman is doing an excellent job as a point of contact for citizens. Despite the increasing workload, it is still able to increase its effectiveness. However, I have the impression that the potential for potential savings has been reached and it is foreseeable that more resources will be needed in the medium term.  Following the recommendation of the Court of Auditors and Parliament, the European Court of Justice has made a significant effort to speed up the handling of its cases. The establishment of a new case management system is very welcome. However, with the recent reform of the Court, the doubling of the number of judges and the ever-increasing number of cases, the issue must continue to concern us in the future.  The European Court of Auditors is an indispensable partner for the discharge as a whole and provides valuable support through its reports and its participation in our events. I find communication with citizens via social media and the press remarkable.  The European Data Protection Supervisor is an ever-growing body which is gaining in importance, not least because of the rapid development of data protection legislation.  In addition to these positive developments, however, we have also had a number of problems this year: the Council continues to fail to recognise Parliament's discharge authority and has once again refused to testify before our committee. We are still working on a new agreement with the Council. However, an agreement has yet to be reached. That is why I recommend postponing discharge for this year in the hope of progress in the future.  In the Committee of the Regions, we have been dealing for years with a dispute between the committee and a former employee who was involved in uncovering irregularities in the CoR's expenditure. With my colleague from the ALDE Group, Mr Klinz, we have worked to ensure that there will be a conciliation procedure, which will also be supported by a large majority of the committee. We hope that this procedure will then also lead to a good result.  In the Economic and Social Committee, individual cases of stress and indications of their lack of preparation were brought to our attention. Investigations and judgments on the individual case must be made by competent authorities such as the Ombudsman, but we are calling for a review and improvement of procedures and rules. The Socialist Group stands for a zero-tolerance policy when it comes to harassment.  There has been a serious incident in the European Court of Auditors in which irregularities in travel expenses and the use of company cars have been detected. Here, too, rules need to be improved and the presence of members more clearly recorded. The Committee on Budgetary Control will monitor these developments and will monitor them positively.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Court of Auditors, the Commission, the agencies network and Parliament’s staff, including the secretariat and our offices, for their valuable work during the 2017 discharge procedure. The decentralised agencies are highly visible in Member States and they have a direct impact on the daily lives of the Union’s citizens. We therefore welcome the overall positive results of the European Court of Auditors’ audit on Union agencies for this financial year.  The Court issued an unqualified audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts and on the legality and regularity of the revenue and the payments underlying the accounts for all the agencies in 2017, except for the payments of the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). We regret that the Court issued an adverse opinion for EASO’s payments. The matters which led the Court to issue this adverse opinion were mainly related to non-compliance of payments on public procurement and recruitment procedures. However, we acknowledged EASO’s new management’s commitment to ambitious reforms. We called on the new management to continue its determined and transparent efforts to develop a more accountable, trustworthy and efficient governance structure and related procedures. Therefore, we proposed to grant discharge to all agencies, except for the European Asylum Support Office, for which we propose to postpone the discharge.  I would like to point out the following eight horizontal remarks. One, we strongly call on the agencies to further implement performance-based budgeting to develop and make use of more suitable indicators to evaluate actual impacts and outcomes, and to consistently seek the most effective ways to provide added value. Two, we call on the Commission, the network and the individual agencies to work together and provide constructive feedback throughout the negotiations for the post—2020 MFF, and to explore new sources of financing for the agencies.  Three, we invite the Court and the Commission to propose and define a consistent formula for the calculation of cancelled carryovers and clear guidelines on agencies’ budget reporting.
