Four, we also call on the Commission in the coming years automatically to provide the discharge authority with the official budget and staff figures regarding only the 32 decentralised agencies.  Five, we are concerned about the number of factors hindering the operational performance of certain agencies and about the shortcomings in the management of procurements. Six, furthermore, we regret that the new audit approach involving private sector auditors has resulted in a significant increase in the administrative burden on the agencies. Seven, the agencies should continue their valuable work regarding prevention and management of conflicts of interest, whistleblower protection, harassment policy and transparency in order to avoid shortcomings in these areas. Finally, we repeat our request of deciding on granting the discharge in the year immediately following the year for which the discharge is granted.  I look forward to the discussion, especially now that we have been given this daylight slot for budgetary control affairs. I once complained that we were only ever allotted a slot at the midnight sitting.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, President of the Court of Auditors, let me begin by thanking my colleagues, the Court of Auditors, the Representatives of the Commission and, of course, the representatives of joint ventures. I am very glad that together we managed to evaluate the financial year 2017, not only from a purely financial point of view, but also from the point of view of real results and impacts. I appreciate this cooperation, which began for me last year when I was shadow rapporteur for joint venture reports. I consider the evaluation of the economic performance and results of joint ventures to be very important, as in many cases they are already affecting our lives. Whether it is the simple expenditure side of the UNION budget or the interconnection and activation of private capital and the resulting employment or the development of science and research. The total budget of joint ventures for 2017 was EUR 2.1 billion, which is about 2% of the total EU budget for the year. Joint ventures employed almost 700 employees in 2017. Joint ventures aim to carry out research and innovation activities, increase the competitiveness of European industry and face major societal challenges. Joint ventures thus play a key role in connecting important strategic partners in the fields of industry and science, contributing to closer cooperation between actors in individual sectors and to the creation of long-standing networks of cooperation. It is the public-private links within these enterprises that are an effective way to develop European research and to finance it effectively. EU joint ventures show that if we effectively pool not only European money, but also private capital and citizens' knowledge and skills, the European Union can be a powerful global player in research and innovation. I also see as important the participation of small and medium-sized companies participating in the activities of joint ventures. I am glad that joint ventures are trying to support them and I hope that in the future they will participate in their activities on an even greater scale. I am very positive about the fact that Horizon 2020 also contains key performance indicators.  In this respect, joint ventures need to be congratulated, as most of them have met or even surpassed these key performance indicators set for the entire programming period in 2017. Furthermore, the effectiveness of joint ventures is underlined by the fact that the management cost ratio remains below 5 %, which points to their lean and efficient organisational structure. I also welcome the fact that, in the case of joint ventures, the vast majority of calls for proposals have been published and closed in accordance with the relevant work plans, and that the 'grant period' and the 'disbursement period' have remained well below the defined objectives. In the case of the ITER Joint Undertaking and fusion energy development, it should then be noted that the Joint Undertaking has reached seven of the nine milestones planned by the ITER Board for 2017 and I appreciate that 30 of the 32 ITER milestones have been reached at the overall level of the ITER project. Only in the case of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking has the Court delivered an opinion subject to the legality and regularity of payments. However, this is the result of projects taken from the legal predecessors of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking, i.e. the Artemis and ENIAC joint ventures, and concerns the unfinished projects of the previous framework programme. Let me therefore once again thank all those involved for their cooperation and congratulate the joint ventures on the results presented. In accordance with the unanimous decision of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I would also like to ask the Plenary of the European Parliament for the approval of the accounts of 2017 of all eight joint ventures.

name: George Ciamba
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it’s a pleasure for me to participate today in this debate on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2017, in the context of the annual discharge procedure, as foreseen in Article 319 of the Treaty. The Council attaches great importance to the discharge exercise. It is important that EU funds are used according to the rules and that expenditure respects the principles of sound financial management. On 20 February, my colleague Ms Luminița Odobescu, the Permanent Representative of Romania to the European Union, had the honour of presenting to the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) the Council’s recommendation to grant discharge to the Commission. This plenary will hold a vote today and, I believe, will confirm the vote of the Committee on Budgetary Control and grant discharge to the Commission. On the one hand, the Council welcomes the fact that, for the second time in a row, the Court gives a qualified opinion on the legality and regularity of payments. Additionally, the Council welcomes the gradual reduction of the overall estimated level of error, as reported by the Court over the last years. On the other hand, the Council regrets that the overall estimated level of error for 2017 payments – at 2.4 % – is still above the benchmark of 2 %. The Council, therefore, reiterates its wish to see further improvements in the financial management systems and in the estimated level of errors across all policy areas. The year 2017 was a special one, not only because it sits in the middle of the period covered by the Multiannual Financial Framework, but also because of the changes in the Control and Assurance Framework. This was particularly important in the area of cohesion, where the Court has introduced a new approach: for the first time, it checked assurance packages submitted by Member States for the current programming period. Having that in mind, a sustained improvement has been observed in the management of the EU budget over the past few years. The overall error rate for payments decreased in 2017 for the fourth year in a row. The Member States and the Commission have been able to improve their management and their control systems. This good work has to be kept up. There is, of course, room for improvement, especially in reimbursement—based payments, which still account for the highest proportion of errors. The rules are still very complicated, both for beneficiaries to follow and for authorities to check. A simpler, more transparent and more predictable regulatory framework is essential to ensure the effective and correct management of EU funds. In the same approach, the Council takes note of the Court’s recommendation concerning the simplification and streamlining of the strategic frameworks that govern the implementation of the EU budget. This is also about making sure that the budget delivers results connected to the objectives of the Union. European taxpayers must see that their money is not wasted and, furthermore, is spent on what matters to them and makes a difference. This is why the Council supports the Court’s recommendation to streamline indicators on the performance of the EU budget and to improve the alignment between high-level general objectives and specific programme and policy objectives, thereby reinforcing accountability for results and increasing clarity and transparency for all stakeholders. Increasing focus on performance measurement, however, should not prevent the Court from continuing its essential work on the annual reports and providing the estimated level of error for all spending areas both in the current and in the next Multiannual Financial Framework. This is particularly important in headings 3 (Security and Citizenship) and 4 (Global Europe), where expenditure is of increasing political significance. Going back to the way the budget and the finances of the EU are managed, the Council found some important elements of concern. There is a significant level of outstanding budgetary commitments and the budget is also exposed to contingent liabilities. The Council would like the Commission to improve the payment estimates and to follow the Court’s recommendation to provide more information about the situation of liabilities and about the use of financial instruments. This is an absolute must to ensure the transparency and predictability of EU funding. The European Parliament and the Council seem, in general, to share the same approach. We welcome the improvements that are there for all to see, and we want to see the good work of Member States’ authorities, of the Commission and of the Court, sustained and further improved. We have to send a clear signal to European citizens and taxpayers that EU funds are used in a responsible and accountable manner.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, rapporteur and honourable Member, Mr President of the European Court of Auditors, Mr President of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur and gentlemen for their excellent work. First of all, I would like to thank all those who have contributed to this constructive discharge procedure, led by Mrs Ayala Sender and her colleagues from the Committee on Budgetary Control. I find your draft report very worth reading, relevant and competent. I would also like to thank the European Court of Auditors, which is a constant constructive-critical adviser to us, whose advice is further forward for us, which we usually follow and which has also appreciated our work as fair. In the 2017 financial year, we have the last year, the discharge of which must be decided in this Parliament, in this period before the election. That is why, for the last five years, I would like to thank the Committee on Budgetary Control and Mrs Gräßle in her chairing, which has always been very, very committed here. Let me take a brief account of this period after five years. We have significantly improved our financial management in recent years – operationally the Commission, but strategically and with critical proposals from Parliament, the Council and the Court of Auditors to the same extent. We have put more emphasis on performance. We have examined how we can best meet common priorities and add value with our limited resources. Added value is also the motto for the next generation of our European budget programmes. We have done a lot to simplify the rules and make life easier for all final beneficiaries in the process of applying, implementing and accounting for projects by using simplified cost options. The adoption of the new Financial Regulation was a milestone, which was shaped by Mrs Gräßle in the deliberations. This is the basis for simplified programmes in the next Multiannual Financial Framework. We have improved the management of the budget and its economic viability. The error rate has almost halved in the five years and is now 2.4%. We will do everything we can to develop this value further, thereby safeguarding the interests of our taxpayers. We have increased the protection of our budget and created an increasingly robust framework for prevention and correction. We have improved the management and control systems. We have also done a great deal to develop the administrations of the Member States in order to make their work the basis for our work. The fact that the Court of Auditors has not delivered a negative judgment in the last two years, but a limited one, is testament to this general improvement. We have also developed our reporting. With the integrated financial reporting package, which combines documents with important information on the performance of programmes and budgetary management and the protection of the budget, we provide you with a comprehensive overview of the discharge procedure. Your demands and the Court's recommendations are taken into account in the Commission's proposals for the next budgetary framework. Ensuring that taxpayers' money is used properly and that there is added value for citizens will continue to be our focus. The current negotiations for the next MFF are a decisive step in this direction. Specifically, on the 2017 financial year, your report, ladies and gentlemen, gives a clear picture of developments, of the mostly positive developments in the European Union's financial management. We want to make it even clearer to the citizen what added value a European budget can bring to each of us on a daily basis. The budget is small, in relative terms, but it is very effective because we create added value, achieve results that a Member State, on its own, could not achieve or could only achieve more expensively. A cross-border infrastructure network for rail, road, energy, digital infrastructure, jobs for young people, energy security, the internal market and the digital single market, research in the field of large-scale research, support for SMEs – all these are key words where added value can be achieved at European level, in the European team. Your report also identifies areas where improvements can be made. I would like to comment on a few here. The first key point is the use of European funds. At the beginning of the MFF in 2014, 2015 and 2016, the funds were very slow to be used. This has improved significantly over the past year. This year we have reached the full speed, i.e. a scheduled rhythm. We want to do everything we can to make this development in 2021 and 2022 through simplification and by adopting the budgetary framework earlier, or at least to reduce it considerably. Secondly, we want taxpayers' money to be used well, and for this the budgetary performance framework is relatively high. This is regularly confirmed by the OECD. We propose further steps with our proposals for the MFF. It must be our goal to use performance data and thus also to make the added value demonstrable. Thirdly, the error rate. We want to do everything we can to ensure that the error rate tends to go down. After the programme has been implemented and after all the checks, we have a remaining error rate of less than 2%. We have achieved this in 2017, and we want to continue to make this the basis for our budget implementation work. A fourth point: conflicts of interest. I should like to pay tribute to Parliament – in particular the Committee on Budgetary Control, for which it has supported, even brought about, the tightening up of the provisions on conflicts of interest. We are now taking steps to help Member States on how the conflict of interest provisions are to be applied in the new Financial Regulation, and we will monitor and monitor appropriately the adequacy of the audit activities at Member State level. To this end, we have scheduled a major conference with the authorities of the Member States on 10 April to discuss concrete measures to be taken in the event of conflicts of interest and to exchange views on best practice. Parliament is very cordially invited to make an active contribution. As you know, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission is examining very closely and very closely the complaint that has been brought to its attention in relation to alleged conflicts of interest concerning the Czech Republic. I would like to point out here that it is important to distinguish between actions that may have taken place in the Member States before the entry into force of the new Financial Regulation on 2 August last year and subsequent acts since 2 August. However, we examine both periods, the period of the present – since 2 August – and the periods of the years before. We started conducting audits at the beginning of January with experts from different Directorates-General. These audits are ongoing. We want to determine whether payments to Agrofert companies have fully complied with the rules on conflicts of interest. It covers the period 2012 to 2018. With regard to the period after 2 August last year, we have asked the Czech Head of Government to give us written information on the specific measures he and his government are taking to rule out conflicts of interest from the outset and to take appropriate remedial action. We are currently analysing the response we have received, focusing on the measures the government intends to take to remedy situations that could be objectively perceived as a conflict of interest. In his reply, the Head of Government has informed us in writing that he is withdrawing from the ESI Fund Council and is not involved in decision-making or communication through funds. On the basis of this analysis, the Commission will draw its conclusions as soon as possible. I would remind you that, as a precautionary measure, the Commission is not currently making payments from the European Structural and Investment Funds for projects to Agrofert or related beneficiaries in the Czech Republic until the situation is fully resolved. The Czech authorities are informed and required to carefully assess the eligibility of expenditure. This is a proactive measure to protect the European budget. It is important to be consistent, but also objective, and not to prejudice either in the context of the analysis of the answer from the Czech authorities or in relation to the question of whether expenditure incurred should be corrected. As with all Commission audits, we must take into account the right of the audited bodies to an adversarial procedure for the provisional findings. If it is found that the current rules have not been complied with, we will take appropriate measures to protect the budget, including corrective measures for the past, where this is intended and possible. We will inform the House, Parliament, in a timely manner. As announced at the plenary session last December, I will appear before the Committee on Budgetary Control in April, and I am ready to do so after the election and i offer to give you further reports on all our audits and the relevant conclusions and measures taken in July, September, October. To the next question, I would like to draw attention to the discussion we held with all the institutions in September on the issue of high-level appointments last year, which is also the subject of this report. Representatives of the EU institutions were able to explain how they conduct their procedures and were able to compare how this happens – best practice. All institutions, I believe, aim to recruit, appoint and promote competent staff on the basis of competence, performance, qualifications and experience. The appointment of the Secretary-General of the Commission is a point of particular interest to you in this report. Since the appointment, Parliament has made several statements, many questions have been asked, including by the Ombudsman. As the Commission, we have cooperated fully here, endeavouring to answer all questions in detail and comprehensively and correctly and to provide access to all the files. My position and our position remains that the appointment has been made in accordance with the Statute, the case law and all the rules in force. The Secretary-General shall carry out his duties in accordance with our rules and will continue to do so. The President and all the Commissioners have full confidence in him. The Secretary-General has all the qualifications and experience necessary for this task. We have no intention of revising our decision. Nor is this possible, as was recognised here in the House in April last year. An appointment cannot be revoked. I can understand some of your questions. The principles of transparency, fairness and equal opportunities are also important to me. It is in this spirit that, in a few days' time, I will propose to my colleagues that a number of vacancies at the highest and highest management levels be advertised. I am sure that the Commission's current procedures, based on the Statute and the applicable law, provide a robust framework that is necessary for compliance with our principles in the selection and appointment of senior and senior managers. A final sentence on the IMG case, which was briefly addressed by Mrs Ayala Sender. The Commission has in the past cooperated with the IMG to implement development policy projects. As you know from the discussions in the Committee on Budgetary Control in recent years, the Commission has challenged the status of imG as an international organisation. In recent case-law, the arbitral tribunal and the ECJ did not follow the Commission's position. That is why the Commission will, of course, comply with these decisions properly. We will carry out the outstanding payments to IMG and examine the possibility of possible further future cooperation with IMG in a legal and objective manner. Ladies and gentlemen! All of you have played a successful and concrete role in the implementation of the budget you have adopted during the period that is coming to an end – in terms of performance, compliance or even in the fight against fraud. The draft report that has been presented to us today has specific demands. We, as the Commission, take this very seriously. I will report fully to the Committee on Budgetary Control on the Commission's follow-up to this in the autumn. Their work has been intense and bears fruit. Thank you very much for this and for the constructive cooperation! As this is the last opportunity to discuss discharges, I would like to thank you all for what I consider to be very fair and collegial cooperation.

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: President of the European Court of Auditors. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Oettinger, representative of the Presidency of the Council, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has done. As this is the last opportunity for the Court of Auditors to speak here in plenary before the end of the parliamentary term, I would like to thank today all the Partners of the Court present – the Committee on Budgetary Control, its chairman Ingeborg Gräßle, its rapporteurs, Commissioner Oettinger and its services, the Presidency of the Council and his working group – for the excellent cooperation during the entire parliamentary term and also during this year's discharge procedure. Your control activities may not always be as visible as your legislative activity, which is sometimes at the centre of the general interest. I am sure, however, that it is equally important for many of our citizens that EU law is applied correctly and that taxpayers' money is well spent. The discharge decisions that Parliament will adopt immediately after this debate are never a 'blank cheque' – rather, they are part of a long-term cooperation process. It is clear from the Treaties that the Commission is legally obliged to take all appropriate measures to comply with Parliament's comments in the discharge decision and also with the Council's explanations. I think you are now well acquainted with the findings in our annual report and our special reports for 2017. As in 2016, we gave a limited – and not a failed – opinion on EU spending, which, in our view, means that 'the glass is half full' and is to be understood as a confirmation of a positive development in the way the Commission and the Member States manage European finances. I would therefore just like to go into four points today. Firstly, as far as our performance audits are concerned, I would like to thank the Members of the European Parliament for having received the recommendations in our special reports in a largely positive way. This is the way to help improve the policies and programmes of the European Union. I would also like to stress that we – the members of the Court and our staff – are available to you and your committees once our reports have been published. Contact us for further explanations or additional information. We are here to support you in your work as parliamentarians. Secondly, with regard to the outstanding commitments – the so-called RALs, the reste liquid ones – we note that Parliament shares our concern: when I was with you last October, I promised you that i would have this issue examined in detail. I am therefore pleased that we have now completed our analysis in this regard, which highlights the underlying causes of the record level of EUR 267 billion in outstanding commitments in 2017. Our Court member, Mrs Turtelboom, will present this analysis to the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control at a joint meeting on 2 April. Thirdly, with regard to your request to the Commission to use a methodology for calculating error rates comparable to that of the Court, and to the requirement that both institutions reach an agreement on this matter: let me repeat that we are in complete agreement on this point. Without prejudice to our independence, we are in close contact with the various Commission services to see to what extent and by when this could happen. Mr Oettinger may wish to comment on this later, but let me now thank him and his team for their first positive contacts on this issue. We look forward to the progress that we will gradually make in the coming weeks and months. This is also in our massive interest. I would also like to take this opportunity to address a number of points raised by the Council in its recommendation. Of course, our aim is also to provide the highest possible level of information and detail, especially where it matters most, and to do so at a reasonable cost. As things stand today, we already need almost half of our resources for our annual report – that is a high percentage. And in passing, we note that the closer we get to the materiality limit, the greater the effort automatically becomes in order to be able to provide useful results in the calculation of the error rate. In recent years, we have Risk analysis improves and tends to focus our efforts on the areas that are most at risk. At the same time, we want to create the conditions for us to be able to confirm the detailed information already provided by other auditors. We are currently working to ensure that this information is of reasonable quality. One example is our approach to cohesion, which was changed in 2017. What was very new was that we reviewed and tracked audits and inspections previously carried out by the expenditure authorities, and then took these results into account in our assessment. With this new approach, we want to provide you in Parliament with more comprehensive information on how EU funds are managed and make the management responsible for its reporting more accountable. It is also our aim to provide you with better geographical and fund-specific insights for the whole of the European Union. We intend to apply this approach in all those areas of the EU budget where this can be implemented cost-effectively and where the results are reliable. Fourthly and finally, a comment on cooperation with the European Central Bank, which is also mentioned in your resolution: as far as access to ECB documents, which we need in order to carry out our audit tasks, has recently improved atmospheric conditions. The ECB now seems seriously willing to enter into an interinstitutional dialogue with us on the draft memorandum of understanding that we sent to the ECB more than a year ago. I think that this development is partly due to the support we have received from your House on this matter. We intend to start the talks quickly now and, if possible, to complete the process by the summer recess. However, I appeal to you to continue to monitor this matter and, if necessary, to legislate in the next parliamentary term if the dialogue with the ECB does not produce a satisfactory result in a reasonable time, and also to address the fundamental problem of restricting our mandate in the area of banking supervision. Ladies and gentlemen, let me come to a final point: since the campaign for the European elections will start in at least 27 Member States in just a few weeks – and perhaps the most important election of its kind to date – I would like to encourage all Members of the European Parliament to review our independent audit work, which we are offering as an objectively factual reference. to dispose of freely. We are looking ahead in our many opinions, which we summarised in February this year in the form of a summary of comments, in which we set out our thoughts on the future MFF and the related programmes. However, the Court also looks back at its annual report and a large number of special reports highlighting many criticisms, but also many success stories and good practices. As auditors, we are not primarily concerned with objecting or measuring. Rather, we want to make a constructive contribution to improving things where we consider it necessary and sensible.

name: Neena GILL
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, it’s good to see our former colleague, Mr Lehne, here. My takeaways on 2017 discharge are that the EU needs to visibly become a stronger and more effective global actor. Not only do we need to enhance our collective foreign and security capabilities as the world’s leading donor, we really do need to review our current way of funding projects with partner countries. Otherwise we’re in danger of getting the reputation of having a magic money tree, and this will impact our credibility unless the focus is increased. My questions to the Commission on AFET expenditure are as follows. Firstly, how will the Commission tackle the lack of EU visibility of pooled funded projects? Will the Commission engage in a substantive and thorough review of working with partners and host countries, pushing for a performance-based approach? Secondly, following up on the letter that I received from the High Representative, could you provide an update to this House on what measures have been taken to increase competition among service providers of EU election observation?  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Innocenzo LEONTINI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament has the exclusive right to approve the implementation of the budget and, as an institution directly elected by the citizens, exercises democratic control to ensure that the Institutions and agencies of the European Union properly manage the funds made available. With regard to the discharge for the implementation of the budget for the financial year 2017 relating to the European Maritime Safety Agency, the European Aviation Safety Agency, the European Union Railway Agency, the Joint Undertaking for Research on Air Traffic Management in the Single European Sky (SESAR) and the Shift2Rail Joint Undertaking, I have based my work mainly on the annual reports of the European Court of Auditors. , which found that the three agencies and the two joint ventures ,which were the subject of the opinions I drafted on behalf of the TRAN Committee, managed their budget in a legitimate and regular manner. I have therefore proposed granting discharge, calling on these bodies to continue along the path of proper budgetary management, transparency and the fight against corruption.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. – Mr President, Commissioner, the Committee on Regional Development notes with satisfaction the steady reduction in the estimated level of error in recent years for expenditure under the heading of economic, social and territorial cohesion. In practice, the reduction is serious, from 4.8% for 2016 to 3% for 2017. Some of the errors identified relate to specific cases and have already been addressed to mitigate the effects.  We welcome the increased budgetary flexibility following the mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework, but believe that further measures will need to be taken to increase flexibility and simplification.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the AGRI Committee. – Dear Chairman, the way of verifying the financial and substanting framework of the annual spending of the Union budget, which we do through the resolutions of the Court's report, ensures to the citizens of the Union that their hard-earned and subsequently taxes are spent in the best possible way, transparently and in accordance with the adopted Union policies.  As rapporteur for the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, I would like to highlight how better identification of the causes of cap implementation errors is important for the implementation of agricultural policy. The Court of Auditors should be able to distinguish between the cause of errors, as in complicated procedures with many stakeholders, unintentional errors are something that can be expected with greater frequency. Systemic errors require a change in the system and fraud must have no place in the implementation of the CAP or in the implementation of the Union budget.  The CAP is a policy that affects more than 11 million farmers and 22 million employees in the agriculture sector, and therefore it is important that errors are detected and corrected in time in a high percentage.

name: Alain CADEC
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. Mr President, the Committee on Fisheries has given, as it does every year, its opinion on the discharge of the union's general budget. This year, the report of the Court of Auditors on the 2017 financial year did not make any specific remarks on the activity report of DG MARE. However, the Committee on Fisheries wants the Court of Auditors to present an error rate for fishing separate from the error rates on the environment, rural development and health, not in aggregate form. This will allow for a more accurate assessment of financial management. Furthermore, the Committee on Fisheries would also like to point out that the lack of consumption of the EFAMP, the European Fund for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries, by the Member States, is of particular concern.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: rapporteur of the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. – Mr President, the European Fisheries Control Agency has been implementing its budget in an exemplary manner. The Agency is essential to carry out sustainable fisheries management, to cover more and more fishing grounds and to achieve the fulfilment of the objectives of the common fisheries policy.  The fishing field is traditionally complex, and it is more complex now. The uncertainty generated by the UK's exit, the implementation of the common fisheries policy, the landing obligation, the Technical Measures Regulation or the impacts of climate change require Europe to make this policy a priority policy.  There are many territories like mine — Galicia, the first fishing region of the European Union — for which a strong fisheries policy, with sufficient resources, which is not a currency of change of anything, is vital. That has been my commitment during this time in the European Parliament, because it is necessary and because it is fair.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by On behalf of the Committee on Culture, I would like to make two opinions on discharge. The first opinion concerns the budget itself, the second opinion concerns the Translation Centre. As regards the opinion in the budget itself, we draw attention to two very important elements, and I will immediately add a positive one, firstly, to the implementation of erasmus+: not only the tendency to increase it, but also the correct way of implementing it. This is so important that we are about to celebrate the 30th anniversary of this programme and at the same time the more than nine million students who have already benefited from this programme. The second is the approach to Creative Europe and Europe for citizens. We have a lot of satisfaction here with one exception: too little absorption in competitions – around 20-21%. We continue to recognise that this programme is undervalued and should be better implemented. As far as the Translation Centre is concerned, the opinion is positive.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which As an advisory committee, we in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs made recommendations for the discharge of LIBE-relevant agencies. In principle, we recommend that all those agencies be discharged by Parliament.  However, I would like to make a few points here: it is a pity that the agencies are unable to publish their vacancies on the EPSO website in all the official languages of the EU, partly due to a lack of money. We see a need for action on the part of the Commission here. Some agencies, notably eu-LISA, the Fundamental Rights Agency FRA, CEPOL and also EASO, are unfortunately notaffected by shortcomings in the award of contracts. At the database agency eu-LISA, we complain that 90 percent of the work is done by three external service providers. This leads to dependency and can even become a security risk.  Last but not least, I would like to point out that the sample size of budgetary control is sometimes so small that it is difficult to make a reasonable judgement on the economic viability of the agencies.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: rapporteur on the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Gender equality is mentioned in every other document in the EU context. But hand on heart: when things get sharp, the institutions too often betray women's rights. It is not enough to make beautiful declarations if we are serious about our feminist fight for equality, and we do so in the Committee on Gender Equality. The EU budget is not currently funding enough gender equality efforts and women's rights. Budgeting from a feminist perspective is still conspicuous by its absence, unfortunately, commissioner. Evaluation of various initiatives and of the impact on gender equality is simply not done. It's 2019 and this won't last. Our committee wants to see increased investment in women's rights in the EU budget, increased efforts to strengthen women's human rights and combat violence against women, and increased investment in sexual and reproductive health and rights both inside and outside the EU.  And we want guarantees that women will have an increased share of the EU budget. Because if you're serious about gender equality, then the money has to come with us.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to extend a very warm welcome to the President-in-Office of the Council and to thank him, firstly for coming and for taking a stand. And I would like to invite you to continue the discussions, so that we still manage to get the vexed issue of the Council discharge off the table, but also to shorten the discharge procedure as a whole. Welcome, we are glad that you are here!  Commissioner, thank you very much for the kind words. I would also like to thank you and your team. We know that discharge is being taken seriously, and we would also like to ask that we reach a solution during this period on the points you have announced, particularly on the issue of tendering procedures for Directors-General, which are more important to us than the question of appointing the Secretary-General, which is left to each institution. I would like to thank you for conflict of interest and I would like to say to you on the subject of IMG and, above all, on the last amendments, that we are astonished – so I was astonished, I only received the appeal verdict today and took note of it. The IMG was an organisation founded by former Commission officials and is still at least partially driven by them. So if you cannot really see from such a judgment what the court's position is about the status of this organisation and why, I find it a frightening lack of transparency. I also wonder why, after winning at first instance, the Commission was so bad this time that it lost everything. Did you want to lose it? We still need to talk about this. We will certainly come to you here.  Thank you very much to the Court of Auditors and we look forward to further cooperation.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, significant progress has been made in 2017. I am thinking in particular of the increased visibility of the European Parliament's action on the Internet, the efforts to be transparent in the management of the overhead envelope, the revision of the rules on visitors, the more frequent use of telework for civil servants, the professional security guaranteed to British officials in Parliament and the gradual strengthening of the rights of Members' trainees. However, there is still a lot of work to be done.  The first is not acceptable, allowing European political parties to receive funding from private companies. How could a member of the ENVI committee, for example, belong to a political party subsidised by the agrochemical giant Monsanto-Bayer?  To put an end to this practice, I have tabled, on behalf of the Socialist and Democratic Group, an amendment calling for a ban on such a subsidy. I hope that Amendment 30 will be supported by all the political groups in the plenary vote this evening. Second, being reluctant to re-establish a single anti-harassment committee is not the best way to build trust among the members of our institution. We have also tabled an amendment with Inès Ayala Sender, the Greens and the GUE.  Those are my observations, Mr. President.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I have this sense of déjà vu, because we meet every year in the discharge procedure and we stress all the time the lack of cooperation with the Council. I already have this feeling that this is some never ending story, that we are saying the same thing all the time, and there is basically no breakthrough here. I don't want to talk about it any more, but it's amazing. On the other hand, I would like to mention discharge to the European Commission in the context of certain problems concerning the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. As regards this fund and the DG Home Internal Security Fund, the flawed determination of the error rate urgently needs to be corrected.  I would also like to conclude by saying that the situation with the Council is a permanent situation and that should change.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: on the alde group. – Mr President, let me also have a brief reaction regarding the accounts of the European Commission's expenditure. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Inés Ayal Sender, not only for her exemplary cooperation, but above all for continuing the process of changing the perception of discharge as an effective part of the life cycle of the treatment of European Union citizens' funds, which I started in 2015. Although mistakes or omissions need to be found, rectified and mechanisms adopted to prevent them, it is also very important to stress that in the case of errors, we are talking about less than 3% of the Union's financial expenditure. We should therefore not forget that more than 97% of the expenditure that has served its purpose has been used properly and in a timely manner and for the benefit not only of individual citizens and businesses, but also of our common objectives. It is from these achievements that we must take an example for the future and present them to the citizens of the Union as a success of the European project. Even as rapporteur for the 2014 main discharge report of the European Commission, I have sought to see discharge as a meaningful part of the life cycle of dealing with the resources of european union citizens. I am therefore glad that the focus on performance and error prevention is an increasing part of the report. Finally, I would like to call on us to focus on the facts and context of the financial year in question when evaluating the budget, and not to use that year as a fictitious guide to future events, but which are not related to it and have no place or justification in today's debate.

name: Bart STAES
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Mr President, those who want to be credible in the debate on the proper handling of public money, who advocate fairness and transparency, who must be prepared to sweep their own doors. That is why we, as the Greens, are pleased that the present draft reports address a number of thorny issues. Firstly, to the highly questionable appointment of Mr Selmayr as Secretary-General of the Commission. The European Parliament spoke of a real coup and the European Ombudsman also ruled in September that this very bizarre appointment had stretched the limits of the law. All this deserves further follow-up. Therefore, a plea to approve the existing paragraphs and the additional amendments. We must also very explicitly condemn that Selmayr was present at two meetings of the European Commission, where the answers to our questions were prepared. He was both judge and party and that is unacceptable. Those who swipe on their own doorstep must also talk about the conflict of interest of the Czech Prime Minister Babiš and the Agrofert consortium, which received millions of European subsidies. Mr. Oettinger, I have three explicit questions to ask you. I hope you're listening. One, what is the state of play in the investigation and the audits of various Directorates-General on this matter in the Czech Republic? Two, when will there be a final report? Three, will there be a statement from the European Commission before the elections in May 2019?  Finally, sweeping on its own doorstep also means a serious reform of the general expenses allowance in Parliament. We must force the Bureau to implement the recommendations of the plenary, which, in accordance with the following principles: a separate bank account, unused money, must be returned to Parliament, all supporting documents must be kept, spot checks are needed and each member publishes an annual summary of the expenditure incurred. This is the only way to regain the public's trust.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, my comment on the discharge of Parliament. Once again, I have put forward a proposal on the dire situation of the staff hired by Manpower Solutions by this Parliament for the House of European History and the Parlamentarium. Whistleblowers have shared with me information about medieval conditions. No decent work clothes, intimidation, too short lunch breaks, ban on speaking to each other, mandatory standing if there are visitors. It goes on and on. And all this at a starvation wage: the absolute minimum wage that is still allowed in Belgium.  I have previously asked the Secretary-General of this Parliament for clarification. A new tender has been launched, but I have not been able to find anything about it or receive anything. Why not? And who is the new payroll company or has the contract with Manpower Solutions been renewed? And what are the conditions for the staff? They say nothing's improved. Parliament cannot afford slave labour, and that is this. This is where the Office and the Secretary-General need to intervene.  On the general expenses allowance, I agree with what Mr Staes has said about it. There is still no exhaustive list of things to use, no obligation to have the external auditor assess the legality of the expenditure at the end of the mandate, no obligation to transparency on expenditure. Once again, we have put forward proposals on this. I am counting on Parliament to adopt them and for the Bureau to resolve these issues before the end of the mandate.

name: Jonathan BULLOCK
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, just as a recap for those in the real world watching this debate, we are discussing the discharge procedure where MEPs have a look through the budgets of all the different EU agencies and institutions and give political approval whether to sign off on their financial activities. No bad thing in principle, as it is one of the few ways to hold these shadowy, behind-the-scenes agencies to account, but the procedure, I would argue, lacks some actual clout. One of the biggest talking points has been the European Asylum Office, which has a budget of EUR 86 million. The Court of Auditors gave an adverse opinion on the legality of its payments. It has had a bad recent history, with high-ranking officios being removed and replaced, due to alleged harassment, misappropriation of funds and breaches of data protection, to name but a few. If we look at the European Parliament budget for 2020, it will be increased to over EUR 2 billion. On top of that, in the Committee on Budgets (BUDG) last night, you approved over EUR 3 million for 51 contractual agents to boost media relations and digital communications activity in the Member States in order to build a so-called pan-European community ahead of the European elections. This sort of state—sponsored propaganda machine is exactly what I oppose and will continue to oppose to protect taxpayers’ money. If Theresa May survives in the short term and continues the Brexit betrayal, she says she will meet all financial obligations to the EU, despite there being no legal obligation. So, under the Tories, if the withdrawal agreement deal goes through, the British taxpayers are on the hook for GBP 39 billion. For these reasons, I’ll be voting against the accounts of these EU agencies. All these matters and policy areas handled by EU agencies should be operated by democratically elected national governments, either on their own or bilaterally.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, any person with common sense, a good family man, a good mother of a family, would look at the costs of this discharge and would see so many, many, many, many, so much waste. Waste that, of course, would not be enough for a plenary to tell. I shall confine myself to mentioning a few of them, to remind you of them, in order to hope that a little common sense will enter the head of those who administer this institution, so that this waste can be reduced. The Strasbourg office for 48 days a year – that is, for 48 days it is used while it is empty for 302 days – costs more than two hundred million, almost a billion euros in five years. Let us force the TIR to go from Strasbourg to Brussels, from Brussels to Strasbourg, with an increase in pollution of 15 000 tonnes of CO2. It is said so much that Europe wants to achieve the goal of reducing pollution by 40% in 2030; However, I fear that we will contribute to this. Then we have 9 million for the house of European history: 200 people visit it every day, so for 200 people 9 million. 500 million for the old headquarters of the EMA, because someone forgot to provide for the withdrawal clause. Until 2039 we will have to keep an empty seat because there is no withdrawal clause. 500 million waste. 16 billion more for administrative expenditure, that is what the new European budget provides for.  But that is not enough for you! You plan to spend as much as EUR 33 million on the election campaign, thinking of hiding the waste of this bandwagon. But it is clear that some people in the past were convinced that it was the peoples of Europe who were leaving; today the peoples of Europe are reacting and are ready to invite you with the move box, with the eviction box, to tell you to leave this Parliament and to plant ... (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, who is not listening at the moment, President of the European Court of Auditors, I am personally pleased that I can support the discharge of all joint ventures and that I can highlight the reports submitted as balanced. Cooperation through joint ventures in the field of research and development is essential for the European Union, especially for the development of our know-how in the field of innovation and technology. The Strategy at European Union level gives a much clearer and stronger mandate to Member States to strengthen and improve business-to-business cooperation across the European Union.  However, let me ask you, Commissioner, who is not listening, during discharge, the fundamental questions that are being put on us today, and that is a conflict of interest. We have a rather fundamental directive to deal with, and it was Bart Staes who asked you three important questions here. Let me be the only one. I would like to ask you, Commissioner, if you are listening to me, whether you will indeed address the conflicts of interest of some top politicians and whether you will answer us why some of your questions sent to prime ministers are still secret.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, President of the Court of Auditors, i would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mrs Dlabaj, for her excellent cooperation and preparation of the correct reports. This year, for the fourth time in a row, I was rapporteur for the accounts of joint ventures. And I would like to say that improvements are being made gradually, both in project management and in the internal organisational and control systems of these enterprises.  There are some risks. Joint ventures have not yet achieved or caught up with the initial delays in the implementation of Horizon 2020, but I still take the view that quality is more important than quantity and that, in the interests of the European budget, funds are, above all, properly invested. However, the accounts confirmed the high European added value of the activities of these joint ventures and I am glad that we can recommend the granting of the 2017 budget discharge for all these enterprises.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, the conflict of interest is the elephant in the chamber, but the European Court of Auditors has not made any reports on the conflict of interest since 2012, when it made it at my request and did not make it public. It's about agencies working with industries. So, for seven years, the Court of Auditors has not, I repeat, made any reports on conflicts of interest, at least on agencies working with industries. It's very important. Whenever new medicines, new products, new helicopters, planes, other models, new seeds come on the market, all of which must be endorsed by European agencies. And if industry experts work there, as they often do, obviously testing is not objective. We need objective and independent tests. More recently, a new fashion has emerged: the world makes, at these agencies, self-declarations of absence of conflict of interest. I mean, I declare myself not in conflict of interest, I -- expert, or i-member of the management board. How can I self-evaluate? The assessment must be made by a...  (The President withdrew the speaker's word)

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate both rapporteurs on the discharge of the EU’s agencies and the European Parliament for the financial year 2017.  These are institutions whose functioning has a substantial impact on the everyday lives of European citizens and on their perception of the effectiveness of law-making within the Union.  These 32 agencies had a combined budget of EUR 2.24 billion in payment appropriations. Bearing in mind the magnitude of their activities, for us it is important that ECA issued clear opinions on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the agencies’ accounts, except for one of them. Despite some weaknesses related to staffing, public procurement procedures and a lack of harmonisation of information technology, we should underline that the agencies demonstrated increased cooperation that helped to enhance their visibility. Furthermore, they were able to demonstrate improvements in efficiency as well as to generate added value. Concerning the European Parliament, we also have positive attitudes. The use of the financial resources in the fulfilment of objectives for 2017 shows encouraging results: 99 % of the budget was committed, and only 1 % had to be cancelled. This proves good management of financial resources. At the same time, the objectives pursued, and outcomes achieved, during the year stem mainly from the priorities set by Parliament’s competent bodies preparing the budget.  Some of the improvements introduced within Parliament during the year 2017 helped not only to increase the effectiveness of its functioning generally, but also to support … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Mr President, I will speak only about the Parliament itself. We all know that the Green Group has a critical view on the general expenditure allowance. We will not repeat it. We recall the days of the budget of 2017 which internalised the car service. We may not remember how heated a debate we had, how critical many Members were and how public about it. But let’s be honest, the new system works. The cars are environmentally-friendly, the drivers are professional. Of course, we have a problem of two seats. The cars drive empty from Brussels to Strasbourg. I noticed that some ALDE MEPs have a critical view on that, but as Mr Verhofstadt is Belgian, he could lead the way and teach all the ALDE Members to use that transport. To conclude, it has been a privilege to work in the Committee on Budgetary Control. Allow me to quote the Russian writer, Andrei Platonov: ‘if money has been spent in the Governate of Gradov it must have been well spent’.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, above all else in the Committee on Budgetary Control, I see it as our duty to act as the final watchdog in the budget of the Commission, both its income and more especially its expenditure. This particular report every year is the summary of that work, and I’m happy to say that – while I will as usual be voting against granting discharge for the year in question, 2017 – I will be voting in favour of this report. This report is the result of the combined work of all the groups on this committee, and especially the work of Ms Ayala Sender and her staff, who presented the initial draft and was fair to all in her approach to amendments and compromise amendments.  It’s not all brightness and light, however. The European Court of Auditors also has a major duty to the people and the Member States of the European Union – a duty to ensure that their scrutiny of the Commission’s books is thorough, honest and transparent. For 2017, it wasn’t. It was a fudge, with many holes, the most glaring of which was the omission of the error rate correction figure. I don’t have time in 90 seconds to go into detail, but suffice to say their failure needs to be exposed, and it is.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: – Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, ladies and gentlemen, I have worked on this discharge procedure in the field of the other institutions and I would like to thank Mr Kohn for his cooperation. I believe that the amendments we have tabled in committee and the few that come to the House in this area will help to improve the situation of the other institutions and bodies and the European Union's External Action Service. I believe, Mr President, that the debate on discharge does not have to be transformed into a battlefield where attacks and political issues have to be addressed, particularly on the eve of the election. I believe that the implementation of discharge has to come from a regular and legal verification of the implementation of the budget, and that this budget and this implementation are in line with principles of good budgetary management. And this applies, Mr President, to the appointment of the Secretary-General of the Commission. I would like to recall that the Secretary-General of the Commission was appointed in February 2018, that Parliament adopted a resolution in April, and that we are now discussing the discharge of 2017. Obviously, it doesn't correspond. I would like to say, Mr President, and I agree with what some colleagues have said here, that it is indeed up to Parliament to approve the accounts legally, but I believe that Parliament would have greater moral credibility and greater legitimacy if it did preach, in our policy of appointments, by example, by our own example, in our own home.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, I would like to thank all my fellow Members for their excellent work on the 2017 discharge. , migration and the protection of fundamental rights.  Thus, for example, Eurojust, which already plays a role in the fight against the most serious transnational crimes and which will become, in the near future, a key partner of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, has highlighted an improvement in performance and a positive administrative reorganisation ahead of the governance reform introduced by the new regulation. I therefore wholeheartedly support the discharge of these agencies, because the correctness and transparency of budgets is, in my view, fundamental to European policies and is due to the citizens.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to raise just one issue very clearly, that of the European Medicines Agency. After a very questionable political choice, which led to the tug-of-war with a coin, of the new headquarters in the Netherlands, in Amsterdam, today we find ourselves with a rented office in Amsterdam and a building under construction in the same city while there was a ready-made headquarters in Milan, which could be occupied and immediately used. But that is what has happened: we will see in the appeals how it will turn out. The incredible story is that of the decision of the High Court of Justice in London which ordered the Agency to pay a rent of EUR 465 million until 2039. I have tabled an amendment to this effect: these responsibilities must be ascertained. It is in no way conceivable that there should be no clear and decisive intervention on such a sensational and serious matter, which seems more of an insult to the taxpayers of Europe.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Lehne, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has said. The European Development Funds can look back on 60 years of existence this year. The 11th European Development Fund, which is now in place, is bound, as is the 9th and 10th, to the Cotonou Agreement, which expires next year.  As the future of the Cotonou Agreement has not yet been finalised, it is time to reflect on the future of the European Development Fund. I believe that the EDF should finally lose its special status as a fund alongside the EU budget, also in view of the fact that often the objectives of the EDF programmes could not be achieved, the errors in implementation were disproportionately high, as the Court of Auditors has noted, and in recent times the funds have increasingly been used as a source of new financial instruments and trust funds. , while the transparency and visibility of EU development policy has not been increased and has left much to be desired.  I welcome the Commission's proposal to transfer the EDF funds to the European budget in the future, thereby giving parliamentary control and influence ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, I would like to refer you to what I continue to call the Selmayr case and read to you Article 11 bis of the status of civil servants which states that 'in the performance of his duties, a civil servant does not deal with any matter in which he has, directly or indirectly, a personal interest'. However, as we all know here, Mr Selmayr's appointment as Secretary-General of the European Commission has been contested to say the least.  We have raised a number of questions here about this appointment and on 24 March 2018, Mr Juncker's office convened a meeting to draft the answers to these questions, with the participation of Mr Selmayr. As our assembly did not find these answers satisfactory, we asked a new set of 61 questions, following which a new meeting was held on 2 April 2018, in which Mr Selmayr once again participated. Therefore, we must act and take serious action in terms of control.  I propose, on the one hand, that Mr Juncker come to explain these practices to the Conference of Presidents, and on the other hand, to set up a commission of inquiry within our institution in order to decide and see more clearly about this matter. In the meantime, Mr President, I propose that Mr Selmayr should be at least suspended from his duties, if not revoked, because the matter is serious from the point of view of respecting the rules of the standards within our institutions.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I want to say in advance that I will support discharge and I want to thank the rapporteurs for their very good work. I would like to focus specifically on the accounts of joint ventures, because it is EUR 2.5 billion, and this is a really important public interest. Here you can see a clear improvement, although implementation should definitely progress faster and possibly the introduction of those information technologies. In any event, european added value has been confirmed, the contribution of these enterprises. And at the same time, in the last 30 seconds I have, I'd like to address a conflict of interest. Not only for important prime ministers, I do not want to thematize the debate only on the Czech environment, although there is also one point in the report. I would really like to see those agencies, because there are people working on various projects within agencies that are related to the private sphere, which I think is biased, non-transparent and I think that is unacceptable. We should ask the European Commission: How will it prevent it from doing so?

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: President of the European Court of Auditors. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which it has been First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks for the interesting debate and the many suggestions. In the light of the time, however, I shall confine myself to just two aspects.  One concerns conflicts of interest and ethical issues. I wanted to inform Mrs Macovei that the intention – and we are currently in the middle of work, and the chamber responsible is dealing with this issue – is to finalise and present a report on the situation of ethical rules in the institutions and bodies before the summer recess. We ourselves are also subject to a peer review, which will be completed well before the summer break in the foreseeable future.  The second aspect I would like to mention is the desire, which has been expressed time and again, for even more error rates on even more sectors of the budget. Let me make this very clear: this will not be possible. That makes no sense either. What is the error rate? The error rate is a statistical-mathematical method that by calculating a certain probability for a certain error rate by testing a thousand transactions across the entire European budget – about a thousand transactions – and making a probability calculation based on the error results we see, where we said last year, in 2017, the probable error rate, the estimated error rate is 2.4 percent with a 95% probability and a tolerance rate of plus one percent and minus one percent. In plain language, this means that it is somewhere between 1.4 and 3.4 percent. And if we now break this down to smaller areas and, of course, work with a much smaller amount of data on smaller areas, then the accuracy of this error rate will be lower and lower. In other words, if, for example, we find an error rate of 0.9 or 0.5 in the administrative area, that is a pure estimate, and the probable error rate may be higher than that, but it may also be lower.  And in this statistical area, it simply no longer makes sense to want to make more precise statements, because the effort that has to be put into it is no longer disproportionate to what is at stake. With about 40 to 50 percent of our resources today, we are doing what we can do. Much more will not be possible. And I think That I simply have to give this in response to the repeated wishes that we should do even more precisely and in even more areas. It is not possible, it does not make sense mathematically and statistically either, because we simply cannot achieve the necessary accuracy.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to comment briefly on three politically important issues or speeches.  On the one hand, we have had a comprehensive view of the documents, figures, data and processes, together with teams of experts from various Directorates-General – DG REGIO, DG AGRI and DG Employment – and other experts on site in Prague since the beginning of January. Now we are in the comprehensive evaluation with our experts. I have asked my colleagues and also the Directors-General to do so as intensively as necessary and as soon as possible. I cannot give a time limit, thoroughness takes precedence over speed. But you can be sure we are on the road intensively. In a few weeks' time, as agreed with your committee secretariat, i intend to give the Committee on Budgetary Control a comprehensive interim report on the audits, initial evaluation results and possible consequences here in Strasbourg on Monday, 15 April. I am then prepared to answer all the questions in a comprehensive way, even without the time pressure that exists today.  Secondly, tendering a post as Director-General or senior manager versus transfer. Once again, we are convinced that both ways of using instruments to decide on a post are equivalent in our legal frameworks. However, I would like to add: what are the reasons for a transfer? There are two reasons that may be quite interesting. Firstly, transfers take place in greater numbers at the beginning of a term of office, but only at the beginning. A new Commission has new Directorates-General, re-divides Directors-General and therefore comes to the conclusion that the stock of competent senior managers should be restructured if necessary. This only makes sense through transfer.  And secondly, we are not practicing mobility as a rigid rule, but as an important part of our human resources management – after five or six years of moving from one office to another. Again, this can only be done through transfer. I would remind you that there have been many complaints from this House when directors-general or comparable positions were occupied six, seven, eight, nine years with the same woman, with the same man. We were asked, why don't you regroup? That would only be a transfer. We are complying with this, but it is clear – and I will also set this out and prove this in the next few days – that the call for tenders, and therefore competition, is certainly the obvious procedure.  Thirdly again, the question of whether and why the Secretary-General was present in this circle of staff in answering the many questions from this House where these questions were to be answered. I quote literally my statement in March in the Committee on Budgetary Control – and I quote them, since many questions needed input from a subject to answer and we wanted to answer as comprehensively as possible. , he took part in parts of the deliberations in the processing. He did this not to influence the wording, but to complete the content. One of your house's questions was: when did Mr Selmayr know? If a question had been from you, in expiration 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, January, February? When did he know? Then it was clear that this question and other questions could only be answered with him or even only by him. If we had replied, we are sorry, we do not know, we have a Secretary-General who is sitting in the same building, one floor higher than us, but we cannot give an answer – I would have liked to hear your reply. That's why we brought it in. He was present so far and since he – and only he – was able to give a concrete answer to many questions for your House.

name: George Ciamba
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank honourable Members so much for this useful exchange of views. I am glad to hear that the Council and Parliament share many concerns, as well the common wish to see year-on-year improvements, creating the basis for an unqualified audit opinion from the court. All parties are encouraged to work together towards sound financial management and control of EU funds. It’s very important that we show our determination and urge all actors to fully assume their responsibilities. Progress needs to be achieved in the coming years. But overall I think the message sent by this debate to Europe’s citizens and taxpayers is clear: we are serious and thorough in our scrutiny of EU spending and we want to make sure that the EU budget is on track in delivering its expected results.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I thank you very much for this enriching debate and I would only like, as I said at the beginning, to talk about two novel points after the vote.  I do not think I have understood the chairwoman of the Committee on Budgetary Control, who I think questioned the well-founded reasoning of the judgment on IMG. You know very well, Mrs Grule, that IMG was founded only by the ambassadors, in Geneva, at a time when the Balkan war required experts to enter after the bombings to establish bridges, power cords, etc. In other words, there were only a few ambassadors to Geneva at that foundation, precisely to support the problems of a conflict as serious as the Balkan war. However, I wonder whether the fact that IMG's problems began in 2012 also has nothing to do with giz's coming to mind — a direct beneficiary of what happened to IMG, that is, the contracts that were rejected to IMG — from Mrs Tanja Gonner, to which you know very well.  The truth is that your articles in Der Spiegel, Mrs Grule, and the amendments you agreed to in the discharge procedure say very little of our ability to help citizens in the European Union. And as for the conflict of interest, Mr. Oettinger, I am very sorry; you know that I greatly appreciate you and that I consider you a good professional, but our Staff Regulations, which is a Regulation adopted in codecision, clearly state in Article 11a: 'An official shall not, in the performance of his duties and save as hereafter provided, deal with a matter in which, directly or indirectly, he has any personal interest such as to impair his independence , and in particular family and financial interests.' — this is only the first part of a much larger article; so when the Commission, in its official approach, says that Mr Selmayr was... (The president interrupts the speaker).

name: Marco VALLI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my fellow Members for the constructive debate we have had. The Committee on Budgetary Control makes important suggestions every year on how to better manage the Eu ropean Union budget. However, there is still a great deal of general waste, starting with this Parliament, from the double seat, from the many privileges of Members and also of Commissioners, which we could manage better, such as the many administrative expenditures that are so much contested, on which we could act more firmly. Let me also make one political point: for the next multiannual financial framework, given that there is a slowdown in the economy, both global but above all European and eurozone, even in countries such as Germany, France and Italy, that is, countries that are driving domestic industrial production, it would be interesting to consider a revision of the clauses on the Stability and Growth Pact. , in order to allow investments, with added value and linked to European funds, to be entunded by the calculation of the deficit, starting with the Structural Funds and all investment funds.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to conclude very briefly: I would like the role of the Committee on Budgetary Control to be taken more seriously by all colleagues and also by the authorities, than I have so far felt, that the proposals and comments of the Committee on Budgetary Control are taken seriously and that they are being implemented. I would like colleagues not to use important issues that are taken up here in Parliament's budget, in order to make themselves important or to polemicise, but to really take serious action towards the posts and try to get the best out of all of us and also for colleagues in the various areas.

name: Arndt KOHN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I want to make it very brief. I would like to thank my shadow rapporteurs very much for their good cooperation, but also for the other institutions, the staff there for the excellent support and, of course, all those involved and the staff of the secretariats.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, very briefly, because colleagues are filling the Hemicycle and I want to be popular, as everybody wants to be. I just want to wrap up by saying that discharge is very serious business. It’s not about the Brexiteers and other anti-European forces screaming about us wasting the taxpayers’ money. It is exactly the opposite.  Tässä on kyse nimenomaan siitä, että me olemme täällä vartioimassa ja vahtimassa sitä, miten näitä meidän yhteisiä rahojamme käytetään ja niitä käytetään – voin vakuuttaa teille – kohtuullisen järkevästi.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, let me thank once again all the shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation and for today's debate.
