Finally, I would like to reiterate that joint ventures play a key role in the interconnection of the public and private sectors, in the interconnection of important strategic partners in the fields of industry and science. Our challenges for the future must be precisely those that will focus on involving more SMEs. Research, development and innovation cannot just be a matter for big companies and multinationals. They are also a key part of the sustainable success and growth of SMEs in the EU.  Let us therefore exploit the potential of joint ventures. Therefore, once again, by unanimous decision of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I would like to ask the Plenary of the European Parliament for the approval of the accounts of all eight joint ventures. Thank you all for your cooperation.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The joint debate is closed.  The vote will take place at 17.00. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The mission of the European Union Organ Translation Centre is intimately linked to the fundamental principle of multilingualism, set out under Regulation 1/1958. Yet, despite the official language status of twenty-four European languages and, moreover, working languages of German, French and English, it is the latter that seems to reign undivided on the eve of the uk's departure. Calls to dedicate it definitively as a single language of business are also being heard. It is therefore fortunate that the Translation Centre is carrying out its missions diligently and efficiently, as evidenced by its accounting documents. However, we can regret the many reservations that envelop this discharge report, which relate in particular to the incompleteness of declarations of interest. Other points that cannot be ignored: the insufficient independence of the accountant and the lack of satisfactory performance indicators. More worrying are the long-term prospects, due to the Centre's heavy dependence on the European Union Intellectual Property Office. On the other hand, the numerous services carried out for the European Asylum Support Office are an eloquent testimony to the chasm of European migration policy.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report urges the Council and the Member States to press ahead with the integration of the European Development Fund (EDF) into the Union budget. This is in view of the fact that budgeting the EDF would ensure a more coherent framework, better supervision and better coordination, as well as synergies between programmes, regions and countries. Existing dual procedural rates would be suppressed despite considerable efforts to approximate (e.B administrative, legal or decision-making procedures) and reduce red tape. At the same time, the EDF contains important elements of flexibility. For example, the EDF has substantial reserves that can be mobilised if necessary, including the financing of humanitarian action in the event of crises, and it also has a multiannual framework for application. In addition, through the African Peace Facility, the EDF also finances operations that are outside the limits of the Treaties, including operations for military or defence purposes. The EDF is still seen as a fundamental instrument of development cooperation, as it plays a symbolic role in the privileged ACP-EU relations established since the first Lomé Convention. This positive legacy could be lost with budgeting. Budgeting could change the nature of cooperation between the EU and the ACP countries.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes.)

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, the President has received a number of requests to declare certain elements of this report inadmissible. He refused to take a position, but so, in an exceptional way, I co-signed with Markus Ferber a number of amendments to abolish them. I ask my group to follow this instruction, which is not related to a political problem, but to a jurisdictional problem, which could not be refereed between the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Committee on Budgetary Control.  The content of these paragraphs makes substantive judgments on the functioning of the Single Resolution Fund or the Stability Pact, which are not the competences of the Court of Auditors or the Committee on Budgetary Control, but of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs.  Therefore, I ask my group to follow the amendments co-signed between the EPP Group and the S -D group, contrary to the voting list that is distributed.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Mrs Berés. I would just like to say, for the sake of good order, that no amendments have been declared inadmissible in this report.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: Mr President, for a point of order, I look at the Member in 1985, Mr Tarabella, I believe, and when it came to voting by show of hands on the previous report, the Ayala Sender report, I did not understand what he was voting for because he was voting both for and against it. So, Mr. President, how could you count down?

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr! If Mr Marc Tarabella really did – I do not normally make such comments – I believe that was the vote list in this case.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, exactly, we sometimes need a little humour in our work. I have a list where there are amendments to the EPP and it is appropriate to vote against it. So, out of humour, my right side voted for it and my left side voted against on some amendments, but that did not in any way taint the President's ability to judge whether the amendments were accepted or refused.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr President, I will allow this to happen again. But we should stick to the Rules of Procedure.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: Mr President, as I understand it, since there is public, there are voters and since there is the press, for Mr Tarabella, the European Parliament, it is a part of humour, sketches and jokes. (Protests) (Various movements)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, sir, for the important contribution.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the report by Miriam Dalli, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, On the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council setting emission standards for new passenger cars and new light commercial vehicles as part of the Union's integrated approach to reducing CO2 emissions from light-duty vehicles and amending Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 (2). (COM(2017)0676 - C8-0395/2017 - 2017/0293(COD)) (A8-0287/2018).

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, allow me, first and foremost, to start by thanking all the shadow rapporteurs with whom I worked on this legislation. Thank you for your ambition. Thank you for your different points of view and your ideas, which many times allowed me to formulate and push for a strong position. The last months were tough. We negotiated hard, but we are here today because we do understand that the transition to a carbon—neutral economy can help address climate change, improve our health and environment, and can bring a new impulse to our countries’ industrial competitiveness.  The legislation aimed at reducing CO2 emissions for passenger cars and light commercial vehicles is part of this whole transition. It’s part of a bigger picture, one that requires a shift from traditional economic models to ones rooted in sustainability, where new technologies can flourish, where innovation takes centre stage and where further investments are channelled into research and development.  The final CO2 reduction targets agreed upon during the trilogue negotiations for 2025 and 2030 are a step in this direction, but they are just the beginning of a transitory path towards the economy of the future. After a number of meetings with the Council and the Commission, we managed to agree that new cars will need to emit 37.5% less CO2 and new vans will need to emit 31% less CO2 from 2030 onwards. Between 2025 and 2029 both cars and vans will be required to emit 15% less CO2. Electric cars, plug-in hybrids, hydrogen, fuel cell technology and efficient combustion engines will all play a role. I am glad that we managed to achieve this. The road was not always easy and we had to overcome some tough lobbying and initial opposition, even from some Member States. But anyway, what’s easy? At the end of the day we managed to successfully close a number of loopholes that would otherwise have weakened the legislation. We made sure that during the transition to the new test cycle manufacturers will not be allowed to inflate the Worldwide Harmonised Light Vehicle Test Procedure (WLTP) value. For the very first time, there is an obligation on the Commission to monitor and report fuel consumption meter data to ensure emission reductions are delivered on the road and not only in the laboratory. Acknowledging the importance of new infrastructure, the legislation is echoing Parliament’s position, pushing for more investment to develop recharging infrastructure all over Europe and in favour of mobilising and incentivising significant public and private investment. Understanding the concerns of trade unions, the legislation allows for the allocation of excess emission premiums to a fund that would help the reskilling and upskilling of workers. This fund is aimed to achieve a climate—neutral economy without negative social implications and, in particular, to support workers in the European car manufacturing industry, a key priority for myself and my political group, the S&D. The new law means fuel savings for consumers and will make it affordable to buy zero- and low-emission vehicles in the years to come. I have always said that I believe in policymaking that pushes change. Policies need to move the shift towards cleaner transport and we, as policymakers, need to encourage and stimulate this move, as I believe we’ll be doing in this legislation. This is our opportunity to inject new life into the EU’s manufacturing sector, create new skilled jobs and boost economic growth in Industry 4.0. Once again allow me to thank Commissioner Arias Cañete for his participation and positive help in this legislation. Thanks to all the shadow rapporteurs and thanks to everyone for their input.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am glad to be here today as we bring to a successful conclusion the legislation setting CO2 emission standards for new cars and vans for the period post-2020. The agreement reached by Parliament and the Council is an important achievement and – together with the legislation on heavy-duty vehicles – marks the completion of a comprehensive legislative framework on climate and clean energy for 2030.  This has been possible thanks to the excellent work and constructive efforts of the negotiators from both institutions. In particular, I would like to warmly thank the rapporteur Ms Dalli for her leadership on this challenging file. It required a lot of work and dedication from her side to bring together the different views and to lead successfully the negotiations. I would like also to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their crucial role in these negotiations.  This agreement is both ambitious and balanced. It is a major step forward in regulating CO2 emissions from cars and vans. Its main elements for new cars: the European Union fleet-wide average CO2 emissions will have to be 37.5% lower in 2030, compared to 2021, and 31% for new vans. Intermediate reduction targets of 15% for 2025 for both cars and vans will ensure that investments are already kick-started now. An innovative and technology-neutral incentive system will stimulate manufacturers to deploy more zero- and low-emission vehicles in the next decade, and a strong governance system will make sure that emission reductions occur in reality, not only in the laboratory. A comprehensive review in 2023 will evaluate the effectiveness of the legislation. This new legislation puts the road transport sector on a clear pathway towards clean mobility, and the broader transition to a climate-neutral economy. Let me highlight its main benefits. The targets agreed, together with the targets agreed for heavy-duty vehicles, will lead to a 24% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions from road transport in 2030 compared to 2005. This will help Member States to reach their binding targets under the Effort Sharing Regulation and for the European Union to deliver its commitments under the Paris Agreement. Citizens will benefit from cleaner air as the result of the new legislation, and consumers will also benefit economically as they are projected to save around EUR 1 100 over the lifetime of an average new car bought in 2030, and nearly EUR 4 000 for an average van. The legislation will also help to modernise the European Union economy, and the automotive sector in particular, to channel investments and strengthen innovation for clean vehicle technologies. The incentive system for zero- and low-emission vehicles will reward the front-runners in developing such vehicles. As a result of this legislation, around 35 million zero- and low-emission vehicles are projected to be driving on the road, compared to a bit more than one million today.  The new regulation is also projected to have positive impacts on the overall economy, creating around 60 000 jobs and more, around 80 000, if batteries are produced in the European Union. In this context, the Battery Alliance was launched to create a sustainable and competitive battery value chain in Europe. This is a market with huge opportunities for economic growth and job creation.  At the same time, the legislation allows for a smooth, gradual and realistic transition to zero-emission vehicles. In 2030, a very large majority of new vehicles – around 87% – will still have an internal combustion engine, as plug-in hybrid vehicles will play an important role. This will give sufficient time to undertake the necessary investments to re—skill and up—skill the workers in the conventional vehicles supply chain.  A clear signal is also provided for investors in refuelling and recharging infrastructure. In particular, by 2030, around 4.5 million public charging points will have to be operational. This represents a substantial increase, requiring significant investments, including at local, regional, national and European Union levels.  Let me conclude by inviting you to support this ambitious and balanced agreement when voted tomorrow. I would also take the opportunity to inform the Members of this House that the Commission has tabled a statement concerning the review provisions of the regulation to accompany its full support for the overall agreement. This will put Europe on track towards the necessary transition towards clean mobility, and I thank all of you for your support.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this is a bit of a rant: the president of the car manufacturers' lobby, Mr Tavares, has called us European legislators amateurs because we want to reduce CO2 emissions for cars in Europe. Amateurs, because we hear young people who walk to defend the climate, who expect us to act with responsibility to protect future generations. Transport accounts for 30% of Europe's CO2 emissions, the majority of which comes from road transport. Here we set a 37.5% reduction for cars and light vehicles, not for tomorrow, but for 2030. The one who postpones the fight against global warming is only a climate sceptic. So I say to Mr. Tavares, if he wants to be on the right side of history, that he is now investing to produce low-emission cars as quickly as possible because it is good for the climate and it is good for jobs.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Things are getting serious for the European car industry, suppliers and workers. Tomorrow, we will vote on a significant tightening of CO2 limits for passenger cars and light commercial vehicles. CO2 emissions for passenger cars are to be reduced by 15% by 2025 and by 37.5% by 2030. Some in this House still consider these objectives to be too low, while others consider them excessive. Climate protection is important, no question. However, I would also like to say to you that achieving these limits is not a breeze – on the contrary. With the outcome of the negotiations, we have once again gone well beyond the Commission's original proposal. However, we must not forget what limits were actually juggled at the beginning of the debate in the European Parliament. The Social Democrats demanded a 50% reduction, the Greens wanted a reduction of up to 75% – downright absurd, unrealistic, and tens of thousands of jobs would have been destroyed as a result. At what price? It is precisely the one-sided focus on electromobility that would have shifted emissions from the exhaust to the power plants. We now have a compromise before us. We have achieved a great deal. The interim target of 15% by 2025 is realistic, the 2023 review of how far we really are is important, and the separate target for light commercial vehicles, at 31%, is also in order. However, we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats have also been committed to improving the use of innovative technologies, such as synthetic fuels. It is very regrettable that, for ideological reasons, a majority was not possible for a technology-neutral solution. Clearly, we have squandered an opportunity here. I will continue to fight for this openness to technology. Nevertheless, we should now launch this law, this compromise. We urgently need to give producers the necessary planning certainty. The development of the vehicles, which are to be on the market by 2025, is already in full swing.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the president for his excellent work and for the work he has done I do not want to say so much about the regulation itself this evening. We have also debated this very intensively here. I believe that, with this regulation, we are indeed moving towards clean mobility, mobility that will also ensure that consumers pay less. This is good! The turnaround in transport will happen, and it is also right that we, as Europeans, help shape it and that we set the framework for it.  However, it is also precisely as Social Democrats that we also have a responsibility towards working people, and that is why it is right that this regulation – contrary to what my colleague Jens Gieseke has just said – should be open to technology. It is also true that we have ruled out the imputation of synthetic fuels in the automotive sector, because we know that, with the available areas, we must make better use of these fuels, for example in air transport, for example in the case of lorries, where we can count it.  In the future, we Europeans, too, must ensure that just transition is at the heart of our efforts. We need to put a lot more money into this in order to arrange continuing education and training for colleagues. In future, we must also consider working hours, to better distribute the work available. All this is a social task, and we must understand climate protection as a task for society as a whole. In the end, the Fridays-for-future demonstrations and the young Europeans, who are asking us to leave something to them, show this.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: Sorry, there is a blue card for you from Mr Rübig. Do you accept this blue card?

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: – No, I think my colleagues in the CDU must learn to behave in this House and not to shout in between, and that with the blue card would encourage this behaviour.  (The speaker declined to answer a question about the procedure for Paul Rübig's 'blue card')

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: I understand that today we are witnessing disagreements between the coalitions in the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany, but we do not have to watch this spectacle. I ask my colleagues for civilised behaviour.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, several dozen young people have been camping in Brussels since Sunday near the federal parliament. They demand a special Belgian climate law. First of all, I think we should leave the symbolism behind and get to work. Get started with the plans that are on the table, with the objectives that have been set. We already have a Flemish climate and energy plan awaiting implementation, and in the European Parliament we have already worked on a real climate and energy package in the last parliamentary term, on the way to 2030. Today we are once again giving the green light to a very concrete measure. New vehicles should emit 37.5% less CO2 by 2030. The NVA, my party, fully supports this. In Belgium, transport accounts for a quarter of CO2 emissions. We desperately need the innovative technology to reduce CO2 at source to meet our climate goals.  We also support the demand for a technology-neutral greening of the new fleet. This is a very important link in attracting investment, encouraging innovation and improving air quality in our villages and our cities. Our citizens have a right to clean air. If Europe is in the competition with China, we must encourage our producers to continue to innovate and to offer and market sufficient low-emission and zero-emission vehicles. We must invest fully in this, not in shoddy software to circumvent the standards.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to start with saying some nice words about Miriam Dalli because, as you probably know, we had fairly tough conversations with the Council and if Miriam hadn’t been as tough as she is, we probably would have had very different results. So, thank you once more. Some facts about the background. We did some counting. In Finland, an electrical car would produce emissions by kilometres of 48 g/km. Why? Because the mix in the grid makes the difference. In Germany, an electrical car would actually produce emissions of about 131 g/km and that was actually the reason why we had a hard fight. In the middle of the night, we waited for a call from Berlin. So, the real problem is actually what kind of mix we have in the grid and if we don’t make a really great effort to change the mix in the grid in the future, we will fail. That’s a fact. I can tell you, my 7—year—old diesel, with renewable second-generation advanced biofuel, produces less CO2 emissions per kilometre than an electrical car in Germany. So, my dear German friends, I think you have to take your efforts and your technological knowledge and do something real to change the grid. If you don’t change the grid then you are going to be a loser – and a European loser. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Peter LIESE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to ask Mr Torvalds whether he has not noticed that the price of CO2 in the ETS has risen to more than EUR 20. This will reduce CO2 emissions in the power plant sector. And I would like to ask my colleague whether he has not noticed that Germany is in the process of exiting coal – with the first measures in the next two to three years. This is a damn strenuous road, and we are hoping for support, not for it to be ignored.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague for his work I give an answer with the greatest pleasure. We have all read the report of the German Coal Commission, and we know that the 2036 exit will happen if I have read it correctly. To create something, we want to have a bit more speed. Thank you very much, and we are continuing to do so with great energy in order to change everything.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all, I too would like to thank the rapporteur Miriam Dalli for her great work in getting this deal. It was a huge fight within the Parliament, as you still sometimes hear – some old voices are still a bit unhappy, but it was also a big fight in the Council, where there were huge splits between progressive countries and countries that didn’t want to do any policy. Unfortunately, Germany itself was even split. The Environment Ministry wanted to have higher ambitions, but the Industry and Transport Ministry did not. So it was a very difficult file. It’s great that we are finally getting these policies ahead. I just want to mention to the Commission that yes, you put the proposal forward, but it doesn’t happen that often that both the Council and Parliament made it more ambitious. I hope that this is a lesson for the Commission when putting forward proposals. In the old days, the Commission tried to be in the middle; now, a bit too often on climate proposals, both sides improve it. So there is room for improvement also for the Commission for future proposals.  Just on the targets that are now on the table, these are very desperately needed in order to get innovation in the automotive sector within Europe and what you can see already is the impact of these regulations. Even the German car industry is now talking about wanting to fully electrify their transport. So you see that the automotive sector in Germany is even now going ahead and this shows that regulation matters and putting ambition in place matters and that’s what we have done.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, if I were to take into account purely the outcome of the negotiations in this document, perhaps I could say that I am satisfied, because, as my colleagues have said, it was a tough negotiation and i am sure that a lot has been done, for which, in particular, miriam dalli has done a lot. However, excessive demands on the development of new technology have been passed on to manufacturers, and this is the end of it. We are already missing this B. The new text of the Directive on the promotion of clean and energy-efficient road vehicles, which was intended to kick-start the market for clean vehicles, is simply not ambitious enough, public sector purchases will come too late and the obligations arising from it contain a lot of loopholes.  So I ask: Who will car manufacturers, whose development and production will cost billions of euros, sell when even the public sector is unwilling to buy them? And how will manufacturers meet our approved targets? Member States have simply washed their hands of the solution, leaving all the burden solely to European products. The infrastructure for clean vehicles is still lacking, and we are in a vicious circle where the market for these cars needs to be started, but no one is willing to buy them yet because of the lack of infrastructure, and no one is willing to build them until these cars are extended more.  Colleagues, i'm sorry, but we may have taken the right first step, but it's just an open Pandora's box, because in all the other steps we were supposed to take, and it was supposed to be a package, we failed. And if we're going to say with this one step that we're going to save something, I'm telling you, that decision is wrong.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in 2017, due to the consumption of oil in road transport, greenhouse gas emissions in Europe increased, as did the average CO2 emissions from new cars. Moreover, although sales of diesel cars are declining, and sales of hybrid and electric vehicles are growing rapidly, in 2019 there are fewer than 20 electric models available in European dealers and therefore their diffusion is evidently limited everywhere. All this tells us how important the regulation we are adopting is, because it will drive the decarbonisation of the automotive sector, which is now more necessary than ever, and will transform the car and van market into a sustainable one, stimulating the spread of zero- and low-emission vehicles. I am proud to have worked for the 5 Star Movement on this regulation and also to help contain the attacks of those who would like to anchor the European car to a fossil future, to the detriment of the environment and the health of our fellow citizens.  For their own good, we should instead invest in renewables and hydrogen, which have a labour intensity five times higher than oil, and support the creation of the 200 000 new permanent jobs that are estimated in the electromobility sectors between now and 2030, so that the transition is truly fair and so that no one is left behind.  I too would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Dalli, sincerely for the work she has done.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the CO2 emission reduction targets contained in this proposal are totally unrealistic: they do not take account of current socio-economic technological realities and will have a major impact on the entire automotive sector, which, I would remind you, employs more than 13 million workers throughout Europe. The text is not technologically neutral, it is a force towards an electrical solution, it does not benefit the competitiveness of the sector. , not to mention the lack of charging infrastructure and that a large part of europe's electricity still comes from coal-fired power stations and lignite. The inclusion of a clause that, hypothetically, could open a review of the targets by 2023 is not enough to rebalance this regulation. Sectors such as the automotive sector need medium- and long-term industrial plans: legislative acts like this are irrational and irresponsible.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Climate protection and job protection must go hand in hand. That is why it was very important in this legislation to see what impact this has on jobs. I am very grateful to the Commission for having carried out an additional impact assessment to assess the proposals that were on the table. The result was clear: proposals for 75%, or Miriam Dalli's original proposal for 50%, would have cost jobs in Europe. But this analysis by the Commission – and I have not met anyone who has been able to refute it, other allegations are not proven in my view – also shows that it is wrong to say that every percentage that goes beyond 30 is a disaster. On the contrary, the Commission shows that, if we are around 40% – and we are now even close to it with a safety margin – there are still positive effects on jobs in Europe as a whole. And that is why it would not have been wise not to use this room for manoeuvre, especially when many people expect more climate protection from the European Union, especially many young people. It is therefore a sensible compromise, and I hope that we will support it tomorrow by a united or by a large majority. Thank you to everyone who has contributed: the rapporteur, of course, but in the GROUP of European Democrats in particular Jens Gieseke, Commissioner Miguel Arias Caete and the President-in-Office of the Council, Elisabeth Köstinger. It is a good result!

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe is a movement. Europe is moving towards the new model of development, a low- and zero-carbon economy, a virtuous alliance between growth and the environment, production and industry, with less waste of energy and pollution. In Europe, the movement of people and 60% of goods are expected to increase by 40% in 2050. Transport currently accounts for 25% of emissions and more than 70% is road transport. Today, the transport sector accounts for 5% of Europe's GDP, a wealth that we spend to a large extent on medicines and shelters due to pollution in our cities and to repair the damage caused by climate change. We must change! This regulation sets binding and ambitious targets for the emissions and fuel economy of cars and vans. It says no more laboratory tests that do not reflect real emissions and asks for data in real driving conditions. We are now working together, all of us, to encourage the public and private investment needed for the conversion of the European car sector, which is still 94% dependent on oil. We now accompany and support workers in retraining and updating their skills. We need to change, and this regulation is a step in the right direction for a different way of life, more respectful of people and the environment.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Environmental goals are of course good to have. However, care must also be taken to ensure that environmental objectives have a realism, i.e. that there is always a realistic prerequisite for manufacturers to keep up with the development of the technology. There is no need to set higher standards and then just reach the target. Then we have failed, it is not possible to meet the requirements. I therefore believe that there must also be agreement with manufacturers as to what is technically possible to do or not. I myself ride electric cars. It works great, I'm fantastically happy. But I live in the countryside and I think that's where the electric car is an option in the future. In big cities, there is too much trouble with the charging infrastructure. There are not enough charging points and the electric car will therefore never be an option in the big city. There will be constant worries about how to load the car. I'm doing fine. At home at my villa I can put in contact, it's no worries, but in the cities I don't think it will be an option and then we have to be able to release cars that are environmentally friendly. (The speaker agreed to answer a question ("blue card") in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". – My question goes in the direction that in e-mobility a battery weighs about 700 kilograms, while a load of diesel weighs 70 kilograms. Now, of course, we have the problem that you can drive a total of 700 kilometres with diesel, whereas with e-mobility you can only drive 350 kilometres. So there is a big question of efficiency here. How do you see that?

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: answer ("blue card"). That's right. That's absolutely right and that's also why I have a regular car as well, with internal combustion engine. The electric car works for a certain part of my needs, but it doesn't work to every need I have. That is why we must also ensure that we can keep the normal cars too. The electric car doesn't work for everyone, that's the way it is. For me, it works great. I have a daily driving requirement of 70 kilometers approximately in distance, and there it works with the electric car. Especially in winter time, the range is down to about 90-100 kilometres on a full charge – that's actually the reality – so I wouldn't make it with just an electric car. That is why we must also ensure that there are alternatives with renewable fuels, that is, where we can produce environmentally friendly fuels, quite simply, as alternatives to petrol and diesel. The electric car is not the solution to all problems, but some of them.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: Mr President, I think it would be nice to agree that we will meet again in three-four years' time and that we will look back with laughter at the rearguard action we have had in these days. Because the sad thing is that social transitions are moving so terribly fast that we as legislators are simply too slow. We drive together in that little diesel, tuffling across the right lane with the Conservatives behind the wheel, while we are being overtaken the left-hand lane by the car of the future. BMW announced yesterday that it will bring a whole new range of electric cars with a 600-kilometre distance to the market. Volkswagen announced in November that it would invest €44 billion in e-mobility over the next five years. That's what's happening now. The market passes us on all fronts. I am going to vote in favour of the compromise, but I already know that in two years' time it will be obsolete and fortunately: the market is going much harder than we as legislators can.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Mr President, civil society applauded us for adopting an ambitious report last October, and for taking a strong stance and sending a clear message to car industries that they must also keep up to speed on climate ambition and demands. However, what is disappointingly clear from the final agreement between the Council and Parliament is that the Council and EU Ministers are happy to water down bold environmental legislation that aims to tackle one of the EU’s biggest polluting sources. CO2 emissions from transport are increasing and efforts to improve the fuel efficiency of new cars are slowing so we must demand a lot more from the sector. We need to stop striking political compromises where the science sets us the limits. Fulfilling the Paris Agreement obligations is not only Parliament’s duty, but it’s also the Council’s duty and they cannot ignore their part in this.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Today we are talking about schizophrenia, which is reflected in the immense new requirements for CO2 emissions from cars that this House wants. We are talking about the EU's cramping, the best planning, an industrial strategy, while trying to put an end to its best industrial drag – the automotive industry. We are talking about the EU's assumes zero emissions for electric cars, which is scientific nonsense and physically completely impossible. Mrs Dalli, when you talk about zero-emissions vehicles, it shows above all their cluelessness.  We are talking about the fact that you are hitting the big German car manufacturers in the right place, thereby weakening Germany, which, on the other hand, they expect to guarantee their savings with banks, to finance cohesion policy and agricultural subsidies and to tolerate their weakness in competition. Ladies and gentlemen, that will not go well. Let them go! Stop! And this unfortunately also applies not only to you, but also to the German Government, which I do not really consider at all, because it suffers from the same schizophrenia.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Sweden is one of the countries in the world where the national economy is most dependent on the automotive industry. We know how important it is to create the right conditions for a viable and more sustainable car industry, both today and in the future. That is precisely why we Swedish Social Democrats, both here in the European Parliament and through our government in the Council, have pushed for such high climate ambitions, for car emissions to be reduced more than today. We would have liked to have seen emissions reduce even further, but this is still an important step along the way, what we are voting on now. It is thanks to the Socialist Group and our rapporteur, Miriam Dalli, and her hard work that we now have these new rules that will benefit both the climate and human health. We Social Democrats will stand up for this tomorrow and vote in favour of the stricter emission standards, both for the sake of the climate, for the sake of human health and for an industry that is strong for the future. A sustainable Europe. That is the vision that we have for our future.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The present draft is not only based on unrealistic targets, but also once again the question of what ideology is actually being pursued here. And this ideology shows that we are going to go against private transport, because many arguments are being thrown together here, which are completely baseless.  Commissioner Arias Caete, if you talk about wanting a zero-emission vehicle, that is utopia. There are no zero-emission vehicles, and they are not foreseeable at all.  And when there is a constant talk of electric vehicles – according to the motto: these are the bringers of salvation: this is nonsense, ladies and gentlemen! The electricity that is needed there is generated in doubt – in Germany at least – in coal-fired power plants, in power plants that are powered by oil, where emissions are generated. There is scientific research which clearly shows that an electric vehicle has already produced the same environmental impact as the other with 110 000 kilometres compared to an internal combustion engine when it hits the road. In other words, these are facts, and we cannot ignore them! In addition, we are constantly concerned with private transport, with passenger cars. What about the real polluters, such as shipping? It is well known that only a few large ships cause the same environmental impact as all German passenger car traffic. You'd have to go for it! (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, this Regulation gives us a legal framework for all Member States to meet the objectives of the Paris Agreement in the coming years. With the establishment of these objectives, the European Union will give the sector clear guidance to programme its investments and technology development in the future.  The passenger car and van sector is of great importance in many countries of the European Union, mainly mine, and Member States will have to undergo profound transformation. And having this legal framework for a sustainable transition is important.  But this transition must ensure that environmental objectives are met while maintaining or increasing the level of economic activity and employment. That is why we need to be particularly vigilant with the most vulnerable groups and regions, and also take into account that the transition affects not only the automotive industry, but also the entire component manufacturing industry.  The European Commission must therefore have a real industrial policy, with the involvement of several general directions and with specific analyses and measures for the most important industrial sectors of the European Union. This is a very important issue for years to come. And I would like to end, Commissioner, by congratulating you on all the work of this parliamentary term, so you have done not only in this sector, but also because the European Union roadmap is already completed before the European elections. We even have the emission reduction strategy on the table by 2050. Thank you very much and many congratulations.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the 44 billion investments by VW were discussed here. This will also show that cars and private transport will become significantly more expensive. So buying cars is becoming a social issue here. Congestion in cities will be severely reduced because many can no longer afford a car and mobility. The second thing where I see a problem is that it is only measured by the exhaust. We all know that, of course, the issues of production, operation and recycling play a major role. Here we see that diesel has 219 grams of CO2 per 150 000 kilometers, e-mobility 277, and gasoline has the most emissions with 300 grams of CO2 per kilometer. I am in favour of introducing life-cycle costs, because this is the future par excellence, and that we focus on synthetic fuels such as hydrogen, because they can be derived from renewable energy. We reject nuclear power because it is expensive and harmful to the environment.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! If we in the European Union are to help protect the climate, if we are to achieve our Paris objectives in 2015, and if we are to create a low-carbon economy, then our transport sector must contribute to achieving this goal. That is why the legislation on which we are going to vote is an important step in the right direction. Here we are going to go in and demand our cars that they should become much more climate friendly - they have to reduce the consumption of CO2. That is why, after all, I am pleased that we are getting this legislation, and it is thanks in particular to Miriam Dalia, that we have achieved the end of legislation that, after all, takes us the right way. Having said that, I would like to say that it is also disappointing that we are not a bit more ambitious. The European Parliament's Committee on the Environment would have liked to have had a 45% reduction in CO2 - we will have one at 37. That is simply not good enough! Young people stand out here in front of parliament and insist that we must make sure we become climate-friendly. We had the opportunity with this legislation, but we did not get to the end. However, it is not parliament's fault. That is because the Council of Ministers does not want to be part of it. If we are to solve the climate problems of the future, then our transport sector must contribute - even with more than what is available here. Having said that, I will support the proposal, because it is, of course, a tremendous step forward in terms of what we have today. Moreover, we must make sure that the Commission is in the ears to ensure that we also measure whether they actually achieve these CO2 reductions on cars. We will be watching to ensure that the automotive industry delivers.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Dalli, as well as our shadow rapporteur, Mr Gieseke, on the great work done during the negotiations on this report. The agreement reached with the Council is a major step forward in achieving the decarbonisation objectives that we have set ourselves, with guarantees to ensure the right transition, while also ensuring the technological neutrality that the legislature must always maintain. The agreement we will vote on tomorrow is yet one more step in addition to the dozens we have dealt with during this climate change mandate, in which we have made great progress during these years of the Juncker Commission, also promoted by Commissioner Arias Cañete; a struggle that the European Union is leading around the world and that European citizenship demands and remembers every Friday that we cannot postpone; a struggle that we can't lose.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, the regulation we are looking at ensures a sustainable energy transition in the new passenger cars and new light commercial vehicles sector. It also stimulates innovation in new technologies that make it accessible to purchase zero-emission and/or low-emission vehicles. It introduces CO2 emissions tests under real conditions as a condition of vehicle type-approval, which can help us avoid fraudulent practices such as those identified by the Parliamentary Committee of Inquiry into Car Emissions of which I was a member.  I therefore welcome the rapporteur, Miriam Dalli, and the whole team that worked on this dossier for the highly balanced proposal for a regulatory framework to articulate the transition of the mobility model, the innovation and adaptation of European industry and the safeguarding of the interests of workers and taxpayers. We have to put into practice this proposal of sustainable innovation, we have to have the ability to monitor, we have to have the ability to empower workers and sustainably develop the territories to be one step ahead in modernity.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which I would like to invite everyone to look at the picture. Three percent of annual and global CO2 emissions are caused by humans. The EU accounts for 9.1%. Of this, just under 30 percent is accounted for by the transport sector, of which 72 percent is for road traffic and 60 percent of that is for cars affected by this bill. The possible, but not so likely, saving would be a maximum of 0.013%.  So what are we doing? We make expensive electric cars mandatory, make individual mobility more expensive and damage the value creation of our leading industry. This saving seems disproportionate to me, even if, as envisaged here, only the exhaust is measured and electric cars are considered to be CO2-neutral, even if the electricity is generated from lignite. Unfortunately, this is an ideological package – repeatedly pointed out by our party. But thanks to a left-wing majority in the House, our amendments were irresponsibly rejected. It would have been better in the interests of our citizens, in the interests of our businesses and, above all, in the interests of the environment.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, every new report we know puts before our very eyes the reality of the need to face with determination the greatest challenge facing humanity, which is the fight against climate change. The transport sector accounts for a quarter of the European Union's emissions. The decarbonisation of the transport sector is therefore an obligation, not an option.  The regulation that we are going to adopt puts us, precisely, on the path of achieving these objectives of decarbonisation, which are unppealable. And, in turn, it places us facing the European challenge of taking steps for our industry to make the big technological leap to maintain leadership, maintain employment, but keep it on clean transport, in transport that is compatible with this challenge that we have to face, which is the total decarbonisation of our productive sectors, of our economy.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Mr President, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has done. It is true that the CO2 limit values for passenger cars and light commercial vehicles are continuously adjusted and downgraded. We need energy-saving cars, because that is the only way we can achieve the EU's climate protection targets. But the limit values that we set today for 2025 and 2030 must also be feasible and provide the right incentives. In this respect, I welcomed the Commission's proposal, which takes into account, with a reduction target of 30% in 2030, that mobility must be affordable and that we must also ensure that jobs in the automotive sector and subcontractors remain with us in the EU. In this respect, I would just like to say that there are no comparable requirements in the world. We are lagging behind in the development of charging infrastructure for electric vehicles in almost all Member States. The electricity demand for electric cars is gigantic, and consumers must also accept the electric cars. First, we talk badly about diesel – but diesel is a good alternative to CO2 – then we do not incentivise renewable fuels, nor do we incentivise plug-in hybrids. We are simply setting overambitious CO2 limits on the drawing board. I think that is wrong and I will therefore vote against it. I want europe to be driven not only by Teslas in the future, but also by the cars that we produce in Europe.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, climate change is leading citizens and us politicians to be more sensitive to the environment, and that is the right thing to do. Transport, of course, contributes to this problem through emissions of carbon dioxide and other substances, that is to say, to climate change. However, I would like to warn against an irresponsible pursuit of ambitious limits.  Firstly, because the European Union is not a decisive producer of CO2, it accounts for less than 10% of global production. The second reason is that the car industry is key in the European Union and we simply cannot expose it to unrealistic objectives, unrealistic pressure on its competitiveness. This could completely destroy it, cut jobs, and not move the CO2 reductions as we imagine.  For me, the European Commission's proposal was acceptable, it was also an acceptable 15% by 2025, but it is not acceptable to increase as ambitiously by 2030 as proposed in the trilogue agreement.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, despite the progress made in recent years, around 500 000 lives are lost annually in Europe due to air pollution.  Moreover, the current climate protests in Europe's capitals send an increasingly clear message - that we must be more ambitious domestically and an example to follow globally, of course, without jeopardising the competitiveness of our industry in the European Union.  It is an important step that, following the interinstitutional negotiations with the Council, Parliament has managed to achieve an agreement to reduce emissions by 37.5% by 2030 in respect of new cars and a 31% reduction for vans. I am convinced that these ambitious allowances will encourage innovation among car manufacturers, for which we must ensure the functionality of the mechanism to stimulate these low-emission vehicles as well as those with zero emissions.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This is not the optimal solution, it is a compromise. The compromise from the optimal solution differs in that in the optimal solution everyone is satisfied, and in the compromise there are costs and there are two sides. On the one hand, environmentalists are moving to ensure that this solution is implemented faster and on a larger scale and better protects the climate. Those who are car manufacturers point out that the pace we propose generates costs, and that is a serious cost. Countries are different – and this is also evident in this House – between those that are car manufacturers and those that have only consumers. What I want to draw attention to, on the other hand, is too much of a span of technical data, precisely the effects, the costs, which are very often calculated in a separated way. I would like to draw your attention to this, because the fairly balanced solution that we are proposing must be balanced and well applied in practice itself.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this debate, which shows the importance of this legislation. Let me stress again that we now have another key element to implementing the 2030 European Union Climate and Energy Framework and meeting our commitments under the Paris Agreement. The legislation is not only to protect our environment: this legislation will help European Union industry to retain its leading competitive position in a fast-changing global market with a demand for clean products and business models that support sustainable mobility and is increasingly significant. The agreed CO2 emission standard for cars and vans will drive new jobs in Europe. Increased consumer expenditure, increased investment in infrastructure, reduction of oil imports and expansion in the battery sector are all positive drivers for job creation. This legislation will bring strong economic benefits and be good for consumers, who will not only benefit from cleaner air, but will also save money when fuelling their vehicles. To summarise, this is a very good compromise and together we can be proud of the result of our joint efforts. We all know about the scale of efforts needed to reach our long-term climate objectives and some contributions to the debate have pointed to that. This legislation is a step in the right direction. Therefore, I invite you to lend your support in tomorrow’s vote. It is important to ensure it can enter into force swiftly. There is no time to lose in our fight against climate change, and this is what our citizens, including our young generation, expect from all of us.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, my thanks to all the colleagues, and thank you Commissioner once again. But allow me to address a couple of issues that were mentioned. First and foremost, let’s stop the scaremongering which says that more investment by companies equates to more expensive cars. With all due respect, all the studies that we were shown – even the impact assessment by the Commission itself – confirmed the financial benefits for consumers, as mentioned just now by the Commissioner himself when he was speaking about a decrease in consumer expenditure. Consumer benefits are the most evident thing in this legislation.  I would have expected some of the Members speaking tonight to know the details of what we are going to vote upon tomorrow. So for example we had Mr Meuthen, who has not even realised that we are speaking about zero and low-emission vehicles defined as vehicles that would emit 50g per km. And we had Mr Kölmel from the ECR, who has not even realised that this is part of a whole package of legislation which addresses different sectors and that this Parliament doesn’t focus on mobility or passenger vehicles alone. The reality is that change is happening, investments are being channelled into new technologies and research is being carried out to ensure that the EU, for example, can produce batteries and battery cells within its boundaries.  I am really glad that Members who originally proposed less ambition today are speaking about this compromise positively, because I am convinced that it was the initial ambition of this Parliament that changed things. And things will continue to change. Just look around at the models that are currently being rolled out and also the increased kilometrage that zero and low-emission vehicles have today. Things have changed from a couple of months ago to today.  My concluding remark would be, let’s continue working to make sure that we attract investments to this continent, to the European Union, that we roll out the required infrastructure and charging stations and develop the necessary technology to produce battery cells and batteries here within the European Union. I look forward to the vote tomorrow. Thank you to all the colleagues for their contributions. Once again, thank you, Commissioner and to all the staff for their help.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: Thank you very much for this discussion and for your closing remarks.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the report by Pier Antonio Panzeri, Cristian Dan Preda, Frank Engel, Charles Goerens, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Development, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Neighbourhood and International Cooperation and Development Instrument (COM(2018)0460 - C8-0275/2018 - 2018/0243(COD)) (A8-0173/2019).

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will be voting on the new Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument. This is a very important procedure, as it will determine how EU assistance to third countries is given in the period 2021-2027. This is worth almost EUR 90 billion. The text is the result of lengthy negotiation and compromise work between all the political groups; we have achieved a position that I consider to be balanced on the merger of the various current financial instruments, so as to ensure greater direction and control by the European Parliament. That is the first point I think we need to emphasise, and that is governance.  The Commission's proposal only provides for implementing acts and comitology for the adoption of programming documents, which means that Parliament can only challenge such acts on legal grounds, that is, if the Commission has exceeded its implementing powers and not for the political decisions that motivated them. This is clearly insufficient and we are therefore inserting delegated acts, a more meaningful and regular strategic dialogue that pre-esses programming decisions. Therefore, in this way, all important strategic choices would be subject to parliament's review and the possibility of raising objections. A second element is the Neighbourhood Policy, which is one of the priority areas and a key element of the European Union's external action. Including the Neighbourhood Policy in the Single Instrument ensures greater flexibility for the easy and rapid mobilisation of additional funding and to support special relations with our neighbours. In addition, the planned allocation of EUR 22 billion represents a 24% increase in this sector compared to the current multiannual financial framework. As far as sub-Saharan Africa is concerned, let us strengthen its budget and provide for a programme for the ACP countries, so that they can address the possible needs arising from a future post-Cotonou agreement. In the objectives of the regulation, we have included a reference to poverty eradication and, as far as official development aid is concerned, we have increased the percentage of these criteria in the projects financed from 92% to 95%. With regard to migration, we stress the need for a holistic and long-term approach and address the root causes of regular, irregular migration and forced displacement, including a reference to climate refugees. We are therefore talking about the need to adopt human rights-based policies to facilitate safe, orderly and regular migration. Furthermore, we consider the importance of addressing the issue of climate change, including with regard to the agreements made, including the Paris agreement, and in the settlement targets the percentage of expenditure allocated to climate issues has increased to 45%, an ambitious target compared to that proposed by the Commission. The priority is what we are doing with regard to human rights. We have introduced a clause suspending assistance to a particular country in the event of persistent non-compliance with these principles. Finally, with regard to the part of the instrument that deals with peace and stability, we make it clear that the funds in this area must be used to create conditions for ensuring sustainable development and cannot, these funds, be used for the purchase of weapons and ammunition or for operations with military or defence implications. This is an important work that has lasted many months and for this reason I obviously thank all my three co-rapporteurs together with myself for their work and I hope that this proposal will be fully approved.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, those who have followed our discussions in Parliament closely on the Commission's proposal on this issue will not be surprised to learn that I was, among the four co-staffers, the one who was, from the beginning, the most sceptical about the idea of a single instrument. I would like to go back briefly to the reasons for this skepticism. Our Parliament had expressed a very clear position a little over a year ago, calling for dedicated instruments for pre-accession, development, neighbourhood and humanitarian aid, because of the financial and political specificities of these Union intervention areas.  The European Commission, with the exception of the pre-accession instrument, has taken this position into account and has presented the proposal being discussed today, which brings together a dozen instruments and programmes that currently exist. Furthermore, in January 2018, the European People's Party voted against the idea of a single instrument for external action in unambiguous terms, stressing that "it would only be the illusion of simplification that would lead to permanent internal quarrels over which area would be the most important". The EPP also pointed out that our European Neighbourhood Policy, which has a direct impact on the lives of European citizens, would be undermined, or even scrambled, without a specific financial instrument to support it. Despite these reluctance, my group and I have engaged in good faith and responsibly in the work to improve the Commission's proposal. This work is long-term, given the exceptional complexity of the case, which invites complicated trade-offs between different types of interests and objectives that are brought together within the same instrument.  It is, indeed, a real revolution in the way the European Union's external action will be financed. This revolution also responds to repeated demands from our Parliament, particularly in terms of more flexibility to respond to unforeseen challenges. But the Commission's proposal lacked important details in terms of the governance and role of the European Parliament, the clear and precise definition of the objectives for the various policies covered, as well as financial guarantees on the allocation of funds and their use. Through cooperation between political groups, we have been able to propose a coherent framework to ensure an increased role in the European Parliament, including through the intelligent use of delegated acts. We have set clear and ambitious objectives for the various areas of external action, while at the centre of human rights and the promotion of democracy.  Finally, with regard to budgetary measures, since this is the heart of our discussion, we have increased the total envelope of the instrument by 4.4%. We have introduced guarantees for geographical financial allocations for the neighbourhood and sub-Saharan Africa. We have also strengthened allocations for human rights, civil society and global challenges, in parallel with a reduction in the reserve from EUR 10.2 billion to EUR 7 billion. Finally, I regret the attitude of the Green Group in the vote in the Committee on Foreign Affairs. We have accepted more than 250 amendments from this group. We, the four co-carriers, have filed a total of 380. Despite the fact that we have taken up an extremely large number of amendments (unprecedented for a report voted here), the Green Group abstained. I don't understand that attitude. This is the historical record and you want to break this instrument? I'd like an answer from you. What do you want to do with this report, with this instrument?

name: Frank ENGEL
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, we all know why we are here, although I regret that there are so few of us for a package that amounts to almost EUR 100 billion over a seven-year financial planning period. I would have liked the number of participants to be more in relation to the size of the case, but perhaps the absence of so many colleagues is also due to the more reasonable pace of the last few weeks of the session. As far as the text is concerned, I think it does justice to the Commission's ambition when it presented its proposal. All of us, who have been involved in the development policy, the development cooperation of the European Union, have come across interlocutors, especially African ones, for whom the proliferation of our financing instruments was so incredible that they no longer knew where to give heads to look for financing. The coherence that this instrument would bring is probably its most positive characteristic. But even if we vote tomorrow on the package concocted by the four co-carriers, we have no certainty that we will achieve the desired effect. This is due in particular to the unfortunately unresolved issue of the inclusion of the European Development Fund in the European Union budget. France, as well as other states, continue to oppose the budgeting of the EDF. And without this budgeting, there will be no instrument of neighbourhood, development cooperation and international cooperation, there will simply not be. It would therefore be desirable for Parliament to reinforce its message, which is also that of the Commission, of the budgeting of the EDF as a democratic necessity, and for the Council, which is the main protagonist of the non-budgeting of the EDF, to adopt this position, instead of remaining walled in a 'postcolonial' attitude. It also remains to be seen whether the Commission has had a unequivocal position on this issue. For I really have the impression that throughout the last few months, at least one Commissioner and his colleagues have made sure that the notion of a sacred instrument of the neighbourhood survives actively in this Parliament, as if the neighbourhood were an end in itself and a need for its own financing instruments, or else it would disappear. We are still talking about a treaty policy that will not be changed by a simple parliamentary or legislative decision. We are talking in this instrument about a 24% increase in funds dedicated to the neighbourhood. Nevertheless, we receive amendments and suggestions from the Commissioner's office on enlargement and the neighbourhood, all of which tend to invalidate the single instrument approach. Personally, I am asking myself the question and perhaps, Commissioner, could you answer it, whether or not there was a fair approach by the college from the beginning. Otherwise, I would have serious questions about the operation of the college. Having said that, Mr President, I am pleased that we have reached a coherent and joint text, and I would like it to be voted on.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would first like to thank my fellow rapporteurs. We have done a very good job over the last six months. It was not an easy job, but we still managed to get you a document before the end of that mandate.  I would also like to thank the officials of the Committee on Development, the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Subcommittee on Human Rights for their professionalism, skills, loyalty and also the stamina they have shown throughout this period. It is the most complicated document that the Committee on Foreign Affairs has drawn up and then, in another novelty, it was the result of three committees whose work deals with external relations. It was a risky bet.  It was a risky gamble because four rapporteurs and three committees were given that. It was a risky gamble because we promised to think outside the box without sacrificing the gains of development. It was also a risky bet because converging our views on this new instrument was not a foregone conclusion. At the first presentation of the document, Ms. Mogherini said that policies would remain in their essence, but that methods would change. We have made a bet on change and I think we have done quite well so far. To go off the beaten track is to make the European Union's external action more coherent. To go off the beaten track is to budget the EDF. How many years do we stop renewing this request to budget the European Development Fund because we have made a habit of teaching the rest of the world about democracy when we ourselves have not been able to have the power or a final word in terms of the implementation of the European Development Fund. To think outside the box is also to understand that it is a question of meeting challenges of a different magnitude for the period 2020-2027, than that which is being implemented. Going off the beaten track also means realizing that states and the Commission cannot do everything.  Money is missing everywhere, so what could be more normal than to invite the private sector to drain part of its savings and part of its means towards development. This is the instrument - the EFSD - which, with its leverage, will ultimately devote more resources to official development assistance. Finally, I would like to say that Parliament's prerogatives will also come out strengthened if our House endorses our recommendations. We have succeeded in enforcing the European consensus on development, we have succeeded in enforcing the rights of the European Parliament by trying to include the different positions we have taken in recent years on this subject, and we have - and this is no small matter - an advance on the Council: we are ready and our bet , it was to finish before the end of this Parliament. We present a coherent report on the future of external relations of neighbourly and development cooperation and international cooperation.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: rapporteur of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Mr President, our contributions from the Committee on Budgets have been, first of all, to align the proposal with the position that this Parliament voted on with regard to the 2021-2027 financial framework. And in this sense we have increased to 35% the contribution that this new fund, this instrument, has to make to the fight against climate change; in addition, we have increased the endowment by almost EUR 4 billion in investments exclusively for Africa. On the other hand, we have also limited the maximum guarantee endowment to EUR 10 billion to avoid a possible imbalance between subsidies and financial instruments and have established a mechanism by which the European Parliament will have to approve the use of the reserve envisaged in this fund. On the other hand, we have also guaranteed the European Investment Bank a minimum volume of sovereign investment operations in the public sector so that they are not interrupted by the change to the new instrument. And finally, and following the work we had already done in the Sustainable Development Fund, we have also finalized the definition of additionality, established stricter criteria in the fight against fraud, tax evasion and money laundering, and also improved complaint mechanisms.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, let me thank the rapporteurs and all of you for the efficient joint work undertaken in the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET), Committee on Development (DEVE) and Committee on Budgets (BUDG), leading to the timely finalisation of the report on the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instruct (NDICI) proposal.  I am pleased that the report gives overall support to the politically and financially ambitious proposal of the Commission. I especially welcome Parliament’s support for a more coherent and responsive instrument. Europe’s voice in the world will be louder and its priorities better served through this instrument – priorities such as the neighbourhood, sub-Saharan Africa, eradication of poverty, sustainable development, migration, promoting human rights and democracy, fighting climate change and preserving peace. I am also glad to see Parliament retained investment as one of the modalities that should be mobilised to pursue these objectives.  I am personally convinced that the budgetisation of the European Development Fund (EDF) will considerably enhance the European Parliament’s legislative, budgetary and scrutiny roles. Overall, I think all these elements will contribute to ensuring that the new instrument meets our objectives and commitments made in the context of the European Union’s global strategy, the new European consensus on development and the global 2030 Agenda. In the context of the inclusion of neighbourhood policy financing in the NDICI instrument that the Commission unanimously proposed and maintained, let me underline this point again: a streamlined, more efficient architecture of our external spending does not call into question the political importance of any single geographical or thematic policy. On the contrary, we want to maximise the impact of each policy while improving our ability to mobilise additional resources where they are needed the most. This is particularly important in response to unforeseen developments, for instance in our neighbourhood. In our vision, programming is the process that will ensure the link between the implementation of the sustainable development goals (SDGs), the European Union’s interests, external action interests and the interest of our partners. This process can only translate into the intended results if it is kept flexible. I also welcome the political ambition of the report to focus on major priorities like human development and the fight against climate change. I believe, however, that such targets should be aspirational and not legally binding obligations. Otherwise, they risk constraining our external activities in a complex and ever-changing context.  I reiterate my conviction that the European Union’s ambitions as the leading international development actor are fully reflected in this proposal, and I welcome your support. However, in the context of the 2030 Agenda, a 95% DAC-ability target may not be realistic. Indeed, it is important to keep a sufficient degree of flexibility to fulfil the European Union’s ambitions in the area of conflict prevention and peace, or in our cooperation with industrialised countries. I believe that by making a legal commitment to achieve a 92% DAC-ability, the Commission is already proposing an ambitious target. The Commission is ready to engage with Parliament in order to explore how best to enhance its role of steering and oversight. A frank and substantive dialogue both at political and technical level with Parliament is indeed our objective in full respect of the interinstitutional balance. However, I think that creating additional layers of institutional control and making excessive use of delegated acts will not achieve that objective. Instead, it will make the functioning of the instrument too complex. Keeping sufficient flexibility is key. In this regard, the foreign policy needs and priorities component for rapid response actions should be maintained in the non-programmable pillar. As is the case for the reserve in the current EDF, the cushion would give us the necessary capacity to respond timely and efficiently to the type of unexpected needs that are so common in external action in the neighbourhood and beyond. I do not believe, therefore, that unallocated funds for the cushion for emerging challenges and priorities should be reduced, nor should their mobilisation become more complex. I look forward to the debate and to tomorrow’s vote, and I thank you so much.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. – Mr President, making the foreign policy budget more accountable and more efficient is necessary, so when the Commission proposed a quite radical reform, I was open—minded. But what I’ve been hammering for, from that day on, is that the only way we could actually assess whether the proposed new so-called architecture that merges various funding lines into one would be more fit for purpose is if we knew how the money would be governed. That is still very weak spot in the Commission proposal. We put some proposals on the table – a steering group between the External Action Service and the Commission, and it’s not a secret that that cooperation can be improved – but we also looked at how to ensure more conditionality to the billions of euros suggested under a so-called flexible amount. This Parliament needs to be able to apply scrutiny. With only 1.6 % of the budget reserved for human rights, my second warning is to avoid a total instrumentalising of the EU’s foreign affairs budget for ‘migration management’ and ‘countering terrorism’. We are a values and rules-based Union, and that should be reflected in the foreign affairs budget too.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
