text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Mr President, fellow president, in recent decades the great number of challenges we have shared has become apparent. Therefore, the new Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument is one of the most important proposals of this legislature. This radical change in external action financial instruments will result in greater flexibility and will also help the European Union strengthen its role on the world stage. It is essential that the actions carried out under this instrument contribute to achieving the sustainable development goals, the 2030 Agenda and the global pacts. In this regard, as draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Education and Culture, I would like to highlight the role of inclusive and quality education as a key element in reducing inequalities and poverty; an essential element in fostering tolerance, building more peaceful societies and addressing the root causes of migration. In conclusion, I would like to stress the need to strengthen partnership with neighbourhood countries if we are to jointly address the challenges. It is therefore imperative that this instrument preserves the financing of European Neighbourhood Policy.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this instrument is a geopolitical instrument more than a development mechanism. The mantra is: 'let us help migrants at home' and 'let us first help the regions that best respond to our immediate foreign policy interests'. Everything must be put in place to ensure that migratory flows cease to be irregular and become – and I am going to say – 'regular, safe and responsible'. The migrant scarecrow is born, not only illegal, but irresponsible. The traditional development policy merges with foreign policy and also with military agreements, against previous opinions of Parliament and outside its control. Western regime-change wars, which generate misery and mass displacement, are completely ignored. It is true that there is no lack of mention of poverty to be eradicated and of human rights. I fear both the homage that vice pays to virtue.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking as draftsman of the opinion of the FEMM Committee on the proposal for a regulation we are debating, a task that I very much welcomed having, during this parliamentary term, cooperated very closely with NGOs, associations and international networks in the field of cooperation. I have to say that I have been faced with issues similar to those referred to a short time before the draftsman of the LIBE opinion: a text which should have dealt with promoting the fundamental principles of the European Union, such as gender equality, human rights, respect for the environment and for cultures, takes the form of its most legislative form as an attempt to allocate funds to manage migratory flows. , to define human beings as 'legal' and 'illegal' and to fortify Europe's borders. Despite the positive results achieved in the negotiation of the FEMM opinion, I can only note with regret that the final text goes backwards not only with regard to femm's opinion but also with regard to the European Commission's gender action plan: a resolution in which references to women's empowerment, gender-based violence and women's rights do not even appear in the main text but only in the appendices to the text.

name: David McALLISTER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, as Chair of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET), I would first of all like to thank all four rapporteurs for their excellent work. The objective of our European Parliament is hopefully clear. We want to make sure that the European Union’s external action is underpinned by sufficient funds so that it can be an effective tool for upholding and promoting our values and interests worldwide. European external action should be coherent and flexible. Therefore, merging the numerous existing financing instruments is an important measure to reach this objective. As a European Parliament, we have a fundamental interest in balancing coherence and flexibility with enhanced democratic accountability and control mechanisms. Therefore, I do welcome that this report provides for an enhanced dialogue between our Parliament and Commissioner Mimica – between the Commission – and the use of delegated acts for important strategic decisions.

name: Norbert NEUSER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has EUR 100 billion over seven years? This is a huge instrument which has been viewed with great scepticism by many of my fellow Members. I would particularly like to thank the rapporteurs and my S&D colleague Antonio Panzeri, with whom I have worked closely.  I believe that it is a draft that is good, a round package, which we have jointly adopted in the AFET and DEVE committees and which we should not re-enter. I would like to draw attention to a number of important points that are important to me from the point of view of development cooperation.  We have achieved that 45 per cent – 45 per cent instead of 25 per cent – of the total budget is used for climate, environmental protection, biodiversity protection and desertification. Secondly, we have managed to see migration more in the context of international challenges. It is important to us that migration policy ensures the safety of people and good planning and implementation, and that people enjoy protection, as enshrined in international law and in our values of the European Union. Migration is really only the result of conflicts, of poverty, of a lack of development. Above all, we want to aim at the strategy of combating the root causes. That's why 10 percent is enough for migration management.  I think that we, particularly as Social Democrats, should warmly welcome this instrument. It is also about gender equality and the rights and participation of women and girls. I am convinced that this instrument is a good basis and the feedback from civil society is absolutely positive. Thank you again for their constructive cooperation!

name: Mirja VEHKAPERÄ
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument is an ambitious reform of the European Union's external relations funding. We will vote on it at a critical time. During the coming funding period, either the success of the 2030 Agenda and the SDC will be ensured or miserably failed. Parliament's proposal is therefore more ambitious than the Commission's proposal. We want to allocate 45% of the funding to climate and environmental measures. We have also brought gender equality more strongly on board and supported investments in social and human development, such as education and health. Now the European Development Fund has also been included in the European Union budget, which strengthens democratic control over development aid. I hope that the Council will accept this. By streamlining external financing, the EU will strengthen its role as a global player. This requires investment in all policy areas, both far away and in our neighbouring regions, for example through the Northern Dimension and arctic cooperation. Sustainable development, human rights, democracy, human development and equality, as well as the eradication of poverty, will continue to serve as a good guideline for external relations. But objectives alone are not enough;

name: Michel REIMON
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has As Greens, we were very sceptical about an instrument where so many financing systems are being pooled under one roof. We then tried to get involved in the negotiations as constructively as possible, took this very seriously, as Mr Preda said, 200 amendments from us alone, while 300 of the four rapporteurs come. We have tried to get in as much as possible, and we have succeeded in a lot of things, we think. The rapporteurs have indeed approached us. I think it was a very constructive negotiation for much of it. However, it must also be said, because we have been mentioned here, that there has been much more progress in quantitative terms. We have not always been completely convinced of the quality. A great deal has gone on in the area of climate protection, a great deal in the area of women's equality. However, the most important points are still in the comments, in the recitals, and not in the actual text. We therefore abstained in committee once and then wanted to continue negotiating. We are still ready to use the last night to take some decisive steps and move on and to give this instrument the finishing touches that we believe could make it possible to agree. But then there must be yet another crucial commitment. As it is now, it could be a good policy. But I see no obligation to do that. Nothing is really fixed. In the area of migration, the money could also be used in measures that we certainly do not support. We still have to take a final step in the negotiations.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the European Commission's proposal for the unification of all the financial instruments of our external action is an offense to this Parliament. The European Parliament's Resolution of 14 March 2008, in which the House called for specific and separate instruments for development cooperation and humanitarian aid, has been ignored. We therefore reject this legislative proposal in its entirety. Because the merger of existing funds does not imply greater respect for the principle of development policy coherence, which is what should govern our action abroad, but quite the opposite, as it will use development aid funds in geostrategic and defence interests. The real objective behind this merger is the use of the enormous amount of security development aid, in the control of migration flows, in the outsourcing of borders. European citizens should know that, through this proposal, the European Union will no longer be the world's largest donor of development aid, something we could be proud of. From now on, that money can be used in weapons, fences, concertinas and border patrols. Day after day, this Union represents less and less the ideals that gave it life, and then we wonder where this social disaffection comes from by institutions like this. Finally, proposals like this also take us away from our objectives and our international commitments, such as the 2030 Agenda, with which our mouths are so filled.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I usually begin by congratulating the rapporteurs on the work done. On this occasion I cannot do so, because the two co-constituents of my group have not yet agreed. But, however, Mr President, I think what this is about is having a foreign policy that is more coherent, more visible and more effective. And for this purpose, the significant amounts that this financial instrument foresees must serve. I think we would be wrong to debate if we had to discuss whether we are dealing with a unitary instrument or a differentiated instrument. I think the important thing, Mr President, is that the European Union weighs on the international stage according to its economic, commercial, financial and industrial weight; that the European Union has a coherent policy that can adapt to changing challenges and that, as Mrs Schaake said, which has left the Chamber, we can preserve and maintain the prerogatives of the European Parliament. Make no mistake about debate. This is not a unitary instrument or differentiated instruments, but rather of putting an emphasis on foreign policy and the visibility of the European Union's external action.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: – Mr President, I won’t repeat what the rapporteurs and the other speakers from my group have said about the key amendments which they have tabled to this draft instrument. They make an improvement to the text, and I hope the Council will accept them.  I’d like to thank the co—rapporteurs, in particular Frank Engel and Charles Goerens from the Committee on Development (DEVE), because they have stood up for European development policy and presented it as more than a simple foreign policy tool. It is its own distinctive policy, based on values rooted in the fight against extreme poverty and the fight for global justice. In the short time left, just two quick points. Firstly, the period in which the new instrument will operate is going to be a crucial one. Between now and 2030, the EU and the global community must deliver on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the Paris Climate Agreement, as well as on the promise of creating a sustainable future – not just for ourselves, but for all who share our planet. EU external action and development will be part of that. Finally, colleagues, this will probably be the last time I’ll speak to this Chamber as an MEP, so after 21 years, I would like to say some thank yous. Thank you, Commissioner Mimica, and your staff. You’ve been brilliant to work with. Thank you to my colleagues on the Committee on Development (DEVE) in particular, the colleagues from the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) we’ve worked with tonight, the staff and the MEPs.  But I want to pick out two people tonight for a special thank you: my two researchers up in the public gallery. They told me that tonight is the first time they’ve had time to come here, because they’re always so busy working. So for James Carey and Laura O’Connor, a special thank you to both of you. Thank you. (Applause)

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Mr President, this is an unfortunate construction. Foreign policy and development policy are not always the same. In fact, foreign policy is often short-term and intended for our own well-being, where development policy aims to combat poverty. That is also what the European Treaty says: sustainable poverty reduction. By merging those two, you run the risk of not doing so. When I hear the Commissioner say that he actually thinks 95% ODAble is too high and that he would like to keep a lot of money available for flexible deployment, I am very concerned because development cooperation does not benefit from flexible short-term commitment. Development cooperation must be long-term and predictable. The Greens are therefore not happy with this merger and the Greens do not really understand what plan B is if it fails to manage the European Development Fund in this area. Because then you don't have that money at all.  Short-term policy is also not good for combating climate change. We are pleased, however, that the co-rapporteurs have adopted a proposal to spend 45% of the money on climate action. We have tried to be very constructive in our proposals. We are also pleased that many proposals have been adopted, but let us be clear: this is about the result. The Greens have been very cooperative, but there are no guarantees where we see that the negotiations with the Council and with the European Commission are really going to help to shape this sustainable poverty reduction.

name: Sabine LÖSING
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It can now be described as a trend that the EU is now using funds originally designed for development aid for migration defence and military purposes – such as the change to the Instrument for Stability and Peace, the EU Trust Fund for Africa and now the single ones in the consolidation of the existing external financial instruments.  Military as a development aid worker? Unfortunately, this is provided for in the Commission's proposal and, unfortunately, also in the agreed text from the committee. The military in crisis areas does not fight poverty and does not eliminate the causes of conflict. This is the final end to neutral, civil European crisis assistance. On the grounds that they are more flexible and effective, the instruments are merged at the expense of democratic control and transparency.  In our view, the merger of all policy areas in the new NDICI, including development cooperation, will lead to a subordination of all policy areas and EU aid to the EU's geostrategic and economic interests. The involvement and financing of military actors and so-called partner armies in the context of training measures and their use as a kind of transitional administration – military as administration! – in crisis areas, we are firmly opposed. This view is also shared by many civil society organisations on the ground. I wonder very much where the colleague from the Socialists in the Committee on Development got his information from. We have tabled a motion to reject the present proposal.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, I want to thank the rapporteurs for their work on this file. When I saw the proposal from the Commission for the first time, I was quite sceptical. As the former rapporteur on the European Neighbourhood Instrument (ENI) and European Fund for Sustainable Development (EFSD), I saw problems in combining both of our external instruments under one umbrella, especially in the case of the ENI. It will be crucial to keep the initial philosophy of this instrument as a policy—driven instrument for our neighbourhood partners. I support continuation of the ‘more for more’ principle. We established this principle in order to reward and support reforms, efforts leading to the consolidation of democracy, rule of law and protection of human rights and support for economic governance reforms. At the same time, we should find the proper framework for discussing the performance and allocation for ‘more for more’. Also, the European Parliament should be more involved in the designing, programming and monitoring of the instrument.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the rapporteurs. I would like to say that the new Single Fund for External Action, which brings together the Fund for Cooperation and Neighbourhood, must certainly not represent a confusion of policies, objectives and loss of specificity, but it does point to a new focus on a decisive hub in order to give shape to stronger cooperation and partnership in the educational and cultural fields. I therefore see, at last, the new strategy inaugurated by the European Union for international cultural relations, which is now fundamental if Europe is to be a global player, is also strongly recalled. I was its rapporteur, which is why I welcome it. This is the first time that the European Instrument for International Policies and Relations has provided that resources can also be used to support Erasmus Mundus activities, for example, with third countries, something that african children and young people from neighbouring countries have insistently asked us to do. In addition, the rapporteurs have taken up the proposal of my committee and our rapporteur to strengthen bilateral international relations between the Union and third countries in all bilateral agreements, also in the light of the new European cultural agenda. I believe that this is an important element in promoting cooperation, intercultural and interreligious dialogue and the role of those involved in this field, who can bring the different civil societies closer together.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Mr President, continuity and consistency are of particular importance in foreign policy. Equally important are the use of more effective external action, policy instruments, as well as sufficient funding, neighbourhood development and international cooperation, and the instrument in question covers them all. It has already been mentioned today that three committees and four rapporteurs have participated in this document, thank you all.  I will notice that there are doubts about several aspects.  Firstly, the European Development Fund and its financing from the European Union budget.  Secondly, the neighbourhood policy. This policy is particularly important. It is enshrined in our treaties. It is good that it is providing for more funding, but there is a clear lack of clarity, as is the consensus in the European Commission and, by the way, in the European Parliament on this issue.  And thirdly, I would like to stress the importance of consistency with the European Union's trade policy, our trade priorities. As with our desire to defend a rules-based multilateral trading system.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal to combine the instruments for neighbourhood, development and cooperation, as well as for the promotion of fundamental rights, which are so important for our external action, could have aroused some concern but, thanks to Parliament's work, the text seems to me to have improved considerably. The increase in the resources envisaged is in line with our demands. I am also particularly pleased to see included the priorities expressed by the AFET Working Group on External Financial Instruments, of which I am a member. For example, with regard to the role of Parliament and democratic control over spending decisions, for greater flexibility and simplification of procedures. It is important that a specific chapter is devoted to the neighbourhood policy, with human rights conditionality as the guiding principle of THE UNION's financial support to our partner countries. The Union needs to regain credibility in its external action, while remaining true to its values even when it pursues its national and strategic interests. It is time to take a step forward together to play a stronger and more constructive role in the development of a peaceful neighbourhood, while also counteracting forms of neo-colonialism that come from other parts of the world.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – Mr President-in-Office, honourable Commissioners, dear colleagues, this instrument has long been important for promoting the values and principles of the European Union. I very much support the ambition to link external financing instruments and also to strengthen flexibility in terms of future development, which must not go to the expense of democratic accountability and control mechanisms. I support the amendments proposed by my colleague Preda and the Group of the European People's Party, which are calling for a separate instrument for neighbourhood policy, and stress the political importance of relations between the Union and its neighbouring countries. Our neighbourhood policy should receive particular attention, which would distinguish it from the other components of our development policy.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Madam President, if used appropriately, but only if used properly, can this instrument serve to make the voice of the European Union more coherent and audible outwards and abroad, and to use that voice for the promotion of democratic values, social sustainability, protection of human rights, cooperation, peace and stability. As rapporteur on humanitarian aid issues in this Parliament, I have seen during this time the extent to which humanitarian crises have changed in nature. Emergency crises have become long-term crises, and political solutions—global action—are just as important as immediate help in resolving people's needs. Only if the European Union uses this instrument to preserve peace or to recompose it where it breaks, will it be worthy of the support we will give it tomorrow in the vote.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab As far as I can remember, the existing instruments – external action – are ending at the end of next year. Therefore, they must be replaced by new instruments and it is good that they are amended, that they are corrected. This means that we use different experiences, and good and bad, to make these instruments better. This is not small money, it is close to EUR 90 billion, so it is important that the instruments are well matched, coherent and give the European Commission the opportunity to act effectively, to eliminate poverty, to promote democracy, and to interfere also in those economic activities that are important for Europe.  I will also emphasise, on behalf of the Committee on Culture, the call to use instruments that are included, which are precisely inclusive, such as Creative Europe, Erasmus+ programmes or what is also ending – Horizon 2020. In my opinion, the skillful use of the wider culture, of all these cultural industries, but also of educational programmes, of scholarship programmes will ensure that this instrument is more effective.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, the increasing number of multidimensional and rapidly evolving global challenges underlines that the EU needs to become a more effective global actor. Restructuring our external action instruments is one crucial point, but we also need to focus much more on policy and programming coordination with Member States. I note the Commission’s proposal of a single instrument and trust this will go hand—in—hand with greater parliamentary oversight. My questions to the Commission are: firstly, will the Commission work with Parliament to agree on a criteria triggering a suspension of funding to partner countries in cases of human rights violations? Secondly, this report proposes a better alignment of the EU’s future external investments with the Paris Agreement goals. Will the Commission commit to our proposed climate and environmental spending targets? Thirdly, Parliament’s proposal to cap assistance for activities linked to the capacity building of military actors seeks to ensure we focus on economic regeneration as opposed to defence. I trust the Commission will respect this with the new instrument.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Madam President, as presented in the EU global strategy, never has our unity been so challenged. We can fight these challenges by ensuring a more inclusive European approach in external action, including closer development cooperation. We need to maximise the added value and shared the expertise of all Member States. Together, we will be able to achieve more than any Member State acting alone. To reach this objective, I – supported by a diverse group of co—signing colleagues from different political groups – tabled Amendment 555, which calls ‘to foster collaboration and increase our capacities’.  It is important to use this window of opportunity through the next Multiannual Financial Framework, and in particular the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument, to promote our unique European competence to act effectively together.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, eradicating poverty is the main objective of development cooperation. The Union's external action goes hand in hand with the major global challenges, in particular the achievement of the objectives of the 2030 Agenda. With the adoption of the Neighbourhood Instrument, Development Cooperation and International Cooperation, we are taking a further step forward in the fight against poverty, both economically and democratically, socially and environmentally. The new and ambitious instrument will give the possibility of having a greater strength and unity of intervention while respecting the universal rights of democracy, the rule of law, human rights, socio-economic integration and environmental protection. I would like to stress that unity does not mean a lack of diversification: on the contrary, geographical priorities will continue to be of great importance, as for example with the new agreements with the ACP countries.  The innovative unity of the instrument will lead the Union to have even greater influence on the international stage, where only a firm and holistic response will be effective.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, it is clear from the debate that I have listened carefully here that there is no complete unity in what this new financial instrument is supposed to look like, and yet it is a very important programme for development in third countries and also for neighbourhood policy, which has very good results and tradition. It is a large financial instrument with which we can change reality and contribute to development in third countries. We can prevent further migration crises. It is therefore important that we have this programme ready for the next financial period.  I understand the Commission is trying to make it more efficient, which is why it brings together some sub-programmes, but we should do it sensibly. There is some need to make it more difficult for grants and beneficiaries to be made clear. According to civil society representatives, there is a risk of losing specific forms already built, and i will therefore support the amendment which aims at a separate neighbourhood programme.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, in the age of Trump and Bolsonaro, and with Putin’s agents interfering in democratic processes, international cooperation and support for neighbouring countries has never been more important. I’m glad to see that recommendations from the Committee on Culture and Education are included in the final version of the text that we will be voting on. For instance, Parliament supports the fact that the new financial instrument can be used for the Creative Europe and Erasmus+ programmes. This will significantly strengthen the cultural dimension of EU foreign affairs through cultural diplomacy and people—to—people contact. This is very important for building understanding and trust in order to foster peace and strengthen democratic life. In fragile democracies and post—conflict countries, it is often arts, sport and cultural activity that create the foundation for rebuilding societies.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, we should welcome the fact that, through the new Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI), the many existing financial instruments will be simplified. This, together with a bigger allocation of funds, should help make EU actions abroad more relevant. However, the key question we must address is the following: will this new instrument primarily serve the promotion of the EU’s geopolitical and economic interests, or, on the contrary, will it mainly promote the achievement of the internationally recognised principles of development aid and international cooperation? In other words, will the new NDICI be an instrument to, for instance, make development aid conditional upon migration policies or to promote the commercial interests of the EU, or will it rather be an instrument to combat poverty and climate change worldwide and promote human rights and democracy, peace and the prevention of conflicts? We must ensure that the priorities, policies and goals of this new instrument that will be supported in practice are the right ones.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I see neighbourhood policy and development aid as one of the instruments of our security. We cannot only care about security in the internal space, but we must also focus on the world around us. There's no doubt about that. I therefore welcome the amount proposed in the budget under this new instrument. In my opinion, this instrument supports a higher level of efficiency precisely by merging several previously separate instruments. I very much hope that there will be a reduction in administrative and personnel costs, for example, and that the efficiency will actually be reflected.  Every Thursday we deal with human rights violations in many countries around the world. And I think that we can now make that political conditionality, that is, by implementing basic democratic procedures, those that we think are the content of our Europeanism, so we can make development aid conditional on that, and I think that it can also contribute to making our policy more effective.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – I would also like to draw attention to this – Commissioner, please listen – and I would like to say one more thing. Questions have been put to you here. I do not know whether Commissioner Hahn wishes to take part in the debate at this stage, but there have been questions about cooperation with Parliament in the use of the instrument, there has been a question here about how conditionality is to be achieved with regard to human rights, whether the instrument will be linked to immigration ... This is a great opportunity to answer the members' questions. Now I would like to give you the floor.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you so much for this very useful debate. Let me congratulate you again for your determination and success in concluding Parliament’s first—reading position in a timely manner. This will allow us to start negotiations as soon as the Council is ready. We in the European Commission are fully and unanimously convinced that establishing a coherent and more responsive Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI) is a paramount step in promoting and delivering on our objectives and commitments made in the context of the EU Global Strategy, the European Consensus on Development and the global 2030 Agenda. I insist that this will be best done within the proposed NDICI architecture by safeguarding and ring—fencing the specific measures and the political importance of each geographical and thematic policy, including human rights and democracy.  In our view, any amendment that might undermine – let alone dismantle – a coherent structure of the NDICI instrument, as supported by the report, would only contribute to inconsistency and contradictions between our policy goals and our financial capacity to carry them forward. In that context, I am confident that the existence of any self—standing financial instrument does not add more significance to any particular EU policy. On the contrary, the best way of overcoming policy silos is building true policy coherence, including funding coherence of our financial instruments.  I would also like to draw to your attention that the financing instruments as proposed by the Commission are fully in line with our development priorities – our development substance that is set in the European Consensus on Development. Therefore, a human—rights—based approach, eradicating poverty, and a rule—based democratic approach to all of our partner countries are – and will be – important and a prevailing part of the implementation policy of our financial instruments.  Also, to all those honourable Members that tabled their concerns on the possible diversion of development funding towards military goals, I would like to point towards revisiting the founding treaties of the European Union, under which any military action funded by the European budget is actually impossible, and this will definitely not be part and parcel of our development policy. Also, let me stress again that the DAC-ability target and the spending targets as proposed by the Commission strike the right balance. They balance the level of our political ambition in each different policy and geographic area and the flexibility needed for implementing those commitments in the most effective way. Finally, let me reassure you again of our commitment to an open dialogue with you to find a fair and balanced solution in order to enhance Parliament’s role of oversight and political steering.  Thank you once again, and we all look forward to the vote tomorrow.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the ability to see globally and maintain geographical and sectoral objectives: this is the choice we have made fully and consistently, so I do not understand the concerns of some about the single instrument. We must not be afraid of the challenges that this instrument presents to all of us. And then let's face it, because in the course of the discussion these months, those who seem so dedicated to the neighborhood, were actually ready to sacrifice the southern neighborhood to look only and exclusively to the east. That is why we were right to incorporate all the instruments. The second issue is governance. The choice we have made is essential: to have greater control and involvement of the European Parliament, through delegated acts and a more meaningful and regular strategic dialogue, which takes account of programming decisions, is important and it is really strange that no one has dwelt on this element of transparency and the possibility for the European Parliament to actually co-decide. Thirdly, I find it forced to read from someone that the instrument seems almost set up to stop immigration. Let us not allow political polemics to lose sight of the real and important issues of an instrument that seeks to give a global dimension to the European Union's actions. Finally, I would like to address the Commission: it is quite clear that the effort made, not without problems, by the European Parliament, should be matched by a qualitative leap forward, both in foreign policy and in the European Union's development policy, showing here a truly great coherence and a capacity for intervention and leadership that has been lacking in some way in recent years.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to clarify the amendment I tabled on behalf of the EPP Group to the motion for a resolution that accompanies the report. It is not a question of unravelling what we have achieved together over the last eight months, we have been able to improve things in terms of neighbourhood. There is a 24% increase in funding, and we have more generally strengthened the policy framework for the neighbourhood, which remains a priority in our action. We have also improved the results-based approach, which is one of the central pillars of European Neighbourhood Policy. However, it is also necessary to be realistic and to say things clearly as they are: the door remains open for a separate neighbourhood instrument. We know very well that the Member States remain divided in the Council on this issue and I believe that all options must be kept on the table for the next Parliament, which will go to the negotiations because, like it or not, the instrument of neighbourhood, development cooperation and international cooperation remains for the moment a colossus with feet of clay. And I would also like to add that, during the negotiations, our colleagues in the Committee on Development tried to channel this whole process into a single development logic. They even proposed extraordinary things, Mr. Panzeri mentioned, such as eliminating the countries of northern Africa from the Southern Neighbourhood Policy and keeping only the countries of the Middle East and a small part to the east. The idea of breaking a policy with an instrument is unacceptable, but they have tried everything to grab the idea of international cooperation and diminish the meaning of foreign and neighbourhood policy. For me, you always have to take a political perspective. Neighbours are more important than anything from the point of view of these financial instruments, I cannot ignore this, I cannot sacrifice our neighbours, Europe's neighbours for an abstract interest and to have more money to fuel dreams without pragmatism.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I might feel targeted by what has just been said, but I decide to ignore it. We have heard once again tonight all the nonsense of the extreme left that we have already had to digest in the past months, namely that it is an instrument of militarism, that it is a martial instrument, that it is an instrument intended to prevent any form of migration. All of this is, of course, not true.  It is basically an extremely interesting instrument because it would finally enable the implementation of the Africa strategy, which we call for at every summit, which has been taking place for two or three years, and which, until then, due to a lack of coherent funding, has not been able to see the light of day.  It would also allow us to have another interaction between the territories covered by the neighbourhood policy and the territories covered by the cooperation policy, which makes a lot of sense. Because in the world in which we live, we cannot really separate Algeria from Niger, or Libya from Chad, or Morocco from Mauritania. We must be aware that all this closer interaction between the territories covered by one policy and the territories covered by another policy is also progress in terms of coherence. We are also safeguarding all options for the continuation of our partnership with the ACP countries, which I think is important given that, from next year, the Cotonou agreements will have to be replaced by something else. We do not know exactly what it will be, but in any case, from now on, the instrument we have on the table covers all the contingencies.  In short, it is also a good instrument because it includes the neighbourhood and I would very much like that tomorrow, when we are out of this room, it will be like this again and again because I think that fetishism does not help us as much as the political realism that all our external policies are financed coherently and ambitiously.  That's it, I have nothing more to add.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I must say again that within the four co-speakers we have had a frank, open discussion. We have exchanged arguments and what matters is the final compromise. Also, blaming one or the other for making his arguments does not count. Finally, what matters is the result and I think we did it in a constructive spirit. That's what I remember from our work. I have heard some comments that can only come from colleagues who have barely read the report. I have read the Commission document, I have contributed to the preparation of this report and some remarks are not at all justified. Some say that it is not a good place for development. We have agreed to devote 95% of this instrument to development and the neighbourhood side even devotes most of the funds for development. Therefore, let us not be told that this is not an instrument of development. Geographical pillars are secure. There is no difference from the previous policy. The method has changed, we have a common reserve for all these instruments, which are now merged, and this allows the Commission to do a better job.  We have also tried to increase the prerogatives of the European Parliament. When we say that we could have done more for development, I will tell you one thing: here, in this instrument, we have not only done the maximum, but we have even tried to go beyond that. If we want to spend more development funds on the EUROPEAN Union's foreign policy, we must go to the Member States that have made promises, including spending 0.7% on official development assistance. If the Member States kept their promises and pledged to cooperate closely with the Commission, at the very least, at least an additional EUR 200 billion could be spent on European development policy in the coming period.  Therefore, it is not in Brussels or Strasbourg that we should address these reproaches, we must go to Berlin, Paris, Rome, Madrid, Warsaw, Prague, Lisbon. We have to go wherever these promises are not kept.  If we want to make the European Union a real development factor, we must realize that the European Union is not only the Commission but also the Member States. That is the European Union. It's sad to have to remember these facts.  From this point of view, I believe that we have done a job that allows us to approach the trilogue discussions with a level of view with the Council, to be modest, because the Council has not yet done its homework. We hope that he will do them everywhere and that our views will not be too divergent.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, 27 October 2008. Adopted on 13 March 2019.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the report by José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra and Knut Fleckenstein, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assn. (IPA III) (COM(20) 18)0465 - C8-0274/2018 - 2018/0247(COD)) (A8-0174/2019).

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the first words in making this speech would like you to be addressed to the co-speaker, Mr Fleckenstein, to thank him for the excellent cooperation he has given. I understand that this cooperation can be interpreted as a model of understanding between the political groups of this Parliament. I would also like to extend this thanks to the rest of the shadow rapporteurs. Commissioner, I would like, before making an introduction to the main elements of this report, to share a concern which has been raised by some colleagues, a little in the context of the electoral process to which we are approaching, in relation to the name of this Regulation — The Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA III) — and the list of potential beneficiaries. I hope that in the course of the further discussions and the negotiations to be taking place, these doubts that some colleagues have expressed can be cleared up. Firstly, it seems to me that it is important to underline the importance of the financial endowment of this instrument: around EUR 15 billion. It is a very important amount, which is intended to support the political, administrative, economic, legal and institutional reforms that countries in this area of pre-accession have to have. These instruments are also aimed at supporting everything about structural reforms and public governance, and are aimed at specific areas of action, which are the principles that inspire the Action of the European Union: respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, the rule of law and the rule of law. Finally, the areas of action are the policy areas of the European Union: economic and social development, agricultural policy and agricultural development, research, development and innovation, development policy in the field of the environment and the fight against climate change, and in particular, Madam President, everything relating to interterritorial and cross-border cooperation. There are three fundamental elements that characterize this new financial instrument that distinguish it from the previous ones. They are, first of all, the principle of equitable sharing, direct and indirect management and, above all, the need to deepen everything that concerns the visibility of the European Union's financial action. On the other hand, I am also interested in highlighting the support it has given to prerogatives, as noted in the previous debate of the European Parliament. This instrument, such as the Neighbourhood Policy, Development and International Cooperation Instrument, seeks to strengthen and strengthen the capacities of this Parliament, which will set annual amounts with the Council, within the framework of the multiannual financial perspective. The Commission must take into account the positions and resolutions adopted by the European Parliament. Parliament will be associated with all developments in programming and, through delegated acts, will have a more active role in maintaining a real strategic dialogue in which Parliament, The Commission and the Council can play their part in each institution. There is another element— and I conclude with this, Madam President. We have found a balanced formula for combining the role to be played by the Commission and the External Action Service in the development of everything related to this financial instrument and I hope, Commissioner, that in the course of the previous developments presented to us by the legislative programme we will be able to continue working and cooperating to make real instrument a fundamental element for the countries of pre-accession. I conclude as I began, Madam President, by thanking Mr Fleckenstein for his work; I hope that we will be able in the coming weeks to continue to cooperate in the institutional triangle in order to try to give a definitive profile to this much-needed and so essential instrument within the framework of the European Union's external action.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, Mr Salafranca, thank you very much for your kind words. You are right about everything you have said about me, but I can give it back one to one: it was a very good cooperation, and above all the result is correct. IPA III is an instrument that does not serve any neighbourhood with EUR 15 billion. The beneficiaries are none other than future Member States of the European Union, namely the six Western Balkan countries.  Last weekend marked the 20th anniversary of NATO's deployment in the former Yugoslavia against the Milosevic regime. This reminded us of the region's past. The ultimate objective of the EU's enlargement policy, including in the war-torn Western Balkans, must be peace and reconciliation. With IPA III funds, we want to serve this goal. Good neighbourly relations, cooperation and networking between countries and many different ethnic groups are therefore highlighted in this report.  The European Union is the largest donor in the region, but an astonishing percentage of people there do not know this. But the people of the region need to know who their biggest supporter is. Obviously, we need to be louder and clearer so that we can be heard and seen. Other countries, such as China, Russia, Turkey, and Arab countries, have long been involved in investment. But these investments are nowhere near as sustainable and forward-looking as ours. That is why I say that we too must keep promoting and presenting our good work.  The statistics tell us that the economy in the candidate countries is growing. But in real terms, one can hardly see a real improvement in living conditions. Growth hardly generates new jobs and thus prospects for living at home. Many people in the Western Balkans still see no other way out than emigration, so it was particularly important to us that this instrument not only provides aid to central governments in the capitals, but also reaches rural regions. It should not matter which party has a majority there. People's living standards must be improved, democracy and prosperity must go hand in hand. Institution-building, democratisation and the rule of law are also the highest priorities of our instrument.  Ensuring the rule of law is not a gift to Mr Juncker or Mr Tusk or to Commissioner Hahn. Respect for and implementation at the micro level down to the highest levels of society is a duty, both for the state and for the citizen. Without the rule of law, EU law cannot one day be adopted or properly implemented.  However, the EU loses its credibility when it demands these values from the candidate countries, but at the same time some Member States no longer respect them. And that is why let us be a good example and use all the possibilities and enforce it in case of doubt.  Ladies and gentlemen, I think we have produced a good report. Thank you to the co-rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs. I am sure that tomorrow, with a broad majority, we will be able to take the next step, also in the interests and for the benefit of our friends in the Western Balkans.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first I would like to congratulate the House, and in particular the rapporteurs, on the excellent work. I am particularly pleased, looking at the Council and Parliament’s positions, that there are many converging views, notably regarding the new thematic programming. The new proposal for pre—accession funding is a EUR 14.5 billion investment in Europe’s own stability, security and prosperity. This instrument helps our partners to strengthen their democratic institutions, improve their judiciaries and public administrations, reform their economies and introduce high EU standards to protect consumers and the environment. All this benefits directly citizens and business in those countries, as well as in the Union itself.  IPA III will be more strategic. Its programming is based on thematic priorities, rather than country allocations, giving it also more of a performance-based nature. It will be important to reach a balance between predictability, which is important for governments to plan their budgets and their national co-financing and, of course, performance, which will allow us to steer strategically and support those partners that commit and deliver.  Strengthening the policy dialogue and building an inclusive partnership with the European Parliament is our objective. We should explore within the limits of the interinstitutional balance in the Treaties. This will be one important point to be discussed during the dialogue, and we look forward to starting it as soon as possible.  One issue that I would like to raise is about respecting the institutional setting between the Commission and the European External Action Service. We clearly need maximum coherence between enlargement and external policy, but what is proposed to amend here would demand disrupting the institutional framework in place. Enlargement policy is first and foremost about exporting internal policies. So, for example, when you propose a horizontal steering group we see duplication with what we have established already on the different chapters of the acquis.  Finally, you have proposed removing the cross-reference to NDICI. As you know, one of the principles for this MFF is simplification and, in particular, achieving a so-called ‘single rule book’. This is important because it streamlines the procedures within the Commission, it increases coherence when dealing with outside partners, and reduces the administrative burden of our actions.  I trust that your intention is not to undermine this objective, but as NDICI and IPA will follow their separate negotiation, we have no guarantees of finishing with the same set of rules. Once again I thank you for your extremely valuable report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Rapporteur for the budg committee's opinion. – Dear Chairman, I welcome Commissioner Hahn. Commissioner, you pointed out in your speech for which all areas the IPA is important. Of course, there are now new challenges facing not only Member States but also these candidate and candidate countries, such as environmental challenges, energy efficiency or migration, so it is important that we provide sufficient resources in the budget to respond to new challenges as well.  You pointed out how important strategic planning is, which is increasingly being improved. What I disagree with is the allocation of funds only by thematic priorities and not by Member State. I think it is very important to continue to have indicative amounts by country, not member states, but candidates and candidates, i.e. beneficiary countries of IPA funds. Why? Because in countries where there are not enough proposed projects and no capacity is strong enough, we need to help with stronger technical assistance. Likewise, we need to administratively reinforce delegations to help these countries to be able to use the funds, not just compete with each other, so those that are better off progressing more and faster.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The EU's accession policy is one of the EU's most successful policies. Many states and their citizens have thus found their way into the EU. In order for the accession process to continue, it is necessary to continue with the instrument of pre-accession assistance, because the people of the countries concerned see their future in the EU. However, in most of these countries, the accession process is proceeding very slowly or, as in the case of Turkey, it is marked by setbacks because it focuses too much on governments. For the countries of the Western Balkans in particular and their people, EU aid must also be turned into a process that works from below. Strengthening the possibilities of cohesion policy, macro-regional, and cross-border cooperation between Member States and local and regional authorities in the candidate countries would make the EU's efforts visible to citizens, which they often are not at the moment – as Mr Fleckenstein pointed out. The new regulations also offer cohesion policy many opportunities for cooperation, including the extension of the EGTC instrument. I hope they will be taken and applied.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: rapporteur on the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Now that we are adopting the new support programme for the accession countries, IPA III, it is important not to repeat past mistakes. In the best of worlds, the funds are used correctly, but sometimes IPA funds have ended up in a strange grey area, such as the armoured vehicles and patrol boats delivered to Turkey to clearly stop the influx of migrants from Syria. Although, according to the responses we have received from the Commissioner in the past, the vehicles were not armed, I find it remarkable that IPA funds – the aim of which is to support reforms and build up their capacity during the accession process – are being used to buy these vehicles in a country such as Turkey, which is in constant conflict with its citizens and its neighbours. We now want IPA III to focus more on strengthening democratic institutions and the rule of law and on reforming the judiciary and public administration, respect for human rights, including minorities, gender equality, workers' rights and non-discrimination. It is also important that IPA funds can be withdrawn for a state that acts contrary to the fundamental values of the EU and is instead paid directly to civil society, to organisations working in support of human rights and fundamental freedoms – in other words, conditional support with greater demands and better control.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, I thank you for continuing the debate we had earlier, I am pleased, first of all, that the IPA has escaped this desire to put everything into this unique instrument. A year ago, my friend Mr. Panzeri was campaigning to also put the IPA inside the great instrument. Fortunately, we are not there yet and our two colleagues, Ignacio Salafranca and Knut Fleckenstein, have done an excellent job on this important issue. Pre-accession funds are a long-term investment, particularly in the European future of the Western Balkans. It is essential that funding is refocused to stimulate clear and irreversible progress on reforms in key areas linked to the Copenhagen criteria. I support the overall philosophy of the report and the replacement of the conditionality of financial assistance, from major changes in the approach of IPA III, by the adoption of the principle of equitable sharing. This is an incentive for more accountability and seriousness for the countries concerned. Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for taking into account the amendments I have tabled on two points, namely the increased participation of civil society, and support in the recipient countries for the deinstitutionalisation of children.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: On behalf of the S&D. Club – Dear Chairman, IPA funding should represent a long-term investment in the European future of the Western Balkans. However, such a future is becoming increasingly uncertain given the political climate in the European Union, the internal challenges facing the Union and the upcoming elections in the European Union. If challenges are overcome soon, western Balkan countries should be given the opportunity to meet the criteria and move closer to membership in the Union. Some of them, like Montenegro, have already come a long way in negotiations. North Macedonia deserved to finally start them. Albania, too.  The IPA must remain a separate instrument with increased resources to foster growth and development and monitor the conditionality of human rights protection and promote the Union's core values. In addition, we need to support capacity building and facilitate the exchange of best practices between beneficiaries and Member States. It stimulates good-seater relationships. While I regret that some good proposals from the Regional Development Committee have not been accepted, I congratulate the rapporteurs and support the proposed text.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, how many times have we called on the Commission to intervene in the way in which the European Union supports Turkey? Our euros have not yet strengthened democracy in Turkey, I think, quite the contrary. The fact that the third pre-accession programme envisages an improved conditionality in the third pre-accession programme, that there is an performance-based approach, will not really impress Mr. Erdoğan's authoritarian regime. I can already put that on a leaf.  The only lesson we can draw from the experience of recent years is that we should not focus on possible enlargement of the Union, but on deepening and on good neighbourliness. Maintaining pre-accession aid as a specific instrument is therefore not a good choice. Supporting IPA priorities such as the rule of law, fundamental rights, good governance and alignment with the EU acquis is also possible within the framework of the global funding structure for the Union's external action.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, since 2007 the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA) has been the main financial instrument supporting reforms in the candidate and potential candidate countries – for example the six Western Balkan countries and Turkey. The most important specific of the current IPA II has been its strategic focus in the face of country strategy papers which represent specific planning documents made for each beneficiary for a seven-year period. In this context I warmly welcome the Commission proposal for establishing IPA III for the next period.  I do believe that IPA over the years has been a very successful and effective instrument when it comes to alignment and coherence between the EU and the candidate countries. Therefore, I fully support the establishment of IPA III with a focus on the rule of law, fundamental rights and migration, EU policies and acquis, socioeconomic development investments for growth and good neighbourly relations. Importantly, the establishment of IPA III has to be done not only in coherence with the priorities of the Western Balkan strategy and EU enhanced engagement with the region, but with increased flexibility and cooperation with Turkey, in the context of possible Turkish accession to the EU in the future.  Last, but not least, IPA III has to become a natural continuity of IPA II, which needs to be implemented fully by all candidate states.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – Madam President, this is an important instrument for pre-accession assistance, which has also proved very necessary in the past.  It is true, however, that IPA III is based on new principles, which of course need to be supported, and this approach to objectives, aimed at distributing resources, which primarily also supports efficiency and, of course, asset economy, may, on the other hand, also have certain pitfalls.  And that is exactly what I would like to draw attention to, because until now, the candidate countries have had instruments in their programmes on the previous experiences of IPA I and IPA II, it will take a great deal of work to adapt to these new principles, and we must be aware of the reality: that the Commission will have to make an intensive contribution to education, to raising awareness, and above all to improving precisely the mechanisms for these instruments to achieve its objective.  And it is also very commendable in this approach that it involves a non-governmental sector that can make an important contribution in the light of its experience of how to make the most efficient use of these resources.  And such an approach also allows for better regional cooperation, and I see a great opportunity in this area, both for the European Commission and for the European Parliament.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, in November 2015, the European Commission set out a medium-term eu enlargement policy strategy. Gradually, all western Balkan countries have been granted candidate status and are currently having a long-term dialogue on the basis of the Copenhagen criteria with a view to being accepted as EU member states. This strategy is intended to strengthen IPA III, which will take effect in 2021, and to maximise the impact of accession negotiations and facilitate the national transition process. For all countries, emphasis is placed on the economic reform agenda, the stability of institutions guaranteeing democracy, the rule of law, human rights and respect for and protection of minorities, the existence of a functioning market economy and the ability to cope with competitive pressure and market forces within the EU. In total, EUR 14.5 billion is proposed for the period 2021-2027 to ensure the financing of pre-access assistance. This amount is comparable – in annual terms – to the Czech Republic's annual contribution to the EU budget. The Programme will seek a wide range of applications in internal policies, security, migration, research and innovation, the environment and climate. Erasmus+ will certainly play an important role. Unfortunately, the whole regulation allows the European Commission to enter the programme in a fundamental way on the basis of not entirely unambiguous criteria. This is also why, on the one hand, the GUE/NGL Group welcomes the whole programme, but on the other hand it cannot unequivocally support it.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I rise for what is most probably my last speech in this place, having watched with amazement the increasing delusion within this House over the past five years. Despite your great and obvious inconsistencies and the fundamental issues facing the EU, you continue in the same direction towards ever closer union, paying scant regard to the changing reality around you.  Take, for example, Turkey. Earlier this month, you passed a report acknowledging the backsliding of basic rights there, yet legislation keeps the door open for their EU membership and a transfer of taxpayers’ money to President Erdoğan’s Turkey, at the very same time that you refuse to acknowledge their incompatibility with your own fundamental values. Yet you criticise Hungary and Poland. Can’t you see your blatant hypocrisy? How much damage must you do before understanding your failure to best represent your citizens’ concerns?

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the critical attention in the debate on guarantees of the rule of law and fundamental rights has been directed at the Turkey case. But I would like to raise another case where we have to weigh up and also judge the pre-accession assistance policy, as well as its effects and shortcomings. How is it possible, in fact, not to see the great beam in the eye of this European Union, what is the very serious situation of discrimination suffered by the Serbian minority, already a victim of the pogroms of 1999 and 2004, in Kosovo? It is nothing more than the possibility of suspending pre-accession assistance to this state, governed, as we all know, by the former leaders of the KLA. The situation here is more serious!  How can we not see the objective irreconcilability of the values affirmed in the European Union with the discriminatory policy, which is now also denounced by a report by the United States State Department, a policy, that of Kosovo, which forces Serbs to live surrounded, victims of violence, deprived of their freedom of movement, the right to live at home and even to receive the help and support of the religious solidarity associations of the Orthodox Church. This is very serious!

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Madam President, as was already heard tonight, the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA) remains the main tool for assisting the profound transformation of those countries aiming to become future members of our European Union. I believe this third generation of the IPA instrument covering the period from 2021 to 2027 will be modernised and streamlined to reflect lessons learned while implementing ongoing IPA programmes. I welcome that, in this report, we advocate for an effective fair share principal, greater coherence, enhanced scrutiny and a stepped—up role for civil society. Last but not least, we demand increased conditionality envisaging a targeted suspension of EU assistance in cases of systemic failures to respect fundamental EU values and backsliding on the Copenhagen criteria. So let me thank the two honourable rapporteurs. This is the right way forward.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, pre-accession assistance plays a central role in the EU’s foreign policy with enlargement countries, and we must continue to put all our efforts into supporting progressive reforms in these countries. Human rights, democracy, the rule of law and the fight against corruption must remain our absolute priorities.  The new funding instrument introduces more flexibility, and this will be particularly key as our complex relationship with Turkey evolves. The deteriorating human rights situation in the country has made it necessary for us to adapt our funding policy, focusing on civil society rather than governmental agencies. Whilst I am sad about the current direction of the country under President Erdoğan’s rule, I am nevertheless convinced that the future of Turkey lies in Europe. My regular contacts with numerous members of Turkish civil society have convinced me that Turkish citizens long for human rights and democracy and to be part of the European family. And when it comes to the Balkans, where I also spend a lot of time, we must continue to be proactive in our support for the institutions, as well as civil society.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Einstein said that the perfection of the means and the confusion of ends seem to characterise our age. This sentence seems to me to be particularly fitting for today's debate. Personally, I do not find it particularly exciting to debate the technical specifications of the IPA III instrument. At the end of the day, we only ask an instrument that it is fit for purpose and that it does well what it was designed for. We therefore ask IPA III to be better suited to the changed political circumstances of the Union and its partners than its processor. I think I can say that, thanks to the excellent work done by Mr Salafranca and Mr Fleckenstein, whom I thank, this is indeed the case with this proposal. It seems to me that very important progress has been made in strengthening Parliament's prerogatives in the design, programming, monitoring and evaluation of the instrument's action and in ensuring political control and democratic control of the European funds used. I also think it is extremely positive, indeed necessary, to strengthen the proposed conditionality and the allocation of funds on the basis of the performance of the countries and clear benchmarks and, above all, the possibility, this time codified in the instrument, of partially or entirely suspending assistance in the event of the candidates being relegated from the Copenhagen criteria or in accordance with the principles of democracy, the rule of law and the rule of law. , human rights and fundamental freedoms. Well, then we really must have the courage to use these benchmarks, to make this instrument stand out, starting with Turkey, on pain of losing our credibility. Ladies and gentlemen, accession policy is and will continue to be one of those that define the EU. Its centrality is also evident in the decision to have a separate instrument, even at a time of unification, such as that proposed by the Neighbourhood Instrument, Development Cooperation and International Cooperation (NDICI). However, once we know that we are going to vote on a good proposal tomorrow, we will need bolder decisions and clearer ideas for the accession policy itself, aspects that have sometimes been lacking in recent years. Thanks to the approval of the new generation of tools we will have a very sharp chisel available. It is in the hand that he will hold it, and therefore also to us, that it will be up to us to use it well and in the most effective way.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, not only should this Parliament stop the dream of some here, the dream that Turkey will one day become a member of the European Union, but also stop the billions of dollars that support this dream. After the so-called coup, 140 000 people were dismissed, of which almost 5 000 were magistrates and prosecutors. 156 000 people were detained, 50 000 ended up in prison, 150 media outlets were shut down, 231 journalists arrested and 2 500 dismissed. If you read that together with the billions of euros invested by the Turkish Presidency for Religious Affairs in almost 200 cities here in the European Union for the creation of mosques, Turkish state mosques in other words, I ask you: stop this so-called pre-accession aid immediately. This support is pointless and accession must never be allowed. (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Rapporteur, question on the 'blue card' procedure. Mr Annemans, have you not heard what we are discussing today? We decided a few weeks ago that we want the Council to suspend the accession talks. We have said that we want to focus on the civilian population as far as resources for Turkey are concerned. With IPA III, we have an instrument where we can say that if it does not work, there is also less money. In this respect, this is working in the right direction. Why do you tell you about the other day? It was superfluous. Do you agree with me?

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: "blue card" answer. Mr Fleckenstein, with all due respect, but in any case this debate takes place in the context of a concept that I do not believe in. Turkey is not a European country, it never will be. I am not calling for a war against Turkey either, I am asking for good neighbourliness with Turkey. I am simply asking for the dream of Turkey's accession, the integration of Turkey as a Member State of the European Union, to be let go. That's all. So we are on a very different level. You're still trying to make it. I don't see that as possible.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank and show my appreciation to all the rapporteurs for having prepared a very good report.  The EU needs to be focused on investing in programmes and projects related to the rule of law, the functioning of democratic institutions and respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, including freedom of expression and of the media. In order to achieve these goals, it is crucial to cooperate with governments, but also to actively support civil society. We need to use our financial support in the region wisely. We are the biggest donor and trading partner of all the countries of the region. We invest in infrastructure, energy networks, environment and agriculture in the Western Balkans. We should expect that the countries will make serious commitments to reforms and to upholding the fundamental values.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, firstly my congratulations to both the rapporteurs for their excellent work. Whilst I welcome the Commission’s overall plans to increase investment in EU external action in the new MFF round, I’m a little sceptical about further increasing IPA funds. As part of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET), I’ve had the opportunity to join missions to pre-accession states. The issue that has struck me whenever I have visited has been the limited absorption capacity for funding in some of these states. Therefore, my questions to the Commission are, firstly – Commissioner Hahn, I hope you’re listening – how is DG NEAR, in this case also IPA III, taking the absorption capacity of accession countries into account?  Secondly, as we’ve just heard, Parliament voted to suspend accession negotiations with Turkey. Given that Turkey is by far the largest IPA beneficiary, how will the suspension of talks affect IPA disbursements? And thirdly, in contrast to other accession countries, public perception of EU in Serbia is far from enthusiastic. Instead, Russian and Chinese investments are greatly overestimated. Before committing more funding, how do we, first of all, ensure clear visibility for the EU’s engagement in Serbia?

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am addressing the Albanian authorities. We cannot accept, we cannot see that, on the one hand, Europe provides good neighbourly and pre-accession resources and, on the other hand, there may be families in Albania, Albanian families, threatening our fellow citizens. We cannot see extortion, we cannot see threats, and I refer to the threats made in recent days by an Albanian family to Francesco Sicignano, who shot and killed an Albanian thief in Vaprio D'Adda. So, the family lost an Albanian thief and today that family plans to extort resources and money from Sicignano or even threaten it. We call on the Albanian authorities to intervene in these statements and on this crime and we make it clear once and for all that from today, as you can see in this sign: 'Beware, legitimate defence is in force!' that is, from today we have a State in Italy that is with the citizen between the thief and the citizen; between the thief and the decent citizen, the State chooses the good citizen.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – Madam President- Commissioner, Dear Colleagues, we are using the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance to help candidate countries and potential candidate countries on the road to european union membership. With this instrument, the Union seeks to improve, especially in respect of human rights, democracy and the rule of law.
