I am one of those who sees the membership of the Western Balkan countries as an urgent step in ensuring peace on the European continent. The European project will not be completed until countries that are historically and geographically part of Europe have become members of the European Union. This funding also aims to prepare the beneficiary countries for successful participation in the Cohesion Policy of the European Union after its annexation. One of the most important areas in which the instrument needs to focus is the building of institutions, the prevention of corruption within state institutions and the increase in their effectiveness is crucial in building citizens' trust

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank both rapporteurs for their excellent work. Pre-accession assistance – billions of euros – is at the same time an investment in the future of the EU, making Europe safer and more prosperous by supporting the stability and prosperity of our closest neighbours and contributing to their EU accession process. Enlargement policy gives a strong push to economic integration with the EU, while agreements with the enlargement countries have liberalised trade for almost all goods. IPA III is the instrument which supports applicant countries in the Western Balkans and Turkey in implementing reforms, fighting corruption, fostering economic development and the functioning of a market economy, as well as improving the investment climate. However, while supporting EU neighbours and their accession process, the conditionality of IPA III assistance should also be strengthened. A possibility of suspending pre—accession assistance in cases of breaches of the principles of democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights should be clear and send a strong signal to those countries.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Madam President, honourable Commissioner Hahn, dear colleagues, taking note of the challenging times that the candidate countries are going through, the European Union should improve its efforts in prioritising key areas for its funding.  Enhancing support to candidate countries in implementing measures that focus on institutional resilience and security-building are of key importance. In addition, the most visible way to success for this founding mechanism is to embrace a strategic plan of promotion and communication.  Therefore, I stress in my amendments that only by increasing the visibility of the instrument, both within the European Union as well as in the candidate countries, we can optimise the European Union’s main instrument for peace and stability in the enlargement area.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I think that countries that are currently seeking to join the European Union really need our help. They should feel it, we are kind of following up on the debate that was in the previous point, that is, the European Neighbourhood Policy.  I see it as essential here that financial pre-access support to countries is an incentive. To really lead to support for legislative reforms in these states. At the same time, I must point out that there is also a good proposal to strengthen the role of the European Parliament as a directly elected body, which will actually increase the use of the procedure in delegated acts. I really appreciate that.  I would also like to comment specifically on Turkey's role in the pre-accession assistance. I would like the people of Turkey to feel union support. However, Turkey today, in my opinion, is not ready to join the European Union. Not only the Member States are aware of this, but I think that the Government of Turkey is also aware of this. There needs to be a dialogue with Turkey, but there are fundamental violations of our democratic values, and I think that is a clear answer to whether Turkey is ready or not.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Then I give the floor to Commissioner Hahn. I hope you have noticed that at least Mrs Gill asked you questions.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank not only Ms Gill, but also some other comments that I would like to refer to. First of all, I would like to thank you for this discussion. My take-away from the discussion is that we have many areas of agreement, and we look forward to continue working constructively. There is broad agreement that key parameters should be preserved of our work with the enlargement countries.  The ‘fundamentals first’ approach, linking the rule of law and fundamental rights with the two other crucial areas of the accession process – economic governance and reforms, the strengthening of democratic institutions and public administration reforms – will continue to be at the helm of our cooperation. The focus on regional cooperation promotes cross-border cooperation with Member States and between Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA) beneficiaries. As we have committed to a European perspective for the Western Balkans, reaffirmed in the Western Balkans Strategy, this regional focus is ever more relevant. At the same time, we are not leaving Turkey behind. Our presence remains important to support, as Mr Fleckenstein said, the democratic process and civil society. This new programming dynamic will help us continue our support to Turkey, but allow us to adapt to the evolving situation and reflect developments in our relations with the country.  I will come to the comments of Ms Maletić and the concerns of Ms Gill. We can combine this, and that’s why I would like to refer to its core update: a more strategic steering towards financial assistance. We set priorities and schemes rather than country envelopes, allowing us to reward performance and progress towards key priorities and to increase flexibility to respond to the evolving needs of the partners in the path towards accession. This means, indeed, if there are absorption problems in the future, we can avoid this by focusing on thematic priorities. Somebody said there might be problems for one country or another in preparing mature projects. In our experience, they are always able to prepare projects but sometimes in this thematic area and sometimes in another one. Of course, we always have to help them to really prepare projects in a way that we can ultimately support financially and assist them to implement them. The idea of thematic priorities is to have a kind of competition, a kind of regatta, amongst the candidate countries and to have the necessary flexibility. So if one country is more focused on rule of law issues, they should have the opportunity to invest more. Others might be more focused on transport, but at the end of the day – which means the accession day – they have to align with all the different elements in order to get quasi—approval from us, the Member States, to accept a new Member State. But in order to arrive there, it’s good to have more flexibility.  There will be, Ms Maletić, an indicative country-specific envelope, but the baseline is indeed the thematic priorities. We are deeply convinced, and this is also true of a vast majority here in the House, that this helps us to be more effective on the ground, to have more flexibility, and to serve our joint interests to prepare the countries thoroughly for hopefully faster accession than is currently probably the case.  So finally, thank you again for helping us to launch this EUR 14.5 billion investment in peace, stability and prosperity for Europe. As I am always saying: either we export stability or we import instability. The concept we have presented will definitely contribute to this aim, and I thank you for your valuable support. I am looking forward to further negotiations on this subject.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I said in my initial speech — and I think Mr Fleckenstein shared it in his speech — that it is important that the principles which inspire this Regulation — which are at the heart of the European Union's action and that we share it with the countries of pre-accession: peace, understanding, harmony and reconciliation — are fundamental elements of our action for the future. So that children born today, for example, in the Western Balkans, have to resort to hemerotecas and history books to learn about the bloody reality that previous generations experienced. I understand, Madam President, that , as Mr Fleckenstein has said as well, the component of this report represents a positive step forward. We hope that tomorrow it can be approved by a large majority in this Parliament and we understand, Commissioner, and I have taken note of the need for coherence between foreign policy and enlargement policy.  In any event, I would like to reiterate our readiness to move forward in this procedure, where there are great coincidences between the Commission and the European Parliament, and we hope that we can all quickly illuminate a new Regulation that will enable us to meet the challenges facing the European Union, not just absorbed into our internal dimension and the problems we have, such as Brexit , but we can deal with these neighbouring countries, these applicant countries, and we can consolidate them into a financial instrument in which, curiously , Mr Preda referred to this a moment ago , we have a whole set of common provisions with the instrument dealing with the financing of neighbourhood policy, development and international cooperation. And I am sure, Commissioner, that we will be able to find formulas that will allow us to quickly adopt a definitive formulation for this Regulation, which can make us face realistically, and in accordance with the principles to which I was referring earlier, the challenges we have in our nearest neighbourhood.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Just three comments at the end. Firstly, Commissioner, we do not want to blur or change competences, but we want there to be a coordination between foreign policy and neighbourhood policy or enlargement policy. I am quite sure that we will find the right wording in our discussions, which also make it clear that there is no fundamental need to change anything. Secondly, I believe that the people of the Western Balkans can be quite satisfied with us. Because it is not only a question of spreading our resources more widely, other areas of responsibility that we have not so far considered, such as climate protection, social affairs, the economy or jobs, but also of being able to do something more together or do less in the way that we have done, depending on the effort on the other hand. : "If you don't do as I want, then there are less", but vice versa: Whoever makes a special effort, who also picks up a bit more speed, must also have a chance to be supported by us a bit better or more. Finally, this IPA III is a clear signal to the people of the Western Balkans: no matter what the next European elections will be, no matter what the majorities in this House will be, the European Parliament will always and in the years to come alongside our friends in the Western Balkans and will endeavour to provide assistance with the almost EUR 15 billion. so that a merger in the European Union can take place as soon as possible. That is what we stand for here, and our successors – so to speak – in the next Parliament will do the same.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, 27 October 2008. Adopted on 13 March 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – For the EU integration of the Western Balkans to be successful, our neighbours must be provided with a credible, tangible accession perspective. The IPA programme is suitable for this: it has enough resources to be directly perceived by citizens. But this will only be the case if the aid is actually used in the public interest. It is therefore essential that the citizens of the candidate countries are able and want to have a say in what the IPA supports and why. At the same time, they are asking the leaders of their countries hard about what they have started with the money. In other words, if we want the south-east of the continent to develop successfully in peace, we cannot allow the Western Balkans to choose Viktor Orban's path. We must not allow citizens to have an accurate view of EU funds; that support in Brussels should be a symbol of waste; that the money may also be stolen by mafia structures moved by politicians. The proposal before us set out appropriate frameworks, and I therefore support it. At the same time, I call on the Commission, when developing the details of IPA III, to consider a broad public consultation on the use of EU funds in the beneficiary countries; establish monitoring committees, including representatives of economic operators and civil society; citizens should always be given the most detailed information possible on the fate of the resources.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Algeria (2019/2627)(RSP)).

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, we have been witnessing a new dynamic in recent weeks, starting on 22 February, with massive nationwide demonstrations in Algeria. These were prompted by the announcement that the incumbent President Bouteflika would run for a fifth mandate in the presidential elections, initially set for 18 April. Since then, demonstrations have continued virtually every day and have grown in size. Besides opposing a new mandate for President Bouteflika, the protesters are demanding a broad reform of Algeria’s political system. Notwithstanding their massive scale, demonstrations have been largely peaceful and the response by the security services has been very measured. Official communication from the government in recent weeks, following the nomination of a new prime minister and deputy prime minister, stresses the necessity to consult and listen to the people with a view to introducing significant reforms. Algeria is a key partner for the European Union. We have important political, economic and people—to—people interests in that country and in that region, where Algeria is a stabilising factor. Our bilateral relations have progressed positively in recent years and we expect that to continue. The High Representative met Minister of State Lamamra in Brussels on 7 March to discuss the situation in the country before his subsequent appointment as deputy prime minister and foreign minister, and I also had the opportunity to talk to him. Demonstrations have so far been peaceful and the response by security services has been measured. This is highly commendable and restraint should continue. As you all know, the situation is currently very fluid. We have been following today’s developments very closely. It’s key now that there should be a positive response to the people’s aspirations: the call for reform of governance, for greater political openness and for more economic and social opportunities, especially for the young. Any process has to be transparent and include all sections of Algerian society. During this period, it’s important to remember that it’s for the Algerians to decide for themselves and among themselves how to make this transition happen.  On the EU side, we should encourage a free, fair and inclusive election of Algeria’s next President to be organised within a reasonable timeframe. The European Union is ready to support the election with technical expertise and will consider fielding an electoral observation mission if, of course, Algeria requests this and if the conditions of the process are met. I count on Parliament’s support in this regard. We should also support the call for a broad reform and transition process. A national conference could be the platform for discussing this as long as it is generally inclusive, representative and designed to ensure political legitimacy. It’s important to make quick progress on this. Citizens’ initiatives for a peaceful solution are also circulating and we understand there is willingness on both sides to define a common way forward. We hope that the consensus crystallises around a road map for the transition, as well as who should be in charge of carrying it out. Whatever process is followed, it must be one that is accepted by Algerians as expressing their will and, as we have stated publicly, the European Union stands ready to accompany Algeria in this process if the Algerians request it. The Union should continue to support Algeria in its socio-economic reforms and the shaping of perspectives that match the desires and ambitions of the population, especially the young. All this will be done in full respect of Algeria’s sovereignty and in a spirit of partnership, as it is defined in our neighbourhood policy concept. The events over the past four weeks have tested political maturity in Algeria and we count on all concerned to face up to the call for change and to bring a peaceful transition to fruition.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, tens of thousands of demonstrators take to the streets of Algiers, Algeria in general, every Friday to express the simple and legitimate demand for a credible political transition and the departure of President Bouteflika, who has been unable to govern the country for a long time. Unfortunately, the authorities do not seem to be listening to the people because their solution to the crisis is not one of them. Extending the term of office of the president, which legally expires on 28 April, and breaking the constitutional framework by suspending the electoral process goes against the demands of Algerians. The national conference proposed by the government was overwhelmingly rejected by the opposition and civil society. In addition, defections are multiplying within the circles of power and the army staff is sending contradictory messages, as we saw this afternoon as well. The international tour of the Algerian authorities, in an attempt to reassure their partners about their ability to manage this crisis, is further proof of the failure of the transition proposed by the Bouteflika family. Algeria is deadlocked. It is a major partner of the European Union, a guarantor of regional stability, stability that could be maintained through respect for the rights and freedoms of Algerians through the establishment of a transparent and inclusive system of governance. Like Algerians, the European Union expects a strong gesture from the government. The illusion of change will not do the trick, it requires a radical break with the current system.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, thank You to Mr Hahn for those words which we share and which we certainly recognise in the peaceful and proud mobilizations of the Algerian people, on the streets for days, and we recognise the need, of course, for a profound change which leads precisely to free and democratic elections within a reasonable time. We absolutely agree to support this phase of transition, to maintain the necessary support for a country like Algeria, with which we have a long tradition of relations and which we absolutely need, closely and with that relationship. We are also proud to have achieved in this last term something that I wanted — a long-term claim — to get a bilateral delegation between the European Union and Algeria in Parliament, which can help and which, of course, we offer the Commission to be able to cooperate in strengthening and offering the Algerian people as soon as possible a democratic and peaceful transition.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Commissioner, there is a deep historical sense of national sovereignty in Algeria. As a result, there is a high sensitivity to any indication of foreign interference in the domestic situation. This factor should take this debate into account, and the Commissioner has also said it. European caution is needed, given the very complex political and social situation algeria now finds itself in after weeks of mass demonstrations.  While a recurrence of the protesters reads "out of the old one cannot make anything new", it remains an exciting question whether the presidential elite, the repressed elites that we must not forget, and also the army itself, are permeated and touched. It is very important for the EU to keep a close track of developments in Algeria. The so-called Arab Spring of 2011 taught us that the continuation of the unrest puts forward groups that have a religious agenda that is at odds with the expectations of the protesters.  As a Protestant, I pray with Algerian Protestants for a peaceful reform process, while at the same time expressing the hope that, as a minority, they will be able to obtain full freedom of faith in public life, because that is a point that absolutely must be raised by the European Union. Freedom of faith for all Algerians, and beware of fundamentalism and a religious agenda in that sense.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Algeria is a country with enormous resources, but managed since its independence by a corrupt military oligarchy under the control of the ruling party — the party-state — exclusive and exclusive. There are two Algerians: the official, which is based on the legitimacy of a distant war of liberation, and the other, the young woman, who is fed up with words and old battles and who lives in hopelessness and unemployment.  Today, chief of staff, General Ahmed Gaid Salah, called for the cessation of the ectoplasmatic disability of the virtual President Buteflika. But let's have no illusions. Power will transiently be in the hands of the President of the Council of the Nation, Abdelkader Ben Salah, but will remain in the hands of the army, of General Ahmed Gaid Salah.  Don't let him confuse us today. Today started yesterday. Last September, when General Salah did the full purge of the Armed Forces, including security services. It was the army preparing its own transition, with the principle of the Prince of Lampedusa, which is that "something must change so that everything remains the same". The point, the difference is that the people have started talking and ran out of time. And, therefore, they have created the fiction that there is a possible change when the reality is that what they are looking for is to stay and perpetuate the the power. But the question is: does military gerontocracy understand that its time has passed and that Algerian society must be opened to true democracy? Algeria is vital for the stability of the Sahel-Saharan area in the south, and our stability in North Africa, in the southern Mediterranean.  This Parliament must send a clear and clear message of support to the people of Algeria in their inevitable and necessary transition. That we understand them, that they are not alone, that we support them and that we support what a better future means for an Algeria that will mean a better future for all.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to greet all the people who have taken to the streets in Algeria, proudly, festively, with undisputed leadership of women, every Friday for weeks. Now, army canes, income and hydrocarbon alien subsidies, and the trauma of a bloody civil war no longer take effect. An entire people has broken fear, shame and submission to seize their destiny. But, once again, we see total silence and some blindness on the part of Brussels. Commissioner, there is a middle way between indifference and interference that Europe must follow: respectful, enthusiastic and fraternal support for a people who are waking up. The EU must finally listen to the demands of the Algerian street and be ready to support its requests for democratic transition, opening up public space and governance based on human rights and the dignity of all. The streets of Algiers, Oran and Constantine must be supported to initiate a true process of democratic transition and avoid a simple false substitution of current power.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, Algerians and Algerians are on the streets, fed up with a political and economic system that has been totalitarian. Under pressure, Buteflika resigned from re-election, postponed the election and opened a transition period. But protesters on the streets demand real change, a government of national unity that invokes elections and drafts a Constitution that guarantees social needs, individual and collective freedoms. They are the largest peaceful protests Algeria has experienced in years. But international silence overwhelms. Algeria is europe's third largest gas supplier and the European Union prioritizes the interests of multinationals and the importation of gas over human rights. Europe must support protests and their claims. From the European Parliament we transfer our support to the legitimate demands of society that demands justice and democracy in Algeria. We have to act.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I understand the seriousness of the situation in Algeria. The protests, thankfully, have so far been peaceful protests with young people taking to the streets because they believe in something different to what the Algerian Government at present is offering. One of the key comments that we see time and time again from people in Algeria is that they desperately want freedom of speech; that they want to be able to express themselves in ways that they’ve not been able to do of late. But the situation is incredibly serious: we’ve got the army chief calling for Bouteflika to be declared unfit to govern. The one point that I want to make specifically today, that has perhaps not been raised yet in this debate, is that freedom of speech must also imply freedom of religion. Freedom of religion is guaranteed under Article 36 of the Algerian Constitution, which states that freedom of religion and creed is inviolable. I want to mention the persecution of religious minorities in Algeria, and specifically Christians, because I’ve met Algerian pastors on two occasions who have come to the European Parliament to express their concerns about how they are being persecuted at present. Algeria has moved from number 42 to number 22 on the world watch list of most persecuting countries of Christians in just one year. We’ve seen churches having been closed, and particularly the EPA – the Église protestante d’Algérie. We have seen the government using various administrative means to close down churches, and we have seen those who have preached on social media put in prison. We’ve seen those who import religious materials put in prison. We’ve seen those who convert to Christianity being persecuted. All I’d ask is that in all of these discussions, in all of these debates, please can we remember that Christians and other religious minorities are being persecuted in Algeria, as these matters are being discussed in the coming days.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, "In the days of France, Algeria was paradise!" Is this quote from a French Algerian supporter? Not at all. It was uttered by one of the major leaders of Algerian independence, Hocine Aït Ahmed, and it is now making even more sense. I hear beautiful words in this Chamber, which is not in for a democratic transition. But what is the European Union doing? What can it do in this process? Algeria is not a member of Europe, at least not yet. For us, any question about Algeria remains the sole responsibility of the Algerian people who wanted independence, but whose leaders have proved incapable of assuming it for 57 years. As such, the place of those who demonstrate, especially in Paris and elsewhere on current events, should be in Algeria and nowhere else. Certainly, the mummy Bouteflika who, during the time of his lucidity, insulted the French and spit perpetually on France, while coming to get treatment at our home at the expense of our taxpayers, arouses in us no sympathy.  So we, for our part, retain only one imperative: the current events must not under any circumstances justify the slightest additional immigration.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we have been following with concern the latest developments in Algeria: the suspension of presidential elections or the request for disqualification made by the Chief of Staff for the President of the Republic. Hence the importance of this process of transition, which brings the Algerian people to the floor and responds to the legitimate aspirations of democracy and freedom, can be done in an orderly manner, which does not lead to a power vacuum and leads us to mistakes that have been made in other countries of the region or to bad experiences , terrible experiences, that this country has lived. It is important that there be an inclusive dialogue, with the participation of political parties and civil society, that gives a legitimate channel of expression to all these groups and that in a credible way it can give the algerian people back to the floor through a process of free and internationally accompanying elections. I hope, Commissioner, that the European Union, which is a positive partner of Algeria, will be able to accompany this process and can sustain those aspirations for freedom which we are seeing peacefully demonstrated on the Algerian streets.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, demonstrations in Algeria are constantly being repeated: these are gigantic and peaceful demonstrations, leaving no doubt about the thinking of most Algerians. The protests, initially directed against the fifth term of office to which Bouteflika aspired, now call for a rapid end to the transition phase. In essence, what we want to avoid is that we move from a call for elections without Bouteflika to a stay in Bouteflika without elections. That is why it is essential for us to show the path of a reasonable transition, because it is absolutely important that we can ensure that Algeria has a framework of stability in which democracy, rights and reforms are central elements. I hope that the activation of Article 102 of the Algerian Constitution will be a first step, even if it is not enough. Finally, in this direction, it is necessary for the European Union and its foreign policy to deal with this country with greater determination, because the future of the whole region also depends on its balanced transition.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The attention we attach to the events in Algeria is completely understandable. This is not only a country geographically close to Europe, but we also all remember the events of the 1990s: this previous democratic experiment, which resulted in the Islamic Salvation Front winning elections, a bloody civil war that not only affected Europeans on Algerian territory but spilled over beyond Algeria's borders into Europe. In this context, although I am in opposition to this European Commission, I applaud Commissioner Hahn's statement that he should look with great peace, patience, caution at the events and the growing conflict in Algeria. Yes, it is in Europe's interest to resolve this conflict peacefully, and in any case, we cannot make the mistakes that we made in neighbouring Libya or in other countries during the Arab Spring.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, 'the heart of Algeria is beating again', this is one of the slogans that can be read on the Algerian streets for more than a month. I would like to pay tribute to the Algerian people for their courage and determination. The organization of these peaceful and exemplary demonstrations commands the admiration of all. Such mobilization of all generations and in all regions deserves more than a simple reform of the regime, it must change. Clearly, this transition cannot be led by those who have led the country into such a situation. The European Union must live up to this challenge and not give the Algerian people the impression that we have not understood the depth of their aspirations. "The future belongs to us" is another slogan carried by the protesters. The Algerian people demonstrate this every day with strength and dignity in their fight for a free and democratic Algeria, it is a beautiful message of hope for Algerian youth.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, today we talked about Algeria after weeks when, every Friday, millions of Algerians were outraged and in protest at the social, political and economic situation in the country. Claiming that there was not a fifth term of President Buteflika, but not only by claiming that, but calling for the longing for the dreams and hopes of a generation of Algerians who today number 45% of the population, under the age of twenty-five who have been excluded from any process of progress and economic growth in the country.  That is why what we are calling on the Government and the institutions that make up the Algerian regime today, and the European Union as a whole, is that, as a result of this crisis, we will be able to respect, listen and act. Respect the millions of peaceful protesters. Listen to legitimate demands for change, reform, freedoms and rights. And act to respond and exit a regime that needs democratic transformations and that responds to the longings of the Algerian people.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, Algeria is a very important country for the European Union and its Member States and is in a pivotal moment. It is a country that has gone through a very long and difficult period in the 1990s, when the Islamist and terrorist challenge resulted in many dead. Now another stage is closed, the one presided over by Buteflika, who has finally given up being re-elected for the fifth time. This opens up a new political moment. Algeria enters a transitional phase, and this process, in my view, should be agile in time and very inclusive in its approach; 'inclusive' is the word you have repeated, Commissioner, and I make it mine. The Algerian people have the opportunity for change after a long period; a change that is being called for from the streets, through peaceful popular demonstrations and protests, I would also like to highlight this. Algerians do not want confrontation or violence, nor destabilize the country. I'm sure they don't want to travel back in time either, because it's about winning the future. And the European Union must be very attentive to this process. We must be willing to accompany the Algerians in this period of change, offering our cooperation if they wish to count on us. It is up to the Algerian people, who, in a dialogueed, inclusive, democratic and peaceful manner, have to decide their future.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Much has already been said about Algeria itself. Let me talk briefly about the European Union. For years, I have been saying that Syria will not be the last country where we, as the European Union, have failed. Algeria will come to us. There, a greedy head of state holds his trembling hand on the lid of the pressure cooker, and one day the pot will explode. That day is here now, and what are we doing? We are watching. Syria has almost 20 million inhabitants, Algeria 40 million. You don't want to imagine what happens when a civil war flares up there.  If eight years ago we had had a strong, common, self-confident foreign policy, and if we had been diplomatically involved, we could have saved ourselves and the people of Syria a great deal. That is why I appeal to Berlin, Paris, Rome, Stockholm and yes, to Vienna and to all the other Heads of State or Government: we need a strong Europe! This can only be done if the principle of unanimity in foreign policy is brought to an end. The people of Algeria and here in Europe will thank us.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the whole debate, in which we have clearly defined our political position. I'm applying to her. The democratisation process in Algeria must be supported, everything must be clearly done to prevent President Buteflika from running and leaving office. On the other hand, everything must be done to ensure that there is no violence and no civil war in Algeria, where the demonstrations are still taking place peacefully. We should offer clear assistance to Algeria in organising presidential elections, send a mission and be a partner in so that these elections are conducted as inclusively, freely as possible, and that it is a clear president who will gain not only legality but also legitimacy in elections.  It is necessary to be cautious, here I subscribe to what some colleagues have said, because the situation can get worse, there may be violence, but the road to democratisation must not be stopped in Algeria.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, Europe, which washes its hands of the Western Sahara conflict where some of its members have historical responsibilities, cannot pretend that it does not see what is happening in Algeria, which is so important to all of us. This Europe has to see that the Algerian people are taking to the streets peacefully against a fifth term for the Mummy Bouteflika, against military gerontocracy, for genuine democratic reforms, and we cannot remain silent and pretend that we do not see, we must clearly stand by the Algerian people by saying that we support them jointly in the demands of democratic reforms. The signs that Europe gives can be decisive so that we do not fall there in bloodbaths as we have seen in other Arab Spring countries in recent years. We absolutely have to support the Algerian people, the young Algerian people in their demand for inclusiveness, for job creation. The prosperity of the Algerian people has to do with our prosperity, just as their security and democracy have to do with ours.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, although the social challenge initiated on 22 February caused President Abdelaziz Bouteflika to give up his candidacy for the fifth time, the fact is that the subsequent suspension of the electoral act scheduled for 18 April in practice represents an extension of , in fact, of his mandate and millions of people remain on the streets in protest against this manifestly unconstitutional dilatory maneuver. If Article 102 of the Constitution is activated, which provides for the removal of the president, as some military personnel now suggest, and without autonomous political parties, the risks of a power vacuum, combined with the serious economic crisis that has plagued the country since 2014, will destabilise the entire region and have geostrategic consequences for Europe as well, especially with regard to the fight against regular immigration , combating terrorism and the supply of hydrocarbons. It is therefore important that the European Union, within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy, calls on the Algerian authorities to guarantee the right of peaceful expression and to support all efforts to hold free elections in the shortest possible space, preventing the current uncertainty from leading to another episode of the Arab Spring fiasco.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, we will continue to monitor all developments in Algeria, which is a key partner to our south. As I said, we hope that the situation remains peaceful and we believe it’s vital that the legitimate aspirations of the Algerian people are addressed.  At the same time, I believe we can agree that the best thing we can do right now is not to interfere in an internal process. We should be ready to provide support to the consensus and the ensuing process when the moment is ripe, while following closely the various steps on the way and remembering that it’s for the Algerians to decide for themselves and among themselves how to make this transition happen. Allow me therefore to express my appreciation for your attention and support in giving this important file the considered approach it deserves, and to stay vigilant on this subject.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. – According to this year's World Watch List drawn up by Open Doors, Algeria has fallen by up to 20 places – from 42nd place to 22nd place – in the list of countries where Christians are most persecuted. The primary source of persecution stems from intolerance between relatives and neighbors. It is worrying, however, that this pressure against Christians is also increasing on the part of the state through laws and bureaucratic obstructions restricting freedom of religion, which are directed primarily at Protestant churches. Since November 2017, government authorities have been closing churches and not granting permits for religious activities and worship, pastors are accused of pro-Greenism and forced to provide regular reports, the import of Christian books and materials is limited, and Christians are detained and condemned only for the sake of practicing their faith. We must therefore urge the Algerian Government to guarantee freedom of religion and to abolish all charges and punishments imposed on Christians simply because of the practice of their faith.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the five-year illegal occupation of Crimea by the Russian Federation (2019/2671(SDR))

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, five years ago the Russian Federation illegally annexed the autonomous Republic of Crimea and the City of Sevastopol. Five years on, the European Union remains steadfast in its support for Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity. We do not, and we will not, recognise this violation of international law. We are unwavering in our non-recognition policy. The deterioration of the security situation in the Black Sea region is a constant source of concern, with an increasing militarisation of the Crimean Peninsula. The unjustified use of force by Russia in the Kerch Strait last November, in itself another consequence of the illegal annexation, is a reminder of its negative impact on regional stability. The Union expects Russia to release unconditionally and without further delay the Ukrainian crew members and vessels that were captured on that day. Russia should ensure respect of their right to legal representation and access by consular authorities. We also expect Russia to provide them with appropriate medical treatment.  This unacceptable situation also stems from the construction of the Kerch Bridge without Ukraine’s consent. Some time ago, Russia started to apply an inspection regime that limits the navigation through the Kerch Strait to, and from, Ukraine ports and leads to significant delays. Hundreds of vessels flying Ukraine’s flag and international flags, including those of EU Member States, have suffered from controls which can last several days. We expect Russia to ensure unhindered and free passage of all ships through the Kerch Strait, to and from the Azov Sea, in accordance with international law.  We welcome Ukraine’s approach to seeking justice, such as the ongoing case under UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. In addition to the negative consequences of the illegal annexation and the security situation in the region, we deplore systematic restrictions of fundamental freedoms and violations of human rights in the peninsula, notably the rights of the Crimean Tatars, which have been seriously violated. Their media outlets have also been shut down; the activities of the Mejlis, their self-governing body, have been banned; and the leaders and members of their community have been persecuted.  We will continue to call for the immediate and unconditional release of Oleh Sentsov, who received the Sakharov Prize last year and whose picture outside the European Parliament reminds the people who walk by every day about his dedication.  We also call for the release of many others, such as Edem Bekirov, Oleksandr Kolchenko, Mykola Semena, Volodymyr Balukh and Emir—Usein Kuku, who have been detained and sentenced by Russia in breach of international law. We call for all human rights violations to be investigated and for international human rights actors to have unfettered access to the Crimean Peninsula. In addition to cases related to the Crimean Peninsula, we unfortunately continue to see examples of illegally-detained Ukrainian citizens being convicted in Russia. Most recently, Pavlo Hryb was sentenced to six years imprisonment, and we also expect him to be released. We will also take every opportunity to raise individual cases publicly and bilaterally with our Russian interlocutors.  Faced with Russia’s violations of international law, Ukraine is not alone. We have stood by our associated partner and continue to do so. We condemned the construction of the Kerch Bridge and pointed to the deterioration of the security situation in the Black Sea and the Azov Sea, including in this forum last October.  Our position on the illegal annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol has been reiterated on many occasions, most recently in the High Representative’s declaration on behalf of the European Union on 17 March. She also publicly addressed this issue during the last Foreign Affairs Council. We also have to take measures to show Russia that its actions have a cost.  Lastly, on 15 March, we added to our list of restrictive measures eight Russian individuals who were involved in the use of force at the Kerch Strait in November. The publication of this decision was made in parallel with similar announcements made by our transatlantic partners in a demonstration of our continued unity.  We have also identified possible areas for further EU support for the Ukrainian regions severely affected by the Russian inspection regime in the Azov Sea. We are particularly looking into developing railway and road connections in the area, training centres in some Ukrainian cities around the Azov Sea, and support for small- and medium-sized enterprises aiming to diversify the business sector and the industrial structure of this region, for the time being heavily depending on steel production.  These violations of international law are happening on our very continent and we, as the European Union, have no doubt about where we stand. We stand on the side of international law. We stand on the side of the basic principle that borders must not be changed by force, and most importantly we stand on the side of the people of Ukraine. In these years we have invested in Ukraine more than in any other country in the world, and Ukraine knows that our support is here to stay.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very I would like to thank Mr Hahn for his contribution on this issue and for his clarity. In Helsinki, as Europeans, we laid out two principles: the sovereignty of a country, free to decide with whom to form coalitions, conclude treaties, and the second point is the inviolability of borders, which can never be changed unilaterally.  And Russia has violated both principles. It has occupied part of another country, is waging war with another part. And in the Sea of Azov – Mr Hahn, as you have pointed out – there is also an attempt to change things under international law, which is unacceptable. And I think we have to be clear here! This was the first violation of international law in these areas since 1945! This must be clearly stated. And it must not become the practice of the Europe of the 21st century that such violations of international law are accepted. For this reason, I believe it must be clear that we are sticking to the sanctions, but that we are open to Russia getting back into a good conversation, for mutual interest, especially for Russia's interest, if international law is restored.  I believe that, five years after that, five years after that the people of Ukraine voted by a large majority in favour of a single Ukraine in a referendum in the 1990s, that the people of Ukraine, in all the elections – in all the free elections that took place in Ukraine – were in favour of a European solution, a path to Europe, and that there is therefore no legitimacy for Russia from the people's level, and that there is therefore no legitimacy for Russia from the people's mind. to make claims from it, old historical or for the reason that one thinks that population has been oppressed. The only ones who have been oppressed are those who have also been oppressed by Stalin, the Crimean Tatars. And I think we have to keep that in mind. This must be made public awareness of this in order to ensure that international law remains its place in Europe.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the illegal and fortly occupation of Crimea by the Russian Federation clearly violates the 1994 International Treaty on the Denuclearisation of Ukraine. It violates the rights of the Ukrainian people, it violates, in particular, the rights of the indigenous Tatar people.  Putin has set up a Russia that disrespects international law, not even the Un Charter respects, and uses Crimea in an expansionist campaign to deceit democracy in neighboring countries and with strategic partnerships with the European Union, as is the case with Georgia, which also has territories illegally occupied by Russia. You don't lose the opportunity to fuel the war in the Donbass, to escalate tensions in the Black Sea, as seen in the Sea of Azov and the Kerch Strait, to make clandestine incursions into the Baltic countries and to weaken and destroy the European Union itself, we must face it! Political declarations are not enough, and sanctions are not even enough. We have to understand, in addition to being firmly on the side of Ukraine, only by being militarily empowered is that in the European Union too we can live up to the strategic defence responsibilities of Europe, the citizens, all our Member States, because the armed conflict is real, it can spread and can even fall within a nuclear catastrophe.

name: Marek JUREK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The five years that have passed since the annexation of Crimea are five years of disgrace to our politics. Russia's security has not suffered in the slightest since then. Europe could not even afford to halt the construction of Nord Stream 2. And let us remember that while the first Nord Stream strand was intended to isolate the Baltic States and Poland, Nord Stream 2 is directly geared towards Ukraine's energy isolation. Only symbolic personal sanctions were supposed to be a manifestation of our disapproval, but strategic balance was in no way restored. This whole situation shows that the European Union's aspirations to build a common security and defence policy are unfounded. Yes, the institutions need to be added to politics, and unfortunately we do not have a policy of solidarity in this area. Only empty gestures remain.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, it has been five years since the illegal occupation of Crimea, and during those five years our response has not been loud enough. Why? I don’t know – because of our need for Russian gas? Because of our fear of Russia? I don’t know why, but I do know that it poses a real question here. How would we react if it happened in the EU? Can my distinguished colleagues from the Baltic states be 100% assured that we will protect them if they are attacked? This is exactly where the Kremlin wants us to be – in this position of starting to doubt our possibility to defend ourselves – provoking us, playing games with us, trying to split us and weaken our response. So let me spell out the facts. Since many years ago, we have seen an increasingly aggressive Russia. Georgia, eastern Ukraine and Crimea are showing us without any uncertainty that the Russian Federation is having no second thoughts about changing the borders in Europe by other means than peaceful if they can. And that leaves us with the just one possibility: we must act together and with firmness, because all other answers – negotiation appeasement, some kind of compromise – will be perceived in the Kremlin as a weakness. So it is time to send a loud and clear message: enough is enough. This has gone too far already, and we have to start working on putting pressure on Russia to leave the occupied territories, both in Georgia in eastern Ukraine and in Crimea.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I’m thankful that the Commission and the High Representative have expressed such a clear condemnation of the illegal occupation of Crimea. It’s very important that, five years after this illegal annexation, we speak about the situation openly, because many people have had their rights suppressed and many people feel abandoned and left alone. So we have to recognise the systematic repression and persecution of political, civil and human rights which have taken place since the illegal occupation and annexation. We have a special duty to remember Oleg Sentsov, because he is our Sakharov laureate. We have to join the Commission and the High Representative in the demand for the unconditional release of the political prisoners. We have to condemn also the extremism laws which have taken place since the annexation, which have brought very serious restrictions to freedom of expression in Crimea.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the five years of what you call the occupation of Crimea are being debated here today, a definition which lawyers such as Professor Reinhard Merkel, a member of the German Ethics Council, have questioned for years.  For you, the story begins with Crimea; for whom we have memory, it starts with the Maidan and the interferences of some parties in this House in that process. But the truth is, it starts much further back. It is a pity that there is no talk here this week of NATO's twenty years of aggression in Yugoslavia. How international law was then broken; exactly the same as what some accuse Russia today. Many mistakes have been made during and after that: the policy of sanctions against Russia and the logical response, which has caused the loss of thousands of jobs in Spain or Italy. Also attempts to gag europe's press, appealing to the fight against Russian propaganda, or the normalization of neo-Nazi groups and the historical revisionism of anti-Semitic collaborators, such as Stepán Bandera or Román Shujévich.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what you refuse to the Crimeans, you give to the Kosovars.  You denounce the illegal occupation of Crimea but you condone the illegal occupation of Kosovo. You denounce the Russians but you approve of NATO's illegal war against Yugoslavia, whose sad 20th anniversary we are commemorating today. You denounce the referendum in Crimea but you support the illegal declaration of independence of Kosovo, a mafia entity, in 2008, which violated Security Council Resolution 1244. You preach the rule of law but you support the putschist power in Kiev, which resulted from a violent coup d'état - the Maidan - which was remotely controlled by the United States. Unlike Kosovo and the Maidan, not a single shot was fired in Crimea. What you hate about the Crimeans is their patriotic will to reintegrate their historic homeland, Russia. By denying them this right, you are doing like the Soviet dictator Khrushchev who, with the stroke of an illegal pen, also gave Crimea to the Soviet Republic of Ukraine. Your stateless policy is that of the Bolsheviks of 1954! (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Colleague, I have been waiting to see what you will do, especially in relation to the fact that we have an office close to us and constantly someone from your office comes out and speaks Russian on the phone.  But I wanted to ask: Do you really see your speech as objective in a situation where the first Czech-Russian bank contributed EUR 10 million to the campaign of Marie Le Pen, your president? Are you really objective and see the violation of the 1994 Budapest Memorandum as a violation of international law?

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: answer 'blue card'. "Dear colleague, I will not respond to these low polemics. There have been investigations, so all this has been done on an absolutely regular basis, at interest rates which, moreover, are 6%, well above the interest rates that a European bank would give. What is scandalous is that in Europe, a party, the main opposition party, does not find any bank to finance it. That's outrageous, and these are Bolshevik methods! (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation).

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: 'blue card' question. Mr Schaffhauser, I have a question because we have seen you here for the last five years to really passionately support all the positions of the Kremlin.  Has there been a position of Mr. Putin and his regime in the last five years that you have not supported? Do you disagree? Tell us something, give us a little detail, or are you really 120% with Mr Putin and the Kremlin? Tell us the truth.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: answer 'blue card'. "Dear Colleague, the policy I support is the policy of France. I'm sorry, look at France's position during its history! Look at how General de Gaulle was the first to visit Stalin's Russia! Look at how all our heads of state have had special relations with Russia! Even look at what President Macron is doing, despite sometimes a difficult positioning! France's policy has always been a policy of balance, independence and sovereignty. And I hope it will remain so!

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, the annexation of Crimea by force five years, blatantly violating the international order, can only be compared to the Anschluss of Austria by Hitler 81 years ago. National Anschluss paved the way for further aggression, culminating in the Second World War. Yes, the Russian aggression has been condemned and sanctions established, but hesitations and differences of opinion have weakened their credibility and impact. The reaction by the EU to new Russian aggression in the Azov Sea last November happened only four months later and targeted eight persons, one for every three Ukrainian seamen arrested by Russians. Ukraine is not an isolated case. The European Parliament resolution on Russia two weeks ago stresses that Russia’s deliberate breaking of international rules poses an imminent threat to Russia’s neighbours in all parts of Europe. There can be no return to business as usual until the Kremlin fully and unconditionally restores the territorial integrity of Europe.  (Applause)

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – Mr President, five years after Russia's illegal occupation of Crimea, we cannot leave here in this Parliament once again to express our deep protest and condemn this illegitimate attitude on the part of Russia. And we cannot fail to draw attention to the absolutely bellicose behaviour that has been carried out by this country in the Kerch Strait and the Sea d'Azov, as well as the increasing militarisation in the Black Sea that harms the whole region. There can be no doubt about this. There is, however, one issue that we must also ask very clearly: today's Russia is not the Soviet Union. I've been deeply, and deeply, anti-Soviet. Russia must be distinguished from the Soviet Union. Our position is not based on an anti-Russian attitude by nature, our position is only a critical position towards an autocratic regime which calls into question fundamental principles and rights which are fundamental principles and rights that this European Union has an obligation to defend.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for your strong statement. Crimea is a stolen peninsula. In March 2014, for the first time since The Second World War, a European country invaded and annexed territory. The green men did not wear badges and signs, but they were Russian soldiers.  Crimea has been disowned by Ukraine after a carefully planned military operation. Mr. Schaffhauser, Russia violated 47 multilateral and bilateral agreements, such as the 1945 UN Charter, the Helsinki Final Act of 1975, the Budapest Memorandum of 1994. With the annexation also began the repression, especially against Crimean Tatars. The stolen peninsula, once a tourist attraction, is one major military base. The new Kerch Bridge, the aggression in the sea of Azov: the Russian provocations do not stop.  Respect for international law is the foundation of our security structure. The day we stop condemning, the day we relax our sanctions, we question that right ourselves and put our own security at risk. I hope we'll never let that happen.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, Russian illegal occupation of Crimea is jeopardising international peace. We’ve already heard. It is a major flashpoint that could lead to conflict and just as easily escalate into an international one. What particularly concerns me is that, under the Russian occupation, the people of Crimea have become increasingly isolated and human rights and economic concerns have deteriorated rapidly. Whilst this House has repeatedly called for the territorial integrity of Ukraine to be restored, Russia has blatantly flouted these calls by building bridges and attacking Ukrainian ships in the Sea of Azov. It is not enough for us to merely award the Sakharov Prize to those who, like Oleg Sentsov, have been fighting this repression. No, it is important that we instead send a strong message to Russia that ignoring international law has consequences, whilst also providing more help to Ukraine for their security. My question to the Commissioner is this: how do we increase this pressure on Russia? Do you believe you can get Member States to sing from the same hymn sheet and support you in what you said earlier, Commissioner Hahn?

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President, for five years already the Russian Federation has been occupying Crimea, and the indigenous people of this peninsula – the Crimean Tatars – perishing most. This is the third wave of violations against this community. The first happened in 1783, with the massive deportation of Crimean Tatars by the Tsarist regime. Then in 1945, Josef Stalin once more deported the indigenous people of Crimea en masse. Now they are a minority in the peninsula, perishing in huge waves of violations, with disappearing children, with political prisoners, with arrests and suffering, and with violations of human rights. Now this year, Crimean Tatars – together with the whole of Ukraine and hopefully the whole international community – commemorate the 75th anniversary of the last deportation. I am grateful for your statement, Commissioner. I echo your appeals to free political prisoners and to give the territory to Ukraine.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, five years after the illegal annexation of the Crimean Peninsula to the Russian Federation, I join my voice with those who condemn this blatant violation of international law. The continuing occupation of the peninsula seriously undermines the pre—eminence of the rule of law in international relations. I have already denounced in this House the appalling consequences this situation has had on cultural heritage in Crimea, which continues to be destroyed on the ground with the loss of significant historical sites. Meanwhile, human rights defenders, political opponents, artists and minorities continue to be persecuted in Russia and in the occupied territories. Because the EU has been firm and consistent in refusing to recognise the illegal annexation of Crimea, Russian agents have been trying to hijack European politics through financing far-right parties and influencing elections and referendums. We must not give way but must continue to stand by international law – including human rights law – in our relations with Russia and with every other country.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I am very glad that this debate has clearly shown that we have a dominant majority and a clear view that the occupation of Crimea is an illegal act, that it violates international law, that Russia continues its illegal activities with its military provocations, especially in the Sea of Azov.  I am also very glad that some of us have recalled the very difficult situation of the various minorities in Crimea itself. The situation there is very dissuased, it is occupied territory and it has already fallen here several times, especially the Crimean Tatars are very strongly discriminated against. There is a severe repression of political opponents, of human rights activists, of independent journalists. This means, this is also an aspect to be mentioned, not only violations of international law, but Russia's own behaviour towards the people of Crimea, who have retained some loyalty to Ukraine or want to live an autonomous life independently of the Russian model. It is therefore a good thing that we are commemorating the anniversary today, and it is clear that sanctions against Russia cannot be lifted.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, five years after the illegal annexation of Crimea, purges continue in public services, arbitrary arrests and human rights violations, especially against tatars, and despite international condemnations and sanctions, the Kremlin continues to push its projects to accelerate the integration of the peninsula, including its military presence. The question is: how many more anniversaies of the sadly so-called Crimean Spring will we have to refer here until Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity are replaced and the Minsk agreements respected? The Union must not only renew the economic sanctions in force by the end of next July, but also be able to put an end to the scandalous Russian money laundering, including by European state banks, in the European banking system. This involves the courage, ignoring external pressures, to blacklist Russia on money laundering and to bring infringement proceedings against states that have not yet transposed the fourth Money Laundering Directive. The Union cannot impose a sanctioning regime against Russian expansionism and, at the same time, allow European banks to provide it with the financial oxygen to proceed.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, First of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn for his clear approach. Clear words against the illegal situation in Crimea. Russia celebrated the fifth anniversary of the annexation of Crimea, but we recall it as an ongoing injustice and occupation, and we must not let up in our position. Crimea under international law belongs to Ukraine, under an international treaty signed by the Russian Federation itself. Today is exactly five years since the UN General Assembly invalidate the Russian referendum in Crimea and confirmed the peninsula's jurisdiction to Ukraine. But it is not only about international law, but also about how the Russian regime behaves in Crimea, how it tramples on the human rights of Ukrainians, Tatars, there are unjustified detentions, cases of torture.  Russia is trying to give the impression that the fate of Crimea is sealed, but we simply must not let up, we must not weaken ourselves, because the fate of Crimea clearly shows the meaning of the European Union. It still shows how important it is for us to be able to live freely.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Mr President, in June 2014, the European Union adopted sanctions targeting Russian energy sources, defence and the financial sector. Economic sanctions cost Russia billions of euros a year. Already in March 2014, visa restrictions were imposed on a number of Russian citizens. While these personal sanctions will not affect Russia's economy and changes in gas and oil prices as much as economic sanctions, they could affect decisive processes on russia's political scene. The Kremlin has used the Russian parliament for its goals. Before the invasion of Ukraine, he voted by the upper house of the Russian Parliament to enter Ukraine. Members of the upper house confirmed Vladimir Putin's occupation of Ukraine. Unanimously. I recommend that the High Representative also instify personal sanctions, up to a total ban on members of the upper house of the Russian Parliament entering the Territory of the European Union.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, five years of occupation of Crimea is five years of unprecedented violations of international law. It is not just a question of border invincibility, human rights are massively violated in Crimea. There are different categories of citizens, and crimean Tatars, for example, are actually lawless citizens who have no rights.  Ukraine needs our help. I fully support Ukraine and have long supported its rights, and I would also like to apologize to the Ukrainian people for the actions of Czech President Milos Zeman, who will use every opportunity to damage Czech-Ukrainian relations. I would really like to apologise for the czech president's behave towards the Ukrainian people. In order for Ukraine not to become our black conscience, we must maintain sanctions, insist on the full return of Crimea to Ukrainian hands.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, following the overwhelming majority of interventions, I can conclude that we all need to continue keeping the non-recognition of the illegal annexation of the Crimean peninsula high on our agenda, continuing to closely monitor developments in the Azov Sea and reflecting on how we can further support Ukraine in this regard.  I also believe that we can agree that we should use all opportunities in our bilateral and multilateral contacts to reiterate our principle position on the illegal annexation and to state that Crimea is Ukraine. Ms Gill, on this we can really rely on the unambiguous position of all EU Member States. Full stop.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – I visited Crimea in 2001. At that time, this beautiful peninsula was a symbol of peaceful reconciliation after the sorrowful years of the Cold War. During the past five years, the tides in the Azov and Black Sea have turned and the peninsula that lies in between now serves a strategic goal for Russia. The Russian authorities have bought off the people by artificially pumped—up salaries, and dissidents have been either silenced or tortured and imprisoned. Russia uses whatever pretext to secure the gateway to the Eurasian heartland and yearns to be the pivot of the Black Sea. I praise the Crimean Estonians, who boycotted the referendum of 2014, which they rightly thought was illegal. Despite the fact that Crimea was occupied by the commands bellowed by Putin and thanks to the collaboration of the Ukrainian Government of that time, we can all take the blame for this tragedy, as our responsive and responsible foreign policy tends to be lethargic at critical moments. Crimea is a costly project for the Kremlin – we still have the chance to make it fail by ending the NordStream2 Programme, which helps Russia to pay their ‘occupation bills’.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Brando Benifei, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on "Post-Arab Spring: future prospects for the Middle East and North Africa" (2018/2160(INI)) (A8-0077/2019)

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, eight years ago, thousands of women and men, particularly young people, took to the streets of the entire southern and eastern shores of the Mediterranean to demand more democracy, respect for their rights, fundamental freedoms, work and social inclusion. Eight years after those protests, which marked a break with the patterns of the past, it is time to take stock of the changes that have taken place in the region and, above all, of the Action of the European Union. While what is commonly referred to as the 'Arab Spring' and which, in reality, has been a series of several stages of progress has in fact led individual countries to take different paths, from greater democratisation to new regimes if not a situation of civil war, Europe has first and foremost sought to accompany the democratic pressures that had emerged. However, following the growing terrorist threat from Daesh and the outbreak of the refugee crisis, Europe has been led to focus more on stabilising our partner countries, security and curbing immigration. In short, once again we have repeated the same mistakes as in the past, not understanding that this would continue the vicious circle from which the people of this complicated region are trying to free themselves. This is what we are still seeing today in Algeria, which is in danger of becoming a new Syria if the situation is underestimated once again. The Union would have many means at its disposal for a more effective foreign policy, but renewed action must necessarily be based on a coordinated approach and greater unity. If the Member States each continue to pursue their own interests in the very short term, sometimes in conflict with each other, we will continue to fail to influence the complex processes that run through the region, thus increasingly playing the role of payers and non-actors, as has happened in Syria. We must therefore deeply rethink our policy towards this very important part of our neighbourhood, taking up our fundamental principles as a polar star. As indicated in the overall strategy for the common foreign and security policy, we must invest more in the resilience of these societies and not in mere stabilisation: stabilising a country by legitimising its authoritarian regimes, repression and social exclusion can work temporarily but risks, over time, re-escalating tensions that are only apparently subtly. Instead, we need a long-term approach, focusing on people and their aspirations, democracy, human rights, social inclusion and socio-economic development. After all, what has emerged from the Arab spring is first and foremost a great crisis of confidence on the part of citizens towards their institutions, which requires the construction of a new social contract, which the Union must encourage and support. The report therefore proposes an approach that takes into account the point of view of the populations involved: a constant and structured dialogue with civil society, including in its minor and local components; an approach that makes young people protagonists, who constitute an important and dynamic part but also vulnerable to these societies. That is why we are proposing to set up permanent advisory councils for young people in the Eu ropean Union delegations and we are proposing an Erasmus Euro-Mediterranean model exchange and work programme, with dedicated resources. We also call, among the many points touched on, for the Member States to put an end to the sale of weapons and equipment used for internal repression against regimes that do not respect human rights. Furthermore, we reiterate that greater cooperation cannot be separated from investigative and judicial cooperation, even in cases involving young Europeans, such as the well-known one of Giulio Regeni, for whom we are still waiting for the truth. In conclusion, therefore, we need a paradigm shift, and we believe that this report points out a path that responds more closely to the aspirations for dialogue, growth and cooperation with our southern and Mediterranean neighbourhood.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, first I wish to thank the rapporteur, Mr Benifei, for his report on the situation in certain countries of the MENA region since the Arab Spring. We very much agree with the main point raised by the report, that almost a decade after the beginning of the Arab uprising, many of the demands that moved so many people to take to the streets are still largely unanswered in most countries. The demand for better democracies, the demand for social justice, the demand for freedom of expression, in short, the demand for more inclusive systems of governance. This was the core of the Arab Spring and some countries have come a long way since 2011.  I am thinking, in particular, of Tunisia, which was the first country to rise up and is still a point of reference for the region. Our global strategy for foreign and security policy makes it very clear. Stability in this region cannot be guaranteed if these demands are ignored or denied. A resilient state needs a resilient society and a resilient society must feature democracy, trust in institutions and sustainable development.  With this in mind, let me emphasise three points. First, no one supports civil society in the Maghreb and Mashreq as much as we Europeans do. Not only have we established a forum for civil society of the neighbourhood south, which is now led directly by civil society organisations. EU delegations across the region are in permanent contact with civil society representatives. We are already working, as suggested in the report, to promote constant consultations with them, with the help of dedicated contact points in each delegation.  The report also mentions the essential work carried out by the European initiative for democracy and human rights and our work to protect human rights defenders. In this context, as also stressed in the report, our engagement with young people is the core of all our policies. There can be no resilience and no democracy without the full engagement of young people. They must find their place in our societies and find the opportunity to follow their dreams.
