Their voice must be heard.  For this reason, we have created a safe platform for the youth of the region, in order to listen to them and help us to define priorities. It’s called Young Med Voices Plus and its purpose is for young people to have an open dialogue with decision-makers and to shape the decision we make. About one month ago they had the chance to be part of the 5+5 dialogue of the Western Mediterranean and to shape the outcomes of the meeting.  I would like to stress that we engage with civil society in all contexts, even the most difficult ones, so my second point is about Syria. As you know, we recently hosted the third Brussels conference on the future of Syria and the region and we decided to put Syrian civil society at the centre of the conference. We gathered over 400 NGOs, engaged everyday on the ground, both in Syria and in the rest of the region, with a special focus on women. We offered them a safe space to meet and to engage ideas and we brought their voice to the table of decision-makers.  This is something we are truly proud of because Syria belongs to the Syrians and the only way to end this conflict is to help the Syrian people, together with the United Nations, build a democratic, inclusive, united and reconciled Syria.  We all know that the situation in the Middle East and North Africa is far from ideal and the aspirations of the Arab Spring have too often been betrayed. The only way to address this state of affairs is to engage relentlessly with all relevant actors. We must continue to engage with civil society, to support them and to help create the space for them to work freely, but we must also engage with governments and advocate the change we would like to see in our region. This would be my final point: human rights and democracy are always at the centre of our engagement with all governments in the region. We, as the European Union, always raise the issue of human rights, sometimes in public and sometimes in private, in our meetings with our counterparts. We fully share the spirit of this report. We want to help our friends on the other side of the Mediterranean to fulfil their aspiration towards better democracies, more freedom and more social justice.  So let me thank you again for your work, and even the more critical aspects, which we take very seriously and we will work to address. We share the same goals and no one is as engaged as the European Union to achieve them.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the This is not only an issue that is important for the development of the region there, but also in order to achieve stability, better living conditions, a situation that must also lead us to ensure security in connection with migration.  If there is no economic and social development there, there will be no stable states, and then there will be no effective cooperation that will make it possible, for example, to fight the traffickers of human beings in order to create the conditions for people to stop dying in the Mediterranean – as in the Sahara region. I believe that we must deliver, and Mr Benifei, in a good report in which he has been very cooperative, has put forward proposals that may also allow countries to strengthen among themselves. Trade relations with Europe are still colonial, but not among themselves. If economic development has to develop there – and, Commissioner, perhaps we should also make more support for cross-border cooperation, with greater infrastructure cooperation among themselves, in order to strengthen the trade relations of such a region in such a way, which will enable us to have better political and economic development in this way, or vice versa, in order to achieve such an improvement.  I believe that this is our immediate neighbourhood, that are the states that share the Mare Nostrum, the Mediterranean, with us. We need cooperation here, and that is why I think it is important that we make a great effort here to strengthen these countries in such a way that, also out of our own interest, these countries are improved in such a way that they can improve the situation for the people there, which is a prerequisite for peace in the Mediterranean and around the Mediterranean, and for the consolidation of democracy and the rule of law in these countries as well.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the European silence on peaceful popular demonstrations in Algeria demonstrates how little we have learned from the Arab Spring. And so we continue to feed fictions such as that Libya has government and navail forces or that sisi's militaristic government - which killed Giulio Regeni and oppresses, arrests and tortures more Egyptians than the deposed Mubarak - is a respectable and cooperative partner. If Europe gives up a comprehensive and consistent strategy for the Southern Mediterranean region based on the values and principles it proclaims and which should stand alongside peoples who call for freedom, democracy, justice and development and not the regimes that prevent them, then we will neither help these brother peoples nor defend our interests, including our security , which is inextricably linked to theirs and the ability to create jobs and socio-economic opportunities for young people. The points highlighted by Mr Brando Benifei in this report are therefore very important, by highlighting the objectives for European Union action in the region, starting with political dialogue, respect for human rights, women and minorities, and above all by stressing the demand for integrated policies to end the mafias of human traffickers and other trafficking , linked to terrorist groups, which are financed through offshore, consented by the European Union and the European Union itself, just as it is necessary to stop the sale of arms by Member States and other regional actors who end up in the hands of criminal and terrorist groups in the region and will eventually turn against us in Europe.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Well... I think that lessons need to be learned from the Arab Spring, and these conclusions are also too hasty at times to look at the situation in the region and sometimes to support those political forces that, in the long term, can cause even greater problems in these countries than they did before. And I think that a little bit of realism, pragmatism, would be useful in assessing these very accidents. We certainly need to support those people who want to have the values that we have here in that region, but we also need to be very careful that this is not a prelude to actions that are detrimental to us.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, this was one of the first topics I got involved with as an MEP and it’s now one of the topics I close with: the Arab uprisings, or rather the courageous uprisings of people against repression, corruption and the lack of opportunity and freedom to shape their own lives. The promise of these values is precious and people calling for them should find solid European support. Us not impacting neighbours does not mean they won’t impact us.  I will always stay with a sense of missed opportunity. If the EU had invested more forcefully in the freedoms and rights of the largely young and desperate populations in the Middle East and North Africa, what could have happened? Because whatever you give attention – and, frankly speaking, money – to, grows. That is why we pushed for a Marshall Plan for the Middle East to invest in democracy, education and human rights, particularly those of women and minorities. Because after years of being plundered by corrupt and authoritarian leaders, institution building and transition are hard but they are very much worth investing in. At some point the EU actually took an opposite turn. The war in Syria and the people it sent adrift towards Europe made for cynical trade-offs in the form of so-called ‘migration management’ – a euphemism for outsourcing the sheltering of people fleeing the worst violence we have seen in a long time, and outsourcing that responsibility to others in exchange for money, to the same kinds of dictators that caused people to flee in the meantime. Looking at Algeria today, it looks like we’ve come full circle. Egypt is still a time bomb and so is Turkey. Libya is a failed state and, as I said, the war in Syria rages on. Unfortunately, and I think this is very damaging, Europe is not a key player to solve that war.  So there are painful but important lessons that the Arab uprisings can teach us about our role in the world. We should continue to improve our policies and not step away from our responsibilities because our fates are intertwined with those of the people in the Middle East.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the high hopes and demands that drove the Arab Spring remain unfulested today. In most countries, the root causes of popular mobilization—social inequality, unemployment, lack of opportunity, authoritarianism, repression, corruption—remain un addressed, and worse, the situation in some countries is deteriorating. It must be acknowledged that the European Union's response to post-Arab Developments was also out of the task. It underlines the lack of vision and ambition, as well as the fact that some Member States have often prioritized particular interests and special relations over a coordinated and coherent response. It is necessary for the European Union to place human rights and democratisation at the heart of its policy towards the MENA region, since authoritarian states are inherently fragile and since stability and prosperity in the region cannot be achieved without democratic systems that address social inequalities and respect human rights.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – (20) Mr President, eight years after the so-called Arab Spring, it must be noted that the just discontent of the people has been made possible by the Western powers. These regions became more instable, more insecure, we had military intervention in Libya, we had military intervention in Syria, imperialism caused the complete destabilization of that territory and objectively strengthened terrorism, human trafficking and all organized crime activities associated with it. Such events, as reality shows, do not arise by chance, they are part of a broader strategy to master the energy materials that abound there in those territories. Unfortunately, we note in this resolution a total lack of critical view of the role of the European Union, NATO and the United States in these regions. We condemn the instrumentalization of human rights and call for respect for international legality and sovereignty of peoples.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the Arab Spring was not a spring but a winter, a long winter of death and destruction. It was an Islamist winter, from which the region is struggling to get out. If there are a few buds today, it is because the revolutionary Islamists were defeated by the army in Egypt or by the Russians and Iranians in Syria. All this took place against the will of the European Union. Supported by the Americans and Europeans, the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt and Tunisia, the Salafists in Syria, the two together in Libya have sowed destruction and violence. The region is reaping chaos. The Benifei report states that these events were democratic. They were actually remotely controlled like the color revolutions in Eastern Europe.  The solution for the region lies neither in an above-ground democratization nor in an abstract right-of-hommism, it is, on the contrary, in the consolidation of the power of States, the only guarantee of the stability of peace.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The report on the Arab Spring and its aftermath sets it up as a spontaneous event and a great event for what happened in 2011. Dictatorships have been replaced by a society of democracy and freedom, of course there are still problems. The reality is that the Arab Spring was, above all, an American project, with the deployment of American, British and French forces. Dictatorships were abolished, but anarchy came instead. Let us look, for example, at what Libya has come to in eight years of democracy. As the most serious consequence for us, the illegal influx of migrants has started, endangering Europe's security, identity and culture. The EU could report on a number of problems, such as the unresolved situation of indigenous minorities and their legitimate need for autonomy. If we're going to deal with these in the Arab Spring instead, let's at least talk about reality.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, the record of the Arab Spring is more than mixed. I do not believe at all that it is possible to compare developments in the region with the anti-communist revolutions of the late 1980s or the Orange Revolution, which the Kremlin voice suggested earlier. At the Maghreb level, we see that there are countries that are persevering in the effort of democratization: this is the case of Tunisia. There are also other countries that are struggling to implement credible and sustainable reforms. We therefore do not have this synchronization of the democratisation process that we have seen, for example, in the countries of Eastern and Central Europe in the late 1980s. I believe that our Union has a major role to play in supporting emerging democratic movements and in supporting economic developments that enable young people to have opportunities for professional integration. Our strategy has been more or less successful, depending on the country and the context, and I am convinced that conditionality is the right approach. We must continue to put the issue of respect for human rights and the rule of law at the forefront in our relations with our partners.  However, we also have things to improve: our coherence, including the tendency of Member States to act outside the European framework as soon as we are faced with a crisis, for example in the face of Russia and unwavering support for all authoritarian regimes in the region. Our message needs to be more compelling. The European Union has a lot of cards to play, especially with regard to the reconstruction of Syria, which cannot be done without our financial support and political support.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, eight years ago, hopes were high for a more inclusive and democratic MENA region. Unfortunately, the overall picture now looks bleak. The main factors that contributed to dissatisfaction and upheaval in 2011 have worsened. Income disparity and youth unemployment have increased: in fact, it is the highest globally. Instead of tackling these fundamental challenges, the EU – driven by Member States – has narrowed its interests to simply security and migration management. This short-sighted approach ignores the brewing anger and frustration in our southern neighbourhood, and it is just a matter of time before it comes back to haunt us.  Commissioner, I have received emails from my constituents about human rights abuses against migrants in Libya, widely reported in our media. What has the EU done to investigate these allegations about EU-funded actors? Secondly, how does the EU support MENA societies working towards constructing new economic orders, given that the rentier economic system has failed to keep pace with rising demands from a growing population? How are we focused to have access to decision-making, particularly for young people, effective service provision and combating corruption? Thirdly, the Russian footprint in the region has expanded visibly. How are we responding to these geopolitical ambitions?

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Arab Spring is a very important experience, a very important lesson that cannot be forgotten, a lesson in responsibility. And it's not about abstract political realism at all, it's about just being responsible for people, because the Arab Spring is the syrian civil war, the war to be waged for democracy until the last Syrian is the civil war in Libya. The Arab Spring is also the context in which ISIS appeared. I agree with the voices in the Chamber that said that we must be involved in the development of the Maghreb countries. In development definitely yes, but that does not mean that we are to engage in conflicts with unpredictable results, especially since we are seeing these tragic results today.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: Mr President, "God laughs at men who complain about the effects of which they cherish the causes." This quote from Bossuet comes to mind when I see the deconded mines of the Europeanists five years after the Arab revolutions you called springs.  With the complicity of the Obama administration, you have started wars in Syria and Libya, the consequences of which have proved catastrophic, from the rise of Islamic terrorism to the migratory submersion that we know today. The Sarkozys and Hollandes will one day have to be accountable to the peoples of Europe, especially with regard to the case of France.  The European Union has been marginalised in the Arab world by supporting the losers in Syria and Egypt, and has contributed, again in the name of democratic renewal, to the collapse of Libya, with the consequences that we know.  The European Union, more than ever, will have demonstrated its true function: to be the substitute for globalism, whose peoples must suffer first and foremost the consequences of its bliss and political harmfulness. The only solution for these peoples and the whole region will be the sovereignty of restored states.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, our southern neighbourhood is very important. Unfortunately, in recent years, in many of these countries the hopes opened by the Arab Spring did not bear fruit in stable and prosperous democratic regimes. On the contrary, there are many problems they now face. They have serious challenges: political, economic, social, security; these countries have to be a priority for the institutions of the Union.  These last twenty years, from here we have given great attention to the countries of eastern Europe, and our southern neighbours have felt somewhat abandoned by us. There, now, the ones that grow are the Gulf countries, particularly. And yet there are many interests and challenges we share: security, emigration, climate change, energy supply, counter-terrorism, important trade flows to preserve, investments, etc.  In addition, we need to intensify our political dialogue with these countries, both bilaterally and within the multilateral framework. And there we have the Union for the Mediterranean, which has turned ten and has not been sufficiently used, despite the significant expectations with which it was born and which, however, with the consequences of the Arab Spring, has not been able to realize its full potential. On the other hand, I would like to stress that many of the Member States , for example mine, Spain – have close ties with the countries of the southern neighbourhood for geographical and historical reasons. We must all row — these countries, the European Union — in the same direction: dialogue, cooperation, investment flows that help modernisation and economic diversification within this region, and also help the training of young people. The Mediterranean countries, I repeat, must be a priority priority for the European Union and its Member States.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The European Union's ambition to play a meaningful role in shaping the future of the crisis-stricken region of the Middle East and North Africa, and in recovering countries struggling with the mismatling consequences of the Arab Spring, is to be commended. Addressing and resolving the migration crisis in the Mediterranean, which is expected to worsen, is in the common interest of the issuing, transit and destination countries, namely the Middle Eastern, North African and Sub-Saharan and European states. The EU needs to review its failed migration policy so far. By eliminating its root causes, with broad international cooperation and support, it should stop illegal immigration in their country of departure. You don't have to bring trouble here, you have to bring help there. This is the Hungarian model.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, it’s worth staying in the Chamber to make an important point, isn’t it?  When the Arab Spring blossomed, European states missed the opportunity to develop an ambitious foreign policy, based on human rights, democracy and the rule of law. We let down the young generations who led these movements by prioritising shortsighted economic interests over support for a long—term path towards democracy. We could have been ambitious, but instead we protected our own interests. We asked of our neighbours that they handle migration for us, we closed our borders, we continued selling arms, and we continued to close our eyes to the deteriorating situation of human rights defenders and the appalling record when it comes to women and LGBTQ+.  As young people in Algeria are now protesting and trying to create a peaceful movement, it is time for the EU’s foreign policy to live up to its full potential. It’s time to stand up for human rights in the Middle East, North Africa and everywhere else.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, first I would like to thank the entire House for all its contributions. I think it was a fruitful debate and many interesting points were raised. This report calls for improved cooperation between the EU Member States and our southern neighbours towards a partnership focused on human rights, sustainable socio-economic development and democracy, which we see as a priority. We will consider carefully the House’s concerns and proposals and will continue to do our utmost to make the Mediterranean a place of enhanced dialogue and cooperation for the benefit of its two shores. But I would also like to respond to Mr Brok, who has already left us. I think it is also about inter-regional cooperation amongst the countries in the south, where a lot of potential is still untapped. Thank you again for this report. It is a huge backing for our work in the region.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Before giving the floor to the rapporteur, Mr Brando Benifei, I wanted to say that I would be very pleased to take part in this debate, but I had to replace an urgent colleague. However, I would like to congratulate him on the work he has done.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, all the more so because of the words that have just been spoken. I would also like to thank Commissioner Hahn for his valuable contribution to this debate, just as I would like to thank all my fellow Members for their contribution, which I believe has also enriched our prospects. I am sure, with reference once again to the Commissioner, that he will take into account, in his work on the southern neighbourhood, the comments made in the report and also in this debate. I would also like to mention the role of the FEMM Committee and the rapporteur, Maria Arena, who was not present but presented a very useful opinion, fundamentally enriching our report on the role of women in the processes of building the resilience of societies in this region. Certainly, the current neighbourhood policy, as revisioned in 2015, has had the merit of introducing the concepts of differentiation, which is necessary to take account of the specific realities of each country, and of contitolarity, which puts the EU and partner countries on an egalitarian level from the point of view of identifying priorities, putting an end to policies perceived as falling from above. I would, however, like to stress that, as this report also shows, we believe that this should not necessarily result in a less capacity to influence partner countries. We expressly call, also in the report, for the conditionality criterion to be applied more rigorously and not just for the views of the authorities to be heard. Building real resilience requires, in a stronger way, the point of view of civil society, and I am also happy with the commitment put in place on Syria in this regard, as the Commissioner has mentioned. A civil society that must be the real protagonist for our action, with particular attention to human rights defenders, who risk their lives every day for the rights of vulnerable groups and minorities. I am therefore convinced, in conclusion, that the text we are going to approve tomorrow will be an important legacy of the European Parliament for the new parliamentary term and for the continuation of the European Union's policies in one of the most strategic areas for our external action.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed.  The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday, March 27, 2019. Written statements (Rule 162) – I believe that this is the right time to take stock of the last five years with regard to EU policies in the Mediterranean. At a time as complex as the present one, almost ten years after the Arab spring, I would like to ask my colleagues: where have we come so far? And most importantly, where are we headed? Unfortunately, and it is clear to everyone, there has been no great progress. Egypt has returned to its starting point with a new military regime that favours stability over human rights. We don't even talk about it in Libya. The only example of a 'successful Arab Spring' remains Tunisia, even though young democracy is under constant attack. In Algeria, we have recently seen the protests of young people against the old ruling class, the desire for change, social mobility and concrete reforms for the country. But the future scenario remains uncertain. It is now up to Europe to play its part: I call for greater coherence but, above all, for a long-term approach that really takes account of the needs of citizens and addresses the root causes of radicalisation, through policies focused on people and young people.
